translated: Such, sire, are the possessions of Ghaṭikāra the potter, with which he has served the Tathāgata and his community of monks,

original: mātāpitarau ca jīrṇau vṛddhau durbalacakṣū //
analyzed: mātā pitarau ca jīrṇau vṛddhau durbala cakṣū
translated: and with which he has maintained his aged and blind parents.

original: ekamidamaha mahārāja samaya veruḍiṅge brāhmaṇagrāme viharāmi //
analyzed: ekam idam aha mahā rāja veruḍiṅge brāhmaṇa grāme viharāmi
translated: There was one occasion, sire, when I was staying in the brāhman village of Veruḍiṅga.

original: so ha mahārāja kalyameva nivāsayitvā pātracīvaramādāya veruḍiṅga brāhmaṇagrāma piṇḍāya prakrāmi //
analyzed: saḥ ha mahā rāja kalyam eva nivāsayitvā pātra cīvaram ādāya veruḍiṅga brāhmaṇagrāma piṇḍāya prakrāmi
translated: And, sire, having dressed in the morning, I took my bowl and outer robe and went to Veruḍiṅga for alms.

original: so ha mahārāja veruḍiṅge brāhmaṇagrāme sāvadāna piṇḍāya caranto yena ghaṭikārasya kumbhakārasya niveśana tenopasakramitvā uddeśe asthāsi
analyzed: saḥ ha mahā rāja veruḍiṅge brāhmaṇa grāme sa avadāna piṇḍāya carantaḥ yena ghaṭikārasya kumbhakārasya niveśana tena upasakramitvā uddeśe asthāsi
translated: He, great king, while wandering for alms in the brahmin village of Veruḍiṅga, having approached the dwelling of Ghaṭikāra the potter, stood to one side.

original: tena khalu punaḥ samayena ghaṭikāro kumbhakāro svakānniveśanānniṣkrānto abhūṣi //
analyzed: tena khalu punar samayena ghaṭikāraḥ kumbhakāraḥ svakāt niveśanāt niṣkrāntaḥ
translated: At that time, great king, Ghaṭikāra the potter had gone out from his dwelling.

original: atha khalu mahārāja ghaṭikārasya kumbhakārasya mātāpitarau tatāgatametadavocat //
analyzed: atha khalu mahā rāja ghaṭikārasya kumbhakārasya mātā pitarau tata āgatam etat avocat
translated: Then, great king, Ghaṭikāra the potter's parents said this to the Tathāgata:

original: niṣkrānto te bhagava upasthāyako //
analyzed: niṣkrāntau te bhagavaḥ upasthāyakaḥ
translated: Blessed One, your attendant has gone out.

original: eṣo uparikoṣṭhake sūpaśca odanaśca ato bhagavā paribhujatu //
analyzed: eṣa u upari koṣṭhake sūpaḥ ca odanaḥ ca atas bhagavā paribhujatu
translated: Here, in the upper room, there is rice and curry. May the Blessed One partake of it.

original: so ha mahārāja uparikoṣṭhakātsūpa odana ca devatāhi pratigrāhetvā paribhujitvā prakrāmi //
analyzed: saḥ ha mahā rāja upari koṣṭhakāt sūpaḥ odana ca
translated: He, great king, having had the rice and curry from the upper room accepted by the deities, partook of it and departed.

original: atha khalu mahārāja ghaṭikāro kumbhakāro yena svaka niveśana tenopasakrami //
analyzed: atha khalu mahā rāja ghaṭikāraḥ kumbhakāraḥ yena svaka niveśana tena upasakrami
translated: Then, great king, Ghaṭikāra the potter approached his own dwelling.

original: adrākṣītkhalu mahārāja ghaṭikāro kumbhakāro uparikoṣṭhakā sūpa ca odana ca paribhakta dṛṣṭvāna punarmātāpitarau etadavocat //
analyzed: adrākṣīt khalu mahā rāja ghaṭikāraḥ kumbhakāraḥ uparikoṣṭhakā sūpa ca odana ca paribhakta dṛṣṭvāna punar mātā pitarau etat avocat
translated: Great king, Ghaṭikāra the potter saw that the rice and curry in the upper room had been partaken of. Having seen it, he again said this to his parents:

original: kenimā tāta ghaṭikārasya uparikoṣṭhakā sūpo ca odana ca paribhuktā //
analyzed: kenimā tāta ghaṭikārasya uparikoṣṭhakā ca odana ca paribhuktā
translated: Who has eaten the soup and rice in the upper room of Ghaṭikāra?

original: evamukte mahārāja ghaṭikārasya kumbhakārasya mātāpitarau ghaṭikāra kumbhakārametadavocat //
analyzed: evam ukte mahā rāja ghaṭikārasya kumbhakārasya mātā pitarau ghaṭikāra kumbhakāram etat avocat
translated: When this was said, Your Majesty, Ghaṭikāra the potter's parents said this to Ghaṭikāra the potter:

original: bhagavatā putra kāśyapena //
analyzed: bhagavatā putra kāśyapena
translated: Son, it was eaten by the Blessed One Kāśyapa.

original: atha khalu mahārāja ghaṭikārasya kumbhakārasya etadabhavat //
analyzed: atha khalu mahā rāja ghaṭikārasya kumbhakārasya etat abhavat
translated: Then, Your Majesty, this occurred to Ghaṭikāra the potter:

original: labdhā punarme sulabdhā lābhā yasya me bhagavā kāśyapo yāvadeko pi ativiśvasto //
analyzed: labdhā punar me su labdhāḥ lābhāḥ yasya me bhagavā kāśyapaḥ
translated: I have gained great gain, in that the Blessed One Kāśyapa, though so very trustworthy,

original: tasya caivamardhamāsa prītisukha kāya na vijahati saptāha ca mātāpṛtṛṇā jīrṇavṛddhānā durbalacakṣūṇā //
analyzed: tasya ca evam ardha māsa prīti sukha kāya na vijahati sapta aha ca mātāpṛtṛṇām jīrṇa vṛddhānām durbala cakṣūṇām
translated: and for half a month his mother and father, who are old, aged, and decrepit, and his eyes are weak.

original: ekamida mahārāja samaya tathāgatasya araṇyakuṭikāye chādyamānāye tṛṇāni na sabhuṇānti //
analyzed: ekam idam mahā rāja samaya tathāgatasya araṇya kuṭi kāye chādyamānāye tṛṇāni na
translated: Once, Your Majesty, at a time when the Tathāgata was having a hut built in the forest, the grass was not cut.

original: so ha mahārāja bhikṣūṇāmāmantrayesi //
analyzed: saḥ ha mahā rāja bhikṣūṇām āmantrayesi
translated: Then, Your Majesty, he addressed the monks:

original: gacchatha bhikṣavo ghaṭikārasya kumbhakārasya niveśana tṛṇāni ānetha //
analyzed: gacchatha bhikṣavaḥ ghaṭikārasya kumbhakārasya niveśana tṛṇāni ānetha
translated: Go, monks, to the house of Ghaṭikāra the potter and bring back grass.

original: atha khalu mahārāja te bhikṣūḥ yena ghaṭikrārasya kumbhakārasya niveśana tenopasakramensuḥ //
analyzed: atha khalu mahā rāja te bhikṣūḥ yena ghaṭikrārasya kumbhakārasya niveśana tena upasakramensuḥ
translated: Then, Your Majesty, those monks went to the dwelling of Ghaṭikāra the potter.

original: tena khalu punarmahārāja samayena ghaṭikāro kumbhakāraḥ svakāto niveśanāto niṣkrānto abhūṣi //
analyzed: tena khalu punar mahā rāja samayena ghaṭikāraḥ kumbhakāraḥ svakātaḥ niveśanātaḥ niṣkrāntaḥ
translated: Now at that time, Your Majesty, Ghaṭikāra the potter had gone out from his dwelling.

original: te tatra nādṛśensu tṛṇāni addaśensu navacchadanā āveśanaśālā //
analyzed: te tatra na adṛśensu tṛṇāni nava chadanā āveśana śālā
translated: They saw there no grass, but they saw a newly-thatched shed.

original: atha khalu mahārāja te bhikṣūḥ yena tathāgato tenopasakramitvā tathāgatasya pādau śirasā vanditvā tathāgata ca etadavocat //
analyzed: atha khalu mahā rāja te bhikṣūḥ yena tathāgataḥ tena upasakramitvā tathāgatasya pādau śirasā vanditvā tathāgata ca etat avocat
translated: Then, Your Majesty, those monks went to the Tathāgata, and, having bowed at his feet, said to him:

original: niṣkrānto te bhagava upasthāyako nāsti cātra kānici tṛṇāni asti cātra navacchadanā āveśanaśālā //
analyzed: niṣkrāntaḥ u te bhagavaḥ upasthāyakaḥ na asti ca atra kānicid tṛṇāni asti ca atra nava chadanā āveśana śālā
translated: “Lord, our attendant has gone out, and there is no grass here, but there is a newly-thatched shed.”

original: evamukte mahārāja tā bhikṣu etadavocat //
analyzed: evam ukte mahā rāja tāḥ bhikṣu etat avocat
translated: When this had been said, Your Majesty, those monks said to them:

original: gacchatha bhikṣavo ghaṭikārasya kumbhakārasya navacchadanā āveśanaśālā uttṛṇīkṛtvā tṛṇāni ānetha //
analyzed: gacchatha bhikṣavaḥ ghaṭikārasya kumbhakārasya nava chadanāḥ āveśana śālāḥ uttṛṇīkṛtvā tṛṇāni ānetha
translated: “Go, monks, and take grass from Ghaṭikāra the potter’s newly-thatched shed.”

original: atha khalu mahārāja te bhikṣū yena ghaṭikārasya kumbhakārasya niveśana tenopasakramitvā ghaṭikārasya kumbhakārasya navacchadanāmāveśanaśālāmuttṛṇīkarensu
analyzed: atha khalu mahā rāja te bhikṣū yena ghaṭikārasya kumbhakārasya niveśana tena upasakramitvā ghaṭikārasya kumbhakārasya navacchadanām āveśana śālām uttṛṇīkaren su
translated: Then, Your Majesty, those monks went to the house of Ghaṭikāra the potter and swept out his new roofed hall.

original: atha khalu mahārāja ghaṭikārasya kumbhakārasya mātāpitarau tā bhikṣūnetadavocat //
analyzed: atha khalu mahā rāja ghaṭikārasya kumbhakārasya mātā pitarau tāḥ bhikṣūn etat avocat
translated: Then, Your Majesty, Ghaṭikāra the potter’s parents said to those monks:

original: ko eṣa ghaṭikārasya kumbhakārasya navacchadanāmāveśanaśālāmuttṛṇīkṛtvā tṛṇāni harati //
analyzed: kaḥ eṣa ghaṭikārasya kumbhakārasya navacchadanām āveśanaśālām uttṛṇīkṛtvā tṛṇāni harati
translated: ‘Who has swept out Ghaṭikāra the potter’s new roofed hall and carried off the grass?’

original: evamukte mahārāja te bhikṣū ghaṭikārasya kumbhakārasya mātāpitarau etaduvāca //
analyzed: evam ukte mahā rāja te bhikṣū ghaṭikārasya kumbhakārasya mātā pitarau etat uvāca
translated: When this had been said, Your Majesty, those monks said to Ghaṭikāra the potter’s parents:

original: yatra āyuṣma bhikṣūṇā bhagavato kāśyapasya ca araṇyakuṭikāye chādyamānāye tṛṇā na sabhuṇanti tatra etāni tṛṇāni nīyanti //
analyzed: yatra āyuṣma bhikṣūṇā bhagavataḥ kāśyapasya ca araṇya kuṭi kāye chādyamānāye tṛṇāḥ na sabhuṇanti tatra etāni tṛṇāni nīyanti
translated: ‘The grass was taken because the grass in the forest hermitage of the exalted Kāśyapa was not sufficient to roof his cell.’

original: evamukte mahārāja ghaṭikārasya kumbhakārasya mātāpitarau tā bhikṣūnetadavocat //
analyzed: evam ukte mahā rāja ghaṭikārasya kumbhakārasya mātā pitarau tāḥ bhikṣūn etat avocat
translated: When this had been said, Your Majesty, Ghaṭikāra the potter’s parents said to those monks:

original: haratha haratha svakāni va //
analyzed: haratha haratha svakāni vaḥ
translated: ‘Take it, take it. It is yours.

original: atha khalu mahārāja ghaṭikāro kumbhakāro yena svaka niveśana tenopasakramesi //
analyzed: atha khalu mahā rāja ghaṭikāraḥ kumbhakāraḥ yena svaka niveśana tena upasakramesi
translated: Then, Your Majesty, Ghaṭikāra the potter went to his own house.

original: adrākṣītkhalu mahārāja ghaṭikāro kumbhakāro navacchadanāmāveśanaśālāmuttṛṇīkṛtā tṛṇāni hṛtāni dṛṣṭvā ca punarmātāpitarau etadavocat //
analyzed: adrākṣīt khalu mahā rāja ghaṭikāraḥ kumbhakāraḥ navacchadanām āveśanaśālām uttṛṇīkṛtā tṛṇāni hṛtāni dṛṣṭvā ca punar mātā pitarau etat avocat
translated: There, Your Majesty, Ghaṭikāra the potter saw that the roof of the new house had been thatched and the grass carried off. When he saw this, he said to his parents:

original: kenimā tāta ghaṭikārasya kumbhakārasya navacchadanā āveśanaśālā uttṛṇīkṛtā tṛṇāni hṛtāni //
analyzed: kenimā tāta ghaṭikārasya kumbhakārasya nava chadanā āveśana śālā uttṛṇīkṛtā tṛṇāni hṛtāni
translated: “Father, mother, who has thatched the roof of Ghaṭikāra the potter’s new house and carried off the grass?”

original: evamukte ghaṭikārasya kubhakārasya mātāpitarau ghaṭikāra kumbhakārametadavocat //
analyzed: evam ukte ghaṭikārasya kubhakārasya mātā pitarau ghaṭikāra kumbhakāram etat avocat
translated: When this had been said, Ghaṭikāra the potter’s parents said to him:

original: bhagavato putra kāśyapasya araṇyakuṭikāye tṛṇāni na prabhavanti tatra etāni bhikṣubhistṛṇāni nītāni //
analyzed: bhagavataḥ putra kāśyapasya araṇya kuṭi kāye tṛṇāni na prabhavanti tatra etāni bhikṣubhiḥ tṛṇāni nītāni
translated: “Son, the grass has been taken by the monks for the Blessed One Kāśyapa’s hut in the forest.”

original: atha khalu mahārāja ghaṭikārasya kumbhakārasya etadabhavat //
analyzed: atha khalu mahā rāja ghaṭikārasya kumbhakārasya etat abhavat
translated: Then, Your Majesty, this occurred to Ghaṭikāra the potter:

original: labdhā me sulabdhā lābhā yatpunarasya me bhagavā kāśyapo yāvadeko pi ativiśvasto //
analyzed: labdhāḥ me su labdhāḥ lābhāḥ yat punar asya me bhagavā kāśyapaḥ yāvat ekaḥ ati viśvastaḥ
translated: “I have gained great gain, in that the Blessed One Kāśyapa, so very confident,

original: tasya caikamāsa prītisukha kāya na vijahe ardhamāsa ca andhānā mātāpitṛṇā //
analyzed: tasya ca eka māsa prīti sukha kāya na vijahe ardha māsa ca andhānā mātā pitṛṇā
translated: And for a month, he did not leave the side of his blind parents, nor for half a month.

original: na khalu punaraha mahārāja abhijānāmi ghaṭikārasya kumbhakārasya idamevarūpa daurmanasyapratilābha yathaiva mahārāje na me bhagavā kāśyapo
analyzed: na khalu punar aha mahā rāja abhijānāmi ghaṭikārasya kumbhakārasya idam evarūpa daurmanasya pratilābha yathā eva mahā rāje na me bhagavā kāśyapaḥ
translated: But, great king, I do not recall having caused Ghatikara the potter such sorrow as you have caused me, great king, by not allowing the Blessed One Kasyapa

original: adhivāsesi vārāṇasīye nagare varṣāvāsanti //
analyzed: vārāṇasīye nagare
translated: to spend the rainy season in the city of Varanasi.

original: atha khalvānanda kṛkisya kāśirājño etadabhavat /
analyzed: atha khalu ānanda kṛkisya kāśi rājñaḥ etat abhavat
translated: Then, Ananda, this occurred to King Kriki of Kashi:

original: lābhā punarme sulabdhā yasya me evarūpo brahmacārī vijite prativasati dvipādakāni puṇyakṣetrāṇi //
analyzed: lābhā punar me su labdhā yasya me evarūpaḥ brahmacārī vijite prativasati dvi pādakāni puṇya kṣetrāṇi
translated: It is a great gain for me that such a one who is a field of merit with two feet dwells in my realm.

original: atha khalvānanda kṛkī kāśirājā ghaṭikārasya kumbhakārasya parṇakulaśālisya śata vāhā preṣayet navodaka ca tailalavaṇakvathana //
analyzed: atha khalu ānanda kṛkī kāśi rājā ghaṭi kārasya kumbhakārasya parṇa kula śālisya śata vāhā preṣayet nava udaka ca taila lavaṇa kvathana
translated: Then, Ananda, King Kriki of Kashi sent a hundred loads of parna-rice, fresh water, oil, salt, and boiling water to Ghatikara the potter.

original: atha khalvānanda kāśyapo kṛki kāśirājāna dharmyayā kathayā sadarśayitvā samādāpayitvā samuttejayitvā sapraharṣayitvā utthāyāsanāto prakrāmi
analyzed: atha khalu ānanda kāśyapaḥ kṛki kāśi rājāna dharmyayā kathayā sa darśayitvā samādāpayitvā samuttejayitvā sa praharṣayitvā utthāya āsanāt prakrāmi
translated: Then, Ananda, after the Blessed One Kasyapa had instructed, inspired, fired, and delighted King Kriki of Kashi with a talk on Dhamma, he rose from his seat and departed.

original: atha khalvānanda bhagavā kāśyapo paścādbhakta piṇḍapātrapratikrānto bhikṣuṇāmāmantresi //🔽niṣīdatha bhikṣavo sannipatitha bhikṣavo bandhath paryaka eṣo hi paryaṅkra bandhāmi tāvadna bhindāmi yāvanna imeṣā saptānā bhikṣusahasrāṇāmetehi
analyzed: atha khalu ānanda bhagavā kāśyapaḥ paścāt bhakta piṇḍa pātra pratikrāntaḥ bhikṣuṇām āmantresi  niṣīdatha bhikṣavaḥ sannipatitha bhikṣavaḥ bandhath paryake eṣaḥ hi paryaṅkra bandhāmi tāvat na bhindāmi yāvat naḥ imeṣā bhikṣu sahasrāṇām etehi
translated: Then, Ānanda, after the meal, when the Blessed One Kāśyapa had finished his alms round, he addressed the monks:

original: eva āsanehi niṣaṇānā anupādāyāśravebhyaścittāni vimuktāni //
analyzed: eva āsanehi niṣaṇānāḥ an upādāya āśravebhyaḥ cittāni vimuktāni
translated: Sit down, monks, gather together, monks, bind your belts. For this is the time when I will bind the belt of the discourse, and I will not unbind it until seven thousand monks have been freed from the pollutants without further clinging right here on these very seats.

original: sādhu bhagavanniti te bhikṣu bhagavato kāśyapasya pratiśrutvā sanniṣīdensuḥ sanipatensuḥ bandhensuḥ paryaṅka //
analyzed: sādhu bhagavan iti te bhikṣu bhagavataḥ kāśyapasya pratiśrutvā sanniṣīdensuḥ sanipatensuḥ bandhensuḥ paryaṅka
translated: Very well, Blessed One, those monks replied to the Blessed One Kāśyapa, and they sat down, gathered together, and bound their belts.

original: ata khalvānanda jyotipālasya bhikṣusya ekarahogatasya pratisalīnasya ayamevarūpaścetaso parivitarko utpadye //🔽aho punaraha bhaveyamanāgatamadhvāna tathāgato arha samyaksabuddho vidyācaraṇasapannaḥ sugato lokavidanuttaraḥ puruṣadamyasārathiḥ śāstā
analyzed: atas khalu ānanda jyotipālasya bhikṣusya eka rahaḥ gatasya pratisalīnasya ayam evarūpaḥ cetasaḥ parivitarkaḥ utpadye  aho punar aha bhaveyam anāgatam adhvāna tathāgataḥ arha samyaksabuddhaḥ vidyā caraṇa sapannaḥ sugataḥ loka vid anuttaraḥ puruṣa damya sārathiḥ śāstā  /
translated: Then, Ānanda, while the monk Jyotipāla was alone in seclusion, this kind of reflection arose in his mind:🔽Oh, may I become in the future a Tathāgata, an Arhat, a Perfectly Enlightened One, endowed with knowledge and conduct, a Sugata, a knower of the world, an unsurpassed trainer of those who can be trained, a teacher of gods and humans,

original: devānā ca manuṣyāṇā ca //
analyzed: devānā ca manuṣyāṇā ca
translated: a Buddha, a Blessed One.

original: so ima ca lokamabhijñāya sadevaka loka samāraka sabrahmaka saśramaṇa prajā sadevamanuṣyā ihaiva vārāṇasyā ṛṣivadane mṛgadāve dharmacakra
analyzed: sā u ima ca lokam abhijñāya sa devaka loka sa māraka sa brahmaka sa śramaṇa prajā sa deva manuṣyā iha eva vārāṇasyāḥ ṛṣivadane mṛgadāve dharmacakra
translated: He, having understood this world, with its gods, Māras, and Brahmas, with its people with ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans, right here in Vārāṇasī, in the Ṛṣivadana Deer Park, set rolling the wheel of the Dharma,🔽🔽which is thrice-revolved and twelve-fold, and cannot be rolled back.

original: pravarteya dvādaśākāra apravartiya śramaṇena vā brāhmaṇena vā devena vā māreṇa vā kenacidvā punarloke saha dharmeṇa //
analyzed: śramaṇena vā brāhmaṇena vā devena vā māreṇa vā kenacid vā punar loke saha dharmeṇa
translated: He, having understood this world, with its devas, Māras, and Brahmās, with its people with ascetics and brahmins, devas and humans, will here in the Deer Park at Ṛṣivadana near Vārāṇasī set rolling the wheel of the Dharma that is thrice-revolved and twelve-fold, and will not be reproached by any ascetic or brahmin or deva or Māra or Brahmā or by anyone in the world.🔽He will teach the Dharma that is good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, with its own meaning, with its own phrasing, and will reveal the pure holy life.

original: eva sarvākārasapanna sarvākāraparipūrṇa ca dharma deśayeya yathāpi bhagavā kāśyapo etarahi //
analyzed: eva sarva ākāra sapanna sarva ākāra paripūrṇa ca dharma deśayeya yathā api bhagavā kāśyapaḥ etarahi
translated: Just as the Blessed One Kāśyapa does now.

original: eva ca devamanuṣyā śrotavya śraddhātavya manyensu yathā bhagavato kāśyapasya etarahi //
analyzed: eva ca deva manuṣyā śrotavya śraddhātavya manyensu yathā bhagavataḥ kāśyapasya etarahi
translated: And devas and humans will think of him as one to be heard and believed in, just as they do of the Blessed One Kāśyapa now.

original: ta bhaveya bahujanahitāya bahujanasukhāya lokānukampāya mahato janakāyasyārthāya hitāya sukhāya devānā ca manuṣyāṇā ca //
analyzed: ta bhaveya bahu jana hitāya bahu jana sukhāya loka anukampāya mahataḥ jana kāyasya arthāya hitāya sukhāya devānā ca manuṣyāṇā ca
translated: That will be for the benefit and welfare of the multitude, out of compassion for the world, for the good, benefit, and happiness of devas and humans.

original: hāyensu āsurā kāyā divyā kāyā abhivardhensu /
analyzed: āsurā kāyā divyā kāyā abhivardhensu
translated: The hosts of the Asuras will wane; the hosts of the devas will wax strong.

original: atha khalvānanda bhagavā kāśyapo jyotipālasya bhikṣusya idamevarūpa cetasā eva cetoparivitarkamājñāya anyatara bhikṣumāmantrayasi //
analyzed: atha khalu ānanda bhagavā kāśyapaḥ jyotipālasya bhikṣusya cetasā eva cetaḥ upari vitarkam ājñāya anyatara bhikṣum āmantrayasi
translated: Then, Ānanda, the Blessed One Kāśyapa, knowing with his mind the thoughts in the mind of the monk Jyotipāla, addressed a certain monk, saying:🔽Come, monk, go to the monk Jyotipāla and say to him:

original: ehi tva bhikṣu yena jyotipālo bhikṣustenopasakramitvā jyotipāla bhikṣumeva vadehi //🔽śāstā te āyuṣmā āmantreti /
analyzed: ehi tva bhikṣu yena jyotipālaḥ bhikṣuḥ tena upasakramitvā jyotipāla bhikṣum eva vadehi  śāstā te āyuṣmān āmantra iti
translated: 'The Blessed One, the Teacher, calls you, venerable Jyotipāla.'

original: upasakrame yena tathāgato //
analyzed: upasakrame yena tathāgataḥ
translated: Go to the Tathāgata.

original: bhagavato kāśyapasya pratiśrutvā yena jyotipālo bhikṣustenopasakramitvā jyotipāla bhikṣumetadavocat /
analyzed: bhagavataḥ kāśyapasya pratiśrutvā yena jyotipālaḥ bhikṣuḥ tena upasakramitvā jyotipāla bhikṣum etat avocat
translated: Having heard the Blessed One Kāśyapa, he went to the monk Jyotipāla and said this to him:

original: śāstā āyuṣma jyotipāla āmantrayati upasakrame yena bhagavā //
analyzed: śāstā āyuṣma jyotipālaḥ āmantrayati upasakrame yena bhagavā
translated: The Blessed One, the Teacher, calls you, venerable Jyotipāla. Go to the Blessed One.

original: sādhvāyuṣmanniti āyuṣmā jyotipālastasya bhikṣusya pratiśrutvā yana bhagavānkāśyapastenopasakramitvā bhagavataḥ kāśyapasya pādau śirasā vanditvā
analyzed: sādhu āyuṣman iti āyuṣmā jyotipālaḥ tasya bhikṣusya pratiśrutvā bhagavān kāśyapaḥ tena upasakramitvā bhagavataḥ kāśyapasya pādau śirasā vanditvā
translated: Very well, venerable one, said the venerable Jyotipāla, and having heard the monk, he went to the Blessed One Kāśyapa, and having approached him, he bowed his head at the feet of the Blessed One Kāśyapa

original: ekānte niṣīdi //
analyzed: ekānte
translated: and sat down to one side.

original: ekānte niṣaṇa āyuṣmanta jyotipāla bhikṣu bhagavā kāśyapa etadavocat //
analyzed: ekānte niṣaṇe āyuṣmanta jyotipāla bhikṣu bhagavā kāśyapaḥ etat avocat
translated: While the venerable Jyotipāla was sitting to one side, the Blessed One Kāśyapa said this to him:

original: nanu jyotipāla ekasya jyotipālasya rahogatasya pratisalīnasya ayamevarūpaścetaso parivitarka utpadye //
analyzed: nanu jyotipālaḥ ekasya jyotipālasya rahaḥ gatasya pratisalīnasya ayam evarūpaḥ cetasaḥ parivitarkaḥ utpadye
translated: But Jyotipāla, while he was alone in seclusion and retirement, this kind of thought arose in his mind:

original: aho punaraha bhaveya anāgatamadhvāna tathāgato rha samyaksabuddho vidyācaraṇasampanno sugato utpadye //
analyzed: aho punar aha bhaveya anāgatam adhvāna tathāgataḥ rha samyaksabuddhaḥ vidyā caraṇa sampannaḥ sugataḥ  /
translated: ‘Oh, that I might become in some future time a Tathāgata, an Arhan, a perfect Buddha, endowed with knowledge and virtue, a Sugata, a knower of the world, a driver of tameable men, a teacher of gods and men,🔽as this exalted Sarvābhibhū now is.’🔽‘Oh, that I might become in some future time a Tathāgata, an Arhan, a perfect Buddha, endowed with knowledge and virtue, a Sugata, a knower of the world, a driver of tameable men, a teacher of gods and men,

original: aho punaraha bhaveyamanāgatamadhvāna tathāgato arha samyaksabuddho vidyācaraṇasapannaḥ sugato lokavidanuttaraḥ puruṣadamyasārathiḥ śāstā 🔽devānā ca manuṣyāṇā ca //🔽so ima ca lokamabhijñāya sadevaka loka samāraka sabrahmaka saśramaṇa prajā sadevamanuṣyā ihaiva vārāṇasyā ṛṣivadane mṛgadāve dharmacakra
analyzed: aho punar aha bhaveyam anāgatam adhvāna tathāgataḥ arha samyaksabuddhaḥ vidyā caraṇa sapannaḥ sugataḥ loka vid anuttaraḥ puruṣa damya sārathiḥ śāstā  / devānā ca manuṣyāṇā ca  sā u ima ca lokam abhijñāya sa devaka loka sa māraka sa brahmaka sa śramaṇa prajā sa deva manuṣyā iha eva vārāṇasyāḥ ṛṣivadane mṛgadāve dharmacakra
translated: a Buddha, a Lord, as this exalted Sarvābhibhū now is.’🔽‘And that I might become in the world, here in the Deer Park at Ṛṣivadana, near Benares,🔽to set rolling the wheel of dharma that may not be rolled back, as the exalted Sarvābhibhū now does,

original: pravarteya dvādaśākāra apravartiya śramaṇena vā brāhmaṇena vā devena vā māreṇa vā kenacidvā punarloke saha dharmeṇa //
analyzed: śramaṇena vā brāhmaṇena vā devena vā māreṇa vā kenacid vā punar loke saha dharmeṇa
translated: and that I might, here in this world with its devas, Māra, and Brahmā, in this generation with its ascetics and brahmans, with its devas and men, make known, having realised by my own insight, this dharma that is lovely in its beginning, lovely in its middle, and lovely in its ending,🔽both in the spirit and in the letter, and make it known in all its fullness and purity, as the exalted Sarvābhibhū now does.’

original: eva sarvākārasapanna sarvākāraparipūrṇa ca dharma deśayeya yathāpi bhagavā kāśyapo etarahi //
analyzed: eva sarva ākāra sapanna sarva ākāra paripūrṇa ca dharma deśayeya yathā api bhagavā kāśyapaḥ etarahi
translated: I would teach the Dharma in all its aspects, in all its details, just as the Blessed One Kāśyapa does now.

original: eva ca devamanuṣyā śrotavya śraddhātavya manyensu yathā bhagavato kāśyapasya etarahi //
analyzed: eva ca deva manuṣyā śrotavya śraddhātavya manyensu yathā bhagavataḥ kāśyapasya etarahi
translated: And devas and humans would think of me as one to be heeded and believed in, just as they do the Blessed One Kāśyapa now.

original: ta bhaveya bahujanahitāya bahujanasukhāya lokānukampāya mahato janakāyasyārthāya hitāya sukhāya devānā ca manuṣyāṇā ca //
analyzed: ta bhaveya bahu jana hitāya bahu jana sukhāya loka anukampāya mahataḥ jana kāyasya arthāya hitāya sukhāya devānā ca manuṣyāṇā ca
translated: That would be for the benefit and welfare of the multitude, out of compassion for the world, for the sake of the great multitude, for the benefit and welfare of devas and men.

original: hāyensu āsurā kāyā divyā kāyā abhivardhensu /
analyzed: āsurā kāyā divyā kāyā abhivardhensu
translated: The hosts of the Asuras would wane; the hosts of the devas would wax.

original: atha khalvānanda bhagavā kāśyapo jyotipālasya bhikṣusya idamevarūpa cetasā eva cetoparivitarkamājñāya anyatara bhikṣumāmantrayasi //
analyzed: atha khalu ānanda bhagavā kāśyapaḥ jyotipālasya bhikṣusya cetasā eva cetaḥ upari vitarkam ājñāya anyatara bhikṣum āmantrayasi
translated: Then, Ānanda, the Blessed One Kāśyapa, knowing with his mind the thoughts in the mind of the monk Jyotipāla, addressed a certain monk, saying:🔽Come hither, monk. Go to the monk Jyotipāla and say to him:

original: ehi tva bhikṣu yena jyotipālo bhikṣustenopasakramitvā jyotipāla bhikṣumeva vadehi //🔽śāstā te āyuṣmā āmantreti /
analyzed: ehi tva bhikṣu yena jyotipālaḥ bhikṣuḥ tena upasakramitvā jyotipāla bhikṣum eva vadehi  śāstā te āyuṣmān āmantra iti
translated: 'The Master calls you, venerable Jyotipāla.'

original: upasakrame yena tathāgato //
analyzed: upasakrame yena tathāgataḥ
translated: Go to the Tathāgata.

original: bhagavato kāśyapasya pratiśrutvā yena jyotipālo bhikṣustenopasakramitvā jyotipāla bhikṣumetadavocat /
analyzed: bhagavataḥ kāśyapasya pratiśrutvā yena jyotipālaḥ bhikṣuḥ tena upasakramitvā jyotipāla bhikṣum etat avocat
translated: Having heard the Blessed One Kāśyapa, he approached the monk Jyotiṣpāla and said this to the monk Jyotiṣpāla:

analyzed: śāstā āyuṣma jyotipālaḥ āmantrayati upasakrame yena bhagavā
translated: Venerable Jyotiṣpāla, the Teacher calls you. Come to the Blessed One.

original: sādhvāyuṣmanniti āyuṣmā jyotipālastasya bhikṣusya pratiśrutvā yana bhagavānkāśyapastenopasakramitvā bhagavataḥ kāśyapasya pādau śirasā vanditvā
analyzed: sādhu āyuṣman iti āyuṣmā jyotipālaḥ tasya bhikṣusya pratiśrutvā bhagavān kāśyapaḥ tena upasakramitvā bhagavataḥ kāśyapasya pādau śirasā vanditvā
translated: Very well, venerable one, the venerable Jyotiṣpāla replied to that monk. He approached the Blessed One Kāśyapa, bowed his head at the feet of the Blessed One Kāśyapa,

original: ekānte niṣīdi //
analyzed: ekānte
translated: and sat to one side.

original: ekānte niṣaṇa āyuṣmanta jyotipāla bhikṣu bhagavā kāśyapa etadavocat //
analyzed: ekānte niṣaṇe āyuṣmanta jyotipāla bhikṣu bhagavā kāśyapaḥ etat avocat
translated: While sitting to one side, the venerable monk Jyotiṣpāla said this to the Blessed One Kāśyapa:

original: nanu jyotipāla ekasya jyotipālasya rahogatasya pratisalīnasya ayamevarūpaścetaso parivitarka utpadye //
analyzed: nanu jyotipālaḥ ekasya jyotipālasya rahaḥ gatasya pratisalīnasya ayam evarūpaḥ cetasaḥ parivitarkaḥ utpadye
translated: Was it not, Jyotiṣpāla, that when you were alone in seclusion, this kind of reflection arose in your mind:

original: aho punaraha bhaveya anāgatamadhvāna tathāgato rha samyaksabuddho vidyācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidanuttaraḥ puruṣadamyasārathiḥ
analyzed: aho punar aha bhaveya anāgatam adhvāna tathāgataḥ rha samyaksabuddhaḥ vidyā caraṇa sampannaḥ sugataḥ loka vid anuttaraḥ puruṣa damya sārathiḥ  /
translated: 'Oh, may I become in the future a Tathāgata, an Arhat, a Perfectly Enlightened One, endowed with knowledge and conduct, a Sugata, a knower of the world, an unsurpassed trainer of those who can be trained, a teacher of gods and humans, a Buddha, a Blessed One.

original: śāstā devānā ca manuṣyāṇā ca /
analyzed: śāstā devānā ca manuṣyāṇā ca
translated: A teacher of gods and humans.'

original: so ima ca lokamabhijñāya para ca lokamabhijñā sadevaka ca loka samāraka saśramaṇabrāhmaṇa prajā sadevamanuṣyā ihaiva vārāṇasīye ṛṣivadane
analyzed: sā u ima ca lokam abhijñāya para ca lokam abhijñā sa devaka ca loka sa māraka sa śramaṇa brāhmaṇa prajā sa deva manuṣyā iha eva vārāṇasīye ṛṣivadane
translated: He, having understood this world and the other world, and the world of gods, Māra, Brahmā, renunciants, and brahmins, with its gods, Māras, Brahmās, and the people therein, right here in the Deer Park in Vārāṇasī,

original: mṛgadāve dharmacakra pravarteya triparivarta dvādaśākāra apravartiya śramaṇena vā brāhmaṇena vā māreṇa vā brahmaṇā vā kenacidvā punarloke 🔽saha dharmeṇa //
analyzed: mṛgadāve dharmacakra śramaṇena vā brāhmaṇena vā māreṇa vā brahmaṇā vā kenacid vā punar loke  saha dharmeṇa
translated: would set rolling the wheel of Dharma that is thrice-revolved and twelve-fold, which has not been set rolling by any recluse or brahmin or god or Māra or Brahmā or by anyone else in the world.🔽And that would be for the benefit and welfare of a multitude, out of compassion for the world, for the good of a multitude, for the welfare and benefit of gods and humans.”

original: eva ca sarvākārasapanna sarvākāraparipūrṇa dharma deśayeya yathāpi bhagavā kāśyapo etarahi //
analyzed: eva ca sarva ākāra sapanna sarva ākāra paripūrṇa dharma deśayeya yathā api bhagavā kāśyapaḥ etarahi
translated: And he would teach the Dharma that is good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, with its own meaning, with its own phrasing, and reveal the fully perfected and purified holy life. Just as the Blessed One Kāśyapa does now.

original: eva ca samagra bhikṣusagha parihareya yathā bhagavā kāśyapo etarhi //
analyzed: eva ca samagra bhikṣu sagha parihareya yathā bhagavā kāśyapaḥ etarhi
translated: And he would lead a community of monks, a community of monastics, a community of noble ones, a community of wholesouled ones, a community of those who have attained peace, a community of those who have attained the very limit of the wholesome, a community that is upright, a community that is a field of merit, a community that is worthy of offerings, a community that is worthy of hospitality, a community that is worthy of gifts, a community that is worthy of reverential salutations, an unsurpassed field of merit in the world. Just as the Blessed One Kāśyapa does now.

original: eva ca me devā ca manuṣyā ca śrotavya śraddhātavya mansensu yathāpi bhagavato kāśyapasya etarahi //
analyzed: eva ca me devā ca manuṣyā ca śrotavya śraddhātavya yathā api bhagavataḥ kāśyapasya etarahi
translated: And he would be one who is listened to and believed in by gods and humans. Just as the Blessed One Kāśyapa is now.

original: ta bhaveyyā bahujanahitāya bahujanasukhāya lokānukapāyai mahato janakāyasyārthāya hitāya sukhāya devānā ca manuṣyāṇā ca //
analyzed: ta bhaveyyāḥ bahu jana hitāya bahu jana sukhāya loka anukapāyai mahataḥ jana kāyasya arthāya hitāya sukhāya devānā ca manuṣyāṇā ca
translated: And he would be for the benefit and welfare of a multitude, out of compassion for the world, for the good of a multitude, for the welfare and benefit of gods and humans.”

original: hāyensu āsurā kāyā divyā kāyā abhivarddhansu //
analyzed: āsurā kāyā divyā kāyā abhivarddhansu
translated: the hosts of the Asuras will wane, the hosts of the devas will wax great.”

analyzed: evam uktaḥ ānanda jyotipāla bhikṣuḥ bhagavanta kāśyapam etat avocat
translated: Thus addressed, Ānanda, the monk Jyotipāla replied to the exalted Kāśyapa,

original: evameta bhagavan //
analyzed: evam eta bhagavan

analyzed: evam ukte ānanda bhagavā jyotipāla bhikṣum etat avocat
translated: When this had been said, Ānanda, the exalted Kāśyapa replied to the monk Jyotipāla,

original: tasmāddhi jyotipāla ida suvarṇapīṭhaka duṣyayuga buddhapramukhe bhikṣusaghe dehi kṛtapuṇyāste devā ca manuṣyāśca śrotavya śraddhātavya 🔽maniṣyati //
analyzed: tasmāt hi jyotipāla idam suvarṇa pīṭhaka buddha pramukhe bhikṣu saghe dehi kṛta puṇyāḥ te devā ca manuṣyāḥ ca śrotavya śraddhātavya  maniṣyati
translated: “Therefore, Jyotipāla, give this golden seat and the suit of garments to the community of monks with the Buddha at their head. Those who have made merit, whether devas or men, will desire to see them.”

original: adāsi khalvānanda jyotipālo bhikṣuḥ suvarṇapīṭhaka duṣyayuga buddhapramukhe bhikṣusaghe //
analyzed: adāsi khalu ānanda jyotipālaḥ bhikṣuḥ suvarṇapīṭhaka buddha pramukhe bhikṣu saghe
translated: “So be it, Lord,” said the monk Jyotipāla, and he gave the golden seat and the suit of garments to the community of monks with the Buddha at their head.

original: atha khalvānanda bhagavā kāśyapo smita prāduṣkaritvā jyotipāla bhikṣu vyākārṣīt //🔽bhaviṣyasi tva jyotipāla anāgatamadhvānantathāgato ' rhansamyaksabuddho vidyācaraṇasampannaḥ sugato lokavidanuttaraḥ puruṣadamyasārathiḥ
analyzed: atha khalu ānanda bhagavā kāśyapaḥ smita prāduṣkaritvā jyotipāla bhikṣu vyākārṣīt  bhaviṣyasi tva jyotipāla anāgatam adhvānam tathāgataḥ  rhan samyaksabuddhaḥ vidyā caraṇa sampannaḥ sugataḥ loka vid anuttaraḥ puruṣa damya sārathiḥ  /
translated: Then, Ānanda, the exalted Kāśyapa, after smiling, proclaimed of the monk Jyotipāla,🔽“Jyotipāla, in a future period you will become a Tathāgata, an Arhan, a perfect Buddha, proficient in knowledge and conduct, a Sugata, an unsurpassed knower of the world, a driver of tameable men, a teacher of devas and men,

original: śāstā devānā ca manuṣyāṇā ca //
analyzed: śāstā devānā ca manuṣyāṇā ca
translated: a Buddha, a lord.”

original: so ima ca loka abhijñāya para ca lokamabhijñāya sadevaka ca loka samāraka sabrahmaka saśramaṇabrāhmaṇī prajā sadevamanuṣyā ihaiva 🔽vārāṇasīye ṛṣivadane mṛgadāve dharmacakra pravartayiṣyasi triparivarta dvādaśākāra apravartita kenacicchramaṇena vā brāhmaṇena vā devena
analyzed: saḥ ima ca loka abhijñāya para ca lokam abhijñāya sa devaka ca loka sa māraka sa brahmaka sa śramaṇa brāhmaṇī prajā sa deva manuṣyā iha eva  vārāṇasīye ṛṣivadane mṛgadāve dharmacakra pravartayiṣyasi tri parivarta dvādaśa ākāra a pravartita kenacid śramaṇena vā brāhmaṇena vā devena
translated: He will understand this world and the next world, the world of gods, Māra, and Brahmā, of ascetics and brahmins, of gods and humans. Right here

original: vā māreṇa vā kenacidvā punarloke saha dharmeṇa //🔽eva ca sarvākārasampanna sarvākāraparipūrṇa dharma deśayiṣyasi yathāpi bhagavā kāśyapo etarahi //
analyzed: vā māreṇa vā kenacid vā punar loke saha dharmeṇa  eva ca sarva ākāra sampanna sarva ākāra paripūrṇa dharma deśayiṣyasi yathā api bhagavā kāśyapaḥ etarahi
translated: in the Deer Park at Ṛṣivadana near Vārāṇasī, he will set rolling the wheel of the Dharma that is thrice-revolved and twelve-fold, and has not been set rolling by any recluse or brahmin or god or Māra or Brahmā or by anyone in the world.🔽And he will do so in accordance with the Dharma.”

original: eva ca samagra śrāvakasagha parihariṣyasi yathāpi bhagavā kāśyapo etarahi //
analyzed: eva ca samagra śrāvaka sagha parihariṣyasi yathā api bhagavā kāśyapaḥ etarahi
translated: And he will teach the Dharma that is good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, with its own meaning, with its own phrasing, and with its own formulation.

original: eva samagra śrāvakasagha parihariṣyasi yathāpi bhagavā kāśyapo etarahi //
analyzed: eva samagra śrāvaka sagha parihariṣyasi yathā api bhagavā kāśyapaḥ etarahi
translated: And he will be attended by a community of many thousands of monks.

original: eva ca te devā ca manuṣyā ca śrotavya śraddhatavya manyensu yathāpi bhagavato kāśyapasya va etarahi //
analyzed: eva ca te devā ca manuṣyā ca śrotavya śraddhatavya manyensu yathā api bhagavataḥ kāśyapasya vaḥ etarahi
translated: And gods and humans will think that he is to be heeded and trusted, just as they do now with the Blessed One Kāśyapa.

original: ta bhaviṣyasi bahujanahitāya bahujanasukhāya lokānukampāyai mahato janakāyasyārthāya hitāya sukhāya devānā ca manuṣyāṇā ca //
analyzed: ta bhaviṣyasi bahu jana hitāya bahu jana sukhāya loka anukampāyai mahataḥ jana kāyasya arthāya hitāya sukhāya devānā ca manuṣyāṇā ca
translated: You will become one who acts for the benefit of many people, for the happiness of many people, out of compassion for the world, for the welfare, benefit, and happiness of a great multitude of gods and humans.”

original: hāyiṣyanti āsurā kāyā abhivardhiṣyati //
analyzed: hāyiṣyanti āsurā kāyā abhivardhiṣyati
translated: The hosts of the asuras will wane, the hosts of the gods will wax strong.”

original: atha khalvānanda bhagavatā kāśyapena jyotipālasmi vyākṛte bhūmyā devā ghoṣamudīrayensu //🔽eso māriṣā bhagavatā kāśyapena jyotipālo nāma bhikṣurvyākṛto so bhaviṣyati anāgatamadhvāna tathāgato rha samyaksabuddho vidyācaraṇasampannaḥ
analyzed: atha khalu ānanda bhagavatā kāśyapena vyākṛte bhūmyāḥ devāḥ ghoṣam udīrayen  māriṣāḥ bhagavatā kāśyapena jyotipālaḥ nāma bhikṣuḥ vyākṛtaḥ saḥ bhaviṣyati anāgatam adhvāna tathāgataḥ rha samyaksabuddhaḥ vidyā caraṇa sampannaḥ  /
translated: Then, Ānanda, when the Blessed One Kāśyapa had prophesied about Jyotipāla, the gods of the earth cried out:

original: sugato lokavidanuttaraḥ puruṣadamyasārathiḥ śāstā devānā ca manuṣyāṇā ca //
analyzed: sugataḥ loka vid anuttaraḥ puruṣa damya sārathiḥ śāstā devānā ca manuṣyāṇā ca
translated: “Friends, this monk named Jyotipāla has been prophesied by the Blessed One Kāśyapa. He will become in the future a Tathāgata, an Arhat, a Perfectly Enlightened One, endowed with knowledge and virtue, a Sugata, a knower of the world, an unsurpassed trainer of those who can be trained, a teacher of gods and humans, a Buddha, a Blessed Lord.🔽He will be a teacher of this world with its gods, Māra, and Brahmā, of this generation with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans, a buddha, a blessed lord.

original: so ima lokamabhijñāya para ca lokamabhijñāya sadevaka ca loka samāraka sabrahmaka saśramaṇabrāhmaṇī prajā sadevamanuṣyā abhijñāya
analyzed: saḥ ima lokam abhijñāya para ca lokam abhijñāya sa devaka ca loka sa māraka sa brahmaka sa śramaṇa brāhmaṇī prajā sa deva manuṣyā abhijñāya
translated: Having directly known this world—with its gods, Māra, and Brahmā, this generation with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans—and having directly known it,

original: iha eva vārāṇasīye ṛṣivadane mṛgadāve dharmacakra pravartayiṣyati triparivarta dvādaśākāra aparivartita śramaṇena brāhmaṇena vā devena vā
analyzed: iha eva vārāṇasīye ṛṣivadane mṛgadāve dharmacakra pravartayiṣyati triparivarta dvādaśākāra aparivartita śramaṇena brāhmaṇena vā devena vā
translated: Here itself, in the Deer Park at Ṛṣivadana near Vārāṇasī, he will turn the wheel of Dharma, with its three revolutions and twelve aspects, which has never been turned by any ascetic, brāhmaṇa, god, Māra, Brahmā, or anyone else.🔽🔽

original: māreṇa vā brahmaṇā vā kenacidvā punarloke saha dharmeṇa //
analyzed: māreṇa vā brahmaṇā vā kenacid vā punar loke saha dharmeṇa
translated: Right here, in the Deer Park at Ṛṣivadana near Vārāṇasī, he will set rolling the wheel of the dharma that is thrice-revolved and twelve-fold and has not been set rolling by any recluse or brahmin or god or Māra or Brahmā or by anyone else in the world.🔽He will set rolling the wheel that is in accord with the dharma.

original: eva sarvākārasampanna sarvākāraparipūrṇa dharma deśayiṣyati yathāpi bhagavā kāśyapo etarahi //
analyzed: eva sarva ākāra sampanna sarva ākāra paripūrṇa dharma deśayiṣyati yathā api bhagavā kāśyapaḥ etarahi
translated: He will teach the dharma that is good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, that has a good meaning, that has the good words, and that is a revelation of the fully accomplished and perfect Brahma.

original: tadbhaviṣyati bahujanahitāya bahujanasukhāya lokānupāye mahato janakāyasyārthāya hitāya sukhāya devānā ca manuṣyāṇā ca //
analyzed: tat bhaviṣyati bahu jana hitāya bahu jana sukhāya loka anupāye mahataḥ jana kāyasya arthāya hitāya sukhāya devānā ca manuṣyāṇā ca
translated: This will be for the benefit and welfare of mankind, out of compassion for the world, for the sake of the great multitude, for the benefit and welfare of devas and men.

original: hayiṣyanti āsurā kāyā divyā kāyā abhivarddhiṣyanti //
analyzed: hayiṣyanti āsurā kāyā divyā kāyā abhivarddhiṣyanti
translated: The hosts of the Asuras will wane; the hosts of the devas will wax.

original: bhūmyānā devānā ghoṣa śrutvā cāturmahārājakāyikā devāḥ trāyastriśā yāmāḥ tuṣitā nirmāṇaratayaḥ paranirmitavaśavartina iti //
analyzed: cāturmahārājakāyikāḥ devāḥ trāyastriśāḥ yāmāḥ tuṣitāḥ nirmāṇaratayaḥ paranirmitavaśavartinaḥ iti
translated: And when the devas of earth have heard the shout, the Caturmahārājika devas, the Trāyastriṃśa devas, the Yāma devas, the Tuṣita devas, the Nirmāṇarati devas, and the Paranirmitavaśavartin devas will take up the shout.

original: tutmuhūrta yāvadbrahmakāyikā devanikāyā ghoṣamamyudgacchet //
analyzed: yāvat brahmakāyikāḥ devanikāyāḥ ghoṣam amyudgacchet
translated: And so on up to the devas of the highest heaven.

original: eṣo māriṣa bhagavatā kāśyapena jyotipālo nāma bhikṣu vyākṛto so bhaviṣyati anāgatamadhvāna tathāgato'rhi samyakasabuddho vidyācaraṇasapanno 🔽sugato lokavidanuttaraḥ puruṣadamyasārathiḥ śāstā devānā ca manuṣyāṇā ca /
analyzed: eṣaḥ māriṣa bhagavatā kāśyapena jyotipālaḥ nāma bhikṣu saḥ bhaviṣyati anāgata madhvāna tathāgataḥ hi samyakasabuddhaḥ vidyā caraṇa sapannaḥ  sugataḥ loka vid anuttaraḥ puruṣa damya sārathiḥ śāstā devānā ca manuṣyāṇā ca
translated: “Friends, the Fortunate One Kāśyapa has prophesied about a monk named Jyotipāla, saying: ‘He will become a Tathāgata, an Arhat, a Perfectly Enlightened One, endowed with knowledge and conduct, a Sugata, a knower of the world, an unsurpassed trainer of those who can be trained, a teacher of gods and humans, a Buddha, a Fortunate One.’🔽He will know this world, with its gods, Māras, Brahmās, renunciants, and brahmins, having directly experienced it with his own direct knowledge.

original: so ima ca lokamabhijñāya para ca loka abhijñāya sadevaka ca loka ca sabrahmaka saśramaṇabrāhmaṇī prajā sadevamanuṣyāmabhijñāya iha
analyzed: saḥ ima ca lokam abhijñāya para ca loka abhijñāya sa devaka ca loka ca sa brahmaka sa śramaṇa brāhmaṇī prajā sa deva manuṣyām abhijñāya iha
translated: Having directly known this world, with its gods, Māras, Brahmās, renunciants, and brahmins, he will teach it, having directly experienced it with his own direct knowledge.

original: eva vārāṇasīya ṛṣivadane mṛgadāve dharmacakra pravartayiṣyati triparivarta dvādaśākāra apravartiya śramaṇena vā brāhmaṇena vā devena vā
analyzed: eva vārāṇasīya ṛṣivadane mṛgadāve dharmacakra pravartayiṣyati tri parivarta dvādaśa ākāra śramaṇena vā brāhmaṇena vā devena vā
translated: Here in Vārāṇasī, in the Deer Park at Ṛṣivadana, he will set rolling the wheel of the Dhamma, which is thrice-revolved and twelve-fold, and which has not been set rolling by any recluse or brahmin or god or Māra or Brahmā or by anyone else in the world.

original: māreṇa vā brahmaṇā vā kenacidvā punarloke saha dharmeṇa //
analyzed: māreṇa vā brahmaṇā vā kenacid vā punar loke saha dharmeṇa
translated: And that wheel of the Dhamma cannot be rolled back by any recluse or brahmin or god or Māra or Brahmā or by anyone else in the world.”

original: eva ca sarvākārasampanna ca sarvākāraparipūrṇa dharma deśayiṣyati yathāpi bhagavā kāśyapo etarahi //
analyzed: eva ca sarva ākāra sampanna ca sarva ākāra paripūrṇa dharma deśayiṣyati yathā api bhagavā kāśyapaḥ etarahi
translated: “And he will teach the Dhamma that is good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, with its own meaning, with its own phrasing, and will reveal the perfectly complete and pure spiritual life. Just as now the Fortunate One Kāśyapa teaches the Dhamma that is good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, with its own meaning, with its own phrasing, and reveals the perfectly complete and pure spiritual life.”

original: eva ca devā ca manuṣyā ca śrotavya śraddhātavya maniṣyanti yathāpi bhagavato kāśyapasya etarahi //
analyzed: eva ca devā ca manuṣyā ca śrotavya śraddhātavya maniṣyanti yathā api bhagavataḥ kāśyapasya etarahi
translated: And the gods and men will listen to and believe in him, just as they do now in the Blessed One Kāśyapa.

original: tadbhaviṣyati bahujanahitāya bahujanasukhāya lokānukapāyai mahato janakāyasyārthāya hitāya sukhāya devānā ca manuṣyāṇā ca //
analyzed: tat bhaviṣyati bahu jana hitāya bahu jana sukhāya loka anukapāyai mahataḥ jana kāyasya arthāya hitāya sukhāya devānā ca manuṣyāṇā ca
translated: This will be for the benefit and happiness of many people, for the sake of gods and men.

original: hāyiṣyanti āsurā kāyā divyā kāyā abhivarddhaṣyanti //
analyzed: hāyiṣyanti āsurā kāyā divyā kāyā abhivarddhaṣyanti
translated: The hosts of asuras will diminish, the hosts of the gods will increase.

original: athānanda bhagavā kāśyapastismi ghoṣe ntarhite tā bhikṣūndharmayā kathayā sadarśay samādāpaye samuttejaye sapraharṣaye //
analyzed: atha ānanda bhagavā kāśyapaḥ tismin ghoṣe ntarhite tāḥ bhikṣūn dharmayā kathayā sa darśay samādāpaye samuttejaye sa praharṣaye
translated: Then, Ānanda, when the Blessed One Kāśyapa had disappeared, he instructed those monks with a discourse on Dharma, exhorting, encouraging, and delighting them.

original: eva bhikṣavo vitarketha eva mā vitarketha eva manasikarītha eva mā manasikarītha //
analyzed: eva bhikṣavaḥ vitarketha eva mā vitarketha eva manasikarītha eva mā manasikarītha
translated: Monks, think like this, not like that. Attend to this, not to that.

original: ātmadvīpā bhikṣavo viharatha ananyadvīpāḥ ātmaśaraṇāḥ ananyaśaraṇāḥ dharmadvīpā ananyadvīpāḥ dharmaśaraṇā ananyaśaraṇāḥ //
analyzed: ātma dvīpāḥ bhikṣavaḥ viharatha ananya dvīpāḥ ātma śaraṇāḥ ananya śaraṇāḥ dharma dvīpāḥ ananya dvīpāḥ dharma śaraṇāḥ ananya śaraṇāḥ
translated: Monks, dwell with an island for yourselves, not with an island for others. Dwell with yourselves as your island, not with others as your island. Dwell with Dharma as your island, not with anything else as your island. Dwell with Dharma as your refuge, not with anything else as your refuge.

original: atha khalu bhagavā ādīptena kāyena saprajvalitena sajyotibhūtena eka tāla vaihāyasamabhyudgato bhikṣū dharmayā kathayā sadarśayetsamādāpayetsamuttejayetsapraharṣayet🔽eva bho bhikṣavo vitarketha eva mā vitarketha eva manasikarotha eva mā manasikarotha ātmadvīpā ātmaśaraṇāḥ ananyaśaraṇāḥ dharmadvīpā ananyadvīpāḥ
analyzed: atha khalu bhagavā ādīptena kāyena sa prajvalitena sa jyotibhūtena eka tāla vaihāyasam abhyudgataḥ bhikṣū dharmayā kathayā sa darśayet samādāpayet samuttejayet sa praharṣayet  eva bho bhikṣavaḥ vitarketha eva mā vitarketha eva manasikarotha eva mā manasikarotha ātma dvīpāḥ ātma śaraṇāḥ ananya śaraṇāḥ dharma dvīpāḥ ananya dvīpāḥ
translated: Then the Blessed One, with his body ablaze, burning and glowing, rose up into the air to the height of one palm tree, and with a Dharma discourse he instructed, inspired, fired and delighted the monks.

original: dharmaśaraṇā ananyaśaraṇāḥ //
analyzed: dharma śaraṇāḥ ananya śaraṇāḥ
translated: Thus, monks, you should think thus, not otherwise. You should direct your thoughts thus, not otherwise. You are your own island, your own refuge, with no other refuge. Hold to the Dharma as an island, hold to the Dharma as a refuge, with no other refuge.

original: atha khalu bhagavā ādīptena kāyena saprajvalitena sajyotibhūtena eka tāla vaihāyasamabhyudgato bhikṣū dharmayā kathayā sadarśayetsamādāpayetsamuttejayetsapraharṣayet
analyzed: atha khalu bhagavā ādīptena kāyena sa prajvalitena sa jyotibhūtena eka tāla vaihāyasam abhyudgataḥ bhikṣū dharmayā kathayā sa darśayet samādāpayet samuttejayet sa praharṣayet
translated: Then the Blessed One, with his body ablaze, burning and glowing, rose up into the air to the height of one palm tree, and with a Dharma discourse he instructed, inspired, fired and delighted the monks.

original: eva bho bhikṣavo vitarketha eva mā vitarketha eva manasikarotha eva mā manasikarotha ātmadvīpā bhikṣavo viharatha ananyadvīpā ātmaśaraṇā
analyzed: eva bho bhikṣavaḥ vitarketha eva mā vitarketha eva manasikarotha eva mā manasikarotha ātma dvīpāḥ bhikṣavaḥ viharatha ananya dvīpāḥ ātma śaraṇāḥ
translated: Thus, monks, you should think thus, not otherwise. You should direct your thoughts thus, not otherwise. Monks, you should dwell as your own island, with no other island. As your own refuge, with no other refuge. As your own resort, with no other resort. Taking the Dharma as an island, taking the Dharma as a refuge, with no other refuge.

original: ananyaśaraṇāḥ dharmadvīpā ananyadvīpā dharmaśaraṇā ananyaśaraṇāḥ //
analyzed: ananya śaraṇāḥ dharma dvīpāḥ ananya dvīpāḥ dharma śaraṇāḥ ananya śaraṇāḥ
translated: They are islands unto themselves, with no other island; they have the Dharma as their island, with no other island; they have the Dharma as their refuge, with no other refuge.”

original: atha khalvānanda bhagavā kāśyapo ekatālāddūtāta vaihāyasamabhyudgamya dvitālāttritāla tritālāto catutālato pacatāla pacatālāto ṣaṭtāla
analyzed: atha khalu ānanda bhagavā kāśyapaḥ ekatālāt dūtāta vaihāyasam abhyudgamya dvitālāt tritāla tritālātaḥ catutālataḥ pacatāla pacatālātaḥ ṣaṭtāla
translated: Then, Ānanda, the Blessed One Kāśyapa rose up into the air from the height of one palm tree to the height of two palm trees, from the height of two palm trees to the height of three palm trees, from the height of three palm trees to the height of four palm trees, from the height of four palm trees to the height of five palm trees, from the height of five palm trees to the height of six palm trees,

original: ṣaṭtālāto saptatāla saptatālasasthito tā bhikṣū dharmayā kathayā sadarśayati samādāpayati samuttejayati sapraharṣayati //
analyzed: tā bhikṣū dharmayā kathayā sa darśayati samādāpayati samuttejayati sa praharṣayati
translated: from the height of six palm trees to the height of seven palm trees. Standing at the height of seven palm trees, he instructed, inspired, fired and delighted those monks with a discourse on Dharma.

original: eva bhikṣavaḥ vitarketha eva mā vitarketha eva manasikarotha eva mā manasikarotha /
analyzed: eva bhikṣavaḥ vitarketha eva mā vitarketha eva manasikarotha eva mā manasikarotha
translated: “Monks, think like this, not like that; direct your minds thus, not thus.

original: ātmadvīpā bhikṣavo viharatha ananyadvīpā ātmaśaraṇā ananyaśaraṇā dharmaśaraṇā ananyaśaraṇāḥ //
analyzed: ātma dvīpāḥ bhikṣavaḥ viharatha ananya dvīpāḥ ātma śaraṇāḥ ananya śaraṇāḥ dharma śaraṇāḥ ananya śaraṇāḥ
translated: Monks, dwell as islands unto yourselves, being your own refuge, with no other refuge, with the Dharma as your island, with the Dharma as your refuge, with no other refuge.”

original: atha khalvānanda bhagavā kāśyapo saptatālāto ṣaṭtāasasthito ṣaṭtālātpacatāla pacatālāto catutāla catutālāto tritāla tritālāto dvitāla
analyzed: atha khalu ānanda bhagavā kāśyapaḥ ṣaṣ tālāt pacatāla pacatālātaḥ catutāla catutālātaḥ tritāla tritālātaḥ dvitāla
translated: Then, Ānanda, the Blessed One Kāśyapa, from the height of seven palm trees, descended to the height of six palm trees, from the height of six palm trees to the height of five palm trees, from the height of five palm trees to the height of four palm trees, from the height of four palm trees to the height of three palm trees, from the height of three palm trees to the height of two palm trees,🔽from the height of two palm trees to the height of one palm tree.

original: dvitālāto ekatāla ekatālāto svake āsane niṣaṇo tā bhikṣū dharmayā kathayā sadarśayetsamādāpayetsamuttejayetsapraharṣayet //
analyzed: dvi tālātaḥ eka tālaḥ eka tālātaḥ svake āsane tā bhikṣū dharmayā kathayā sa darśayet samādāpayet samuttejayet sa praharṣayet
translated: from a height of two tālas he would descend to a height of one tāla, and from a height of one tāla he would descend to the ground. And he would instruct, urge, incite and gladden those monks with a talk about dharma as they sat on their seats.

original: eva bhikṣavo vitarketha eva mā vitarketha eva manasikarotha eva mā manasikarotha //
analyzed: eva bhikṣavaḥ vitarketha eva mā vitarketha eva manasikarotha eva mā manasikarotha
translated: “Think thus, monks, not otherwise; direct your minds thus, not otherwise.”

original: ātmadvīpā bhikṣavo viharatha ananyadvīpā ātmaśaraṇā ananyaśaraṇā dharmadvīpā ananyadvīpā dharmaśaraṇā ananyaśaraṇāḥ //
analyzed: ātma dvīpāḥ bhikṣavaḥ viharatha ananya dvīpāḥ ātma śaraṇāḥ ananya śaraṇāḥ dharma dvīpāḥ ananya dvīpāḥ dharma śaraṇāḥ ananya śaraṇāḥ
translated: “Monks, live with yourselves as your island, yourselves as your refuge, with no other as your refuge; with the dharma as your island, the dharma as your refuge, with no other as your refuge.”

original: atha khalvānanda bhagavā kāśyapaḥ paryaṅka bhindanto tā bhikṣū āmantrayasi //🔽aha bhikṣavo paryaṅka bhindāmi sarveṣamimeṣā saptānā bhikṣusahasrāṇā etehi eva āsanehi niṣasmānāmanupādāśravebhyaścittāni vimuktāni sthāpayitvā
analyzed: atha khalu ānanda bhagavā kāśyapaḥ paryaṅka tāḥ bhikṣū āmantrayasi  aha bhikṣavaḥ paryaṅka bhindāmi sarveṣam imeṣā saptānā bhikṣu sahasrāṇā etehi eva āsanehi niṣasmānām anu pāda āśravebhyaḥ cittāni vimuktāni sthāpayitvā
translated: Then, Ānanda, the exalted Kāśyapa, breaking his silence, addressed the monks, saying:

original: jyotipālasya bhikṣusya //
analyzed: jyotipālasya bhikṣusya
translated: “Monks, I break my silence. Of all these seven thousand monks, their minds have been liberated from the āśravas, except that of the monk Jyotipāla.

original: so pi mahya vyākṛto va anuttarāye samyaksabodhaye //
analyzed: saḥ pi vyākṛtaḥ vaḥ anuttarāye samyaksabodhaye
translated: He, too, has been proclaimed by me as destined to become a Tathāgata, an Arhan, a perfect Buddha.”

original: syātkhalu punarānanda evamasyāsyāt anyo so tena kālena tena samayena jyotipālo nāma bhikṣuḥ abhūṣi //
analyzed: syāt khalu punar ānanda evam asya asyāt syāt tat tena kālena tena samayena jyotipālaḥ nāma bhikṣuḥ
translated: It may be, Ānanda, that you will think that at that time and on that occasion the monk named Jyotipāla was somebody else.

original: naitadeva draṣṭavya //
analyzed: na etat eva draṣṭavya
translated: But you must not think so.

original: aha so tena kālena tena samayena jyotipālo nāma bhikṣu abhūṣi //
analyzed: aha saḥ tena kālena tena samayena jyotipālaḥ nāma bhikṣu
translated: I was at that time and on that occasion the monk named Jyotipāla.

original: idamavocadbhagavānāttamanā āyuṣmānando tāni sapta ca bhikṣusahasrāṇi bhagavato bhāṣitamabhinandensuḥ //
analyzed: idam avocat bhagavān ātta manāḥ āyuṣmā ānandaḥ tāni sapta ca bhikṣu sahasrāṇi bhagavataḥ bhāṣitam abhinandensuḥ
translated: Thus spoke the Exalted One, and the venerable Ānanda and the seven hundred monks were elated and rejoiced at what the Exalted One had said.

original: iti śrīmahāvastuavadāne jyotipālasūtra samāpta //
analyzed: iti śrī mahāvastu avadāne jyotipāla sūtra samāpta
translated: Here ends the Jyotipāla Sūtra in the Mahāvastu-Avadāna.

original: jyotipālen bhikṣuṇā bhagavato kāśyapasya saśrāvakasaghasya yvāgūpāna kṛtvā śatasahasreṇa keśara krīṇitvā bhagavanta kāśyapa saśrāvakasagha
analyzed: jyotipālen bhikṣuṇā bhagavataḥ kāśyapasya sa śrāvaka saghasya yvāgū pāna kṛtvā śata sahasreṇa keśara krīṇitvā bhagavanta kāśyapa sa śrāvaka sagha
translated: The monk Jyotipāla, having provided the exalted Kāśyapa and his community of disciples with food, with a hundred thousand pieces of gold bought a keśara tree, and gave it to the exalted Kāśyapa and his community of disciples.

original: abhyokiresi suvarṇapīṭhaka ca duṣyayoga bhagavato kāśyapasya adāsi //🔽eva ca anupraṇidhesi //
analyzed: suvarṇapīṭhaka ca duṣyayoga bhagavataḥ kāśyapasya 🔽eva ca anupraṇidhesi
translated: He presented to the exalted Kāśyapa a golden throne and a suit of garments of burnished gold, and made this vow:

original: yathāya bhagavā kāśyapo samyaksabuddho dvātriśatīhi mahāpuruṣalakṣaṇehi samanvāgato aśītihi anuvyajanehi upaśobhitaśarīro aṣṭadaśehi āveṇikehi 🔽buddhadharmehi samanvāgato daśahi tathāgatabalehi valavā caturhi vaiśāradyehi viśārado aho puna aha pi anāgatamadhvāna bhaveya tathāgato
analyzed: yathāya bhagavā kāśyapaḥ samyaksabuddhaḥ dvātriśatīhi mahāpuruṣa lakṣaṇehi samanvāgataḥ aśītihi anuvyajanehi upaśobhita śarīraḥ aṣṭadaśehi āveṇikehi  buddha dharmehi samanvāgataḥ daśahi tathāgata balehi valavā caturhi vaiśāradyehi viśāradaḥ aho puna aha pi anāgatam adhvāna bhaveya tathāgataḥ
translated: Just as the exalted Kāśyapa, the perfect Buddha, is endowed with the thirty-two marks of a Great Man, his body adorned with the eighty minor characteristics,

original: ' rha samyaksabuddho vidyācaraṇasapanno sugato lokavidanuttaraḥ puruṣadamyasārathiḥ śāstā devānā ca manuṣyāṇā ca yatāya bhagavā kāśyapo
analyzed: rha samyaksabuddhaḥ vidyā caraṇa sapannaḥ sugataḥ loka vid anuttaraḥ puruṣa damya sārathiḥ śāstā devānā ca manuṣyāṇā ca yatāya bhagavā kāśyapaḥ
translated: endowed with the eighteen special attributes of a Buddha, powerful with the ten powers of a Tathāgata, confident with the four grounds of self-confidence, so may  in some future time become a Tathāgata, an Arhan, a perfect Buddha, proficient in knowledge and conduct, a Sugata, an unsurpassed knower of the world, a driver of tameable men, a teacher of devas and men, as this exalted Kāśyapa now is.

original: etarahi //🔽eva ca triparivarta dvādaśākāra anuttara dharmacakra pravarteya yathāpi bhagavānkāśyapo etarahi //🔽eva ca śrāvakasagha parihareya yathāya bhagavā kāśyapo etarahi //
analyzed: etarahi  eva ca tri parivarta dvādaśa ākāra anuttara dharmacakra pravarteya yathā api bhagavān kāśyapaḥ etarahi  eva ca śrāvaka sagha parihareya bhagavā kāśyapaḥ etarahi
translated: Just as the exalted Kāśyapa now is.🔽Just as the exalted Kāśyapa now sets rolling the wheel of dharma which is thrice-revolved and twelve-fold and as such has not been set rolling by any recluse or brahman, so may  in some future time set rolling the wheel of dharma which is thrice-revolved and twelve-fold and as such has not been set rolling by any recluse, brahman, deva, Māra, Brahmā or any one else.🔽Just as the exalted Kāśyapa now has, may  in some future time have a community of thousands of disciples.

original: eva ca me te devā ca manuṣyā ca śrotavya śraddhātavya manyensuḥ yathāpi bhagavato kāśyapasya etarahi //
analyzed: eva ca me te devā ca manuṣyā ca śrotavya śraddhātavya manyensuḥ yathā api bhagavataḥ kāśyapasya etarahi
translated: Just as the exalted Kāśyapa now is honoured, revered, esteemed, worshipped, and respected by the community of his disciples, so may  in some future time be honoured, revered, esteemed, worshipped and respected by the community of my disciples.🔽Just as the exalted Kāśyapa now is honoured, revered, esteemed, worshipped and respected by devas and Nāgas, by kings of the Asuras, by Sramaṇas and by Brahmans, and is honoured, revered, esteemed, worshipped and respected by this great multitude which is thus a cream, a choice cream,

original: eva tīrṇo tārayeya mukto mocayeya āśvasto āśvāsayeya parinirvṛto parinirvāpayeya yathāya bhagavā kāśyapo etarahi //
analyzed: eva tīrṇaḥ tārayeya muktaḥ mocayeya āśvastaḥ āśvāsayeya parinirvṛtaḥ parinirvāpayeya bhagavā kāśyapaḥ etarahi
translated: I, when I have crossed, may lead others across; when I am released, may lead others to release; when I have attained perfect peace, may lead others to perfect peace, even as the exalted Kāśyapa now does.

original: ta bhaveya bahujanahitāya bahujanasukhāya lokānukapāya mahato janakāyasyārthāya hitāya sukhāya devānā ca manuṣyāṇā ca //
analyzed: te bhaveya bahu jana hitāya bahu jana sukhāya loka anukapāya mahataḥ jana kāyasya arthāya hitāya sukhāya devānā ca manuṣyāṇā ca
translated: May I become one who is for the welfare of the world, for the sake of the multitude, for the good of devas and men.

original: jyotipālaḥ kāśyapena anuttarāye samyaksabodhaye vyākṛto //🔽bhaviṣyasi tva jyotipāla anāgatamadhvāna tathāgato rha samyaksabuddho vidyācaraṇasapannaḥ sugato lokavidanuttaraḥ puruṣadamyasārathiḥ 🔽śāstā devānā ca manuṣyāṇā ca imasmi eva bhadrakalpe samanantara dvātriśatīhi mahāpuruṣalakṣaṇehi samanvāgato aśītihi anuvyajanehi upaśomitaśarīro
analyzed: jyotipālaḥ kāśyapena anuttarāye samyaksabodhaye vyākṛtaḥ  bhaviṣyasi tva jyotipāla anāgatam adhvāna tathāgataḥ rha samyaksabuddhaḥ vidyā caraṇa sapannaḥ sugataḥ loka vid anuttaraḥ puruṣa damya sārathiḥ  / śāstā devānā ca manuṣyāṇā ca imasmi eva bhadra kalpe samanantara dvātriśatīhi mahāpuruṣa lakṣaṇehi samanvāgataḥ aśītihi anuvyajanehi upaśomita śarīraḥ
translated: Jyotipāla was proclaimed by Kāśyapa to the supreme perfect enlightenment.

original: aṣṭādasehi āveṇikehi buddhadharmehi samanvāgato daśahi tathāgatabalehi balavā caturhi vaiśāradyehi viśārado //
analyzed: aṣṭādasehi āveṇikehi buddha dharmehi samanvāgataḥ daśahi tathāgata balehi balavā caturhi vaiśāradyehi viśāradaḥ
translated: Jyotipāla, you will become a Tathāgata, an Arhan, a perfect Buddha, proficient in knowledge and conduct, a Sugata, an unsurpassed knower of the world, a driver of tameable men, a teacher of devas and men, endowed with the thirty-two marks of a Great Man, with his body radiant, with the eighty minor characteristics, with his whole body well proportioned, powerful, with a halo extending an arm’s length, with a body that extends a fathom, with a complexion surpassing that of the deva-king Suyāma, with a head-ornament of the ūrṇā, with a fringe of eyelashes like a tortoise-shell, with skin the colour of gold, with seven rounded protuberances on his body, with a body that is straight, with a prominent nose, with a body that is well-proportioned like a nyagrodha tree, with a broad and level-set shoulder, with a body that is not over-tall, with a body that is well-proportioned in all ways, with a body that is not over-stooped, with a body that is not over-bent, with a body that is not over-lean, with a body that is not over-fat, with a body that is not over-dark, with a body that is not over-fair, with a body that is not over-long, with a body that is not over-short, with a body that is not over-stunted, with a body that is not over-bent, with a body that is not over-crooked, with a body that is not over-bent, with a body that is not over-bent, with a body that is not over-bent, with a body that is not over-bent, with a body that is not over-bent, with a body that is not over-bent, with a body that is not over-bent, with a body that is not over-bent,

original: eva tīrṇo tārayiṣyasi mukto mocayiṣyasi āśvasto āśvāsayiṣyasi parinirvṛto parinirvāpayiṣyasi yathāpi aha etarahi //
analyzed: eva tīrṇaḥ tārayiṣyasi muktaḥ mocayiṣyasi āśvastaḥ āśvāsayiṣyasi parinirvṛtaḥ parinirvāpayiṣyasi yathā api aha etarahi
translated: Thus, when you have crossed, you will lead others across; when you are freed, you will free others; when you have attained peace, you will bring peace to others, just as I do now.

original: ta bhaviṣyasi bahujanahitāya bahujanasukhāya mahato janakāyasyārthāya hitāya sukhāya lokānukapāyai devānā ca manuṣyāṇā ca //
analyzed: ta bhaviṣyasi bahu jana hitāya bahu jana sukhāya mahataḥ jana kāyasya arthāya hitāya sukhāya loka anukapāyai devānā ca manuṣyāṇā ca
translated: You will be for the benefit and welfare of the multitude, for the sake of a great many people, for the benefit and welfare of devas and men.

original: samanantaravyākṛto punarjyotipālo bhikṣurbhagavatā kāśyapena samyaksabuddhena iya mahāpṛthivī atīva ṣaḍikara kampe prakampe saprakampe
analyzed: punar jyotipālaḥ bhikṣuḥ bhagavatā kāśyapena samyaksabuddhena iya mahā pṛthivī atīva kampe prakampe sa prakampe
translated: And immediately after the monk Jyotipāla had been proclaimed by the exalted Kāśyapa, the perfect Buddha, this great earth shook, trembled, quaked, quivered, vibrated and trembled violently six times.

original: bhūmyā ca devā ghoṣamudīrayensuḥ śabdamanuśrāvayensu //
analyzed: bhūmyā ca devāḥ ghoṣam udīrayensuḥ śabdam anuśrāvayen su
translated: And the devas of earth cried out and made their cry heard,

original: yathānyeṣu vyākaraṇeṣu vistareṇa kartavya yathāpi aya bhagavato anupraṇidhiḥ //
analyzed: yathā anyeṣu vyākaraṇeṣu vistareṇa yathā api aya bhagavataḥ anupraṇidhiḥ
translated: as has been done in other proclamations. And this was the exalted one’s resolve.

original: kāśyapamanupravrajitvā śodhaye cārāma pānīya copasthāye jyotipālo bodhisatvo sabuddhena anuśiṣṭo //
analyzed: kāśyapam anupravrajitvā śodhaye ca ārāma pānīya ca upasthāye jyotipālaḥ bodhisatvaḥ sabuddhena anuśiṣṭaḥ
translated: After he had gone forth under Kāśyapa, Jyotipāla, the Bodhisattva, purified the park and the water, and served the Buddha.

original: yvāgūpāna adāsi suvarṇapīṭhaka ca vastrayuga ca /
analyzed: yvāgūpāna adāsi suvarṇapīṭhaka ca vastrayuga ca
translated: He gave him food and drink, a golden throne and a pair of garments.

original: bodhisatvo jyotipālo prārthayamāno bhavanirodha //
analyzed: bodhisatvaḥ jyotipālo prārthayamānaḥ bhava nirodha
translated: The Bodhisattva Jyotipāla, desiring the cessation of existence,

original: so ta dāna dattvā praṇidhesi lokanāyako asyā /
analyzed: saḥ ta dāna dattvā praṇidhesi loka nāyakaḥ asyāḥ
translated: having given that gift, made this vow: “May I become a world-leader for this (world).

original: devamanuṣyācaryo ārya dharma prakāśyyā /
analyzed: ārya dharma
translated: May I teach the noble Dharma to gods and humans.

original: eva ca mahya asyātprakāśanā dharmasya eva ca bahū satvā āryadharmehi niveśeyyā //
analyzed: eva ca asyāt prakāśanā dharmasya eva ca bahū satvāḥ ārya dharmehi
translated: And may it be so that by teaching this Dharma, I may establish many beings in the noble Dharma.”

original: eva ca me śruṇensu devamanuṣyā vākya eva ca dharmacakra pravarteya bahujanahitāya dharmolkā prajvāleya parāhaṇeya dharmabherī sapatākā
analyzed: eva ca me deva manuṣyāḥ vākye eva ca dharma cakra pravarteya bahu jana hitāya dharma ulkā prajvāleya parāhaṇeya dharma bherī sa patākā
translated: And may gods and humans listen to my words. And may I turn the wheel of Dharma for the benefit of many. May I light the torch of Dharma, beat the drum of Dharma, raise the banner of Dharma,

original: ucchrapayeya dharmaketu dharmaśakha prapūrayeya kṛcchrāpannaiḥ jātijarāpīḍitairmaraṇadharmaiḥ bhavacakṣukaiḥ apāyehi prajñācakṣu niveśeyya
analyzed: ucchrapayeya dharma ketu dharma śakha prapūrayeya kṛcchra āpannaiḥ jāti jarā pīḍitaiḥ maraṇa dharmaiḥ bhava cakṣukaiḥ apāyehi prajñā cakṣu niveśeyya
translated: and fill the Dharma conch. May I establish the eye of wisdom in those who are in distress, afflicted by birth and old age, subject to death, and wandering in cyclic existence, in the lower realms.

original: sajīve kālasūtre saghāte raurave avīcismi ṣaṭsu gatiṣu vikīrṇā bhavasasārātparimocayeya narake pakvāvipakvā apāyanipīḍitā maraṇadharmā
analyzed: sa jīve kālasūtre sa ghāte raurave ṣaṭsu gatiṣu vikīrṇāḥ bhava sa sārāt parimocayeya narake pakva avipakvāḥ apāya nipīḍitāḥ maraṇa dharmāḥ
translated: In Saṃjīva, Kālasūtra, Saṃghāta, Raurava, Avīci, and the six destinies, may I liberate them from the cycle of existence. May I liberate from the cycle of existence those in hell, whether cooked or uncooked, afflicted by lower realms, subject to death,

original: alpasukhaduḥkhabahulā bhavasasārātparimocayeya //
analyzed: alpa sukha duḥkha bahulā bhava sa sārāt parimocayeya
translated: having little happiness and much suffering.”

original: artha careya lokasya devamanuṣyāṇā deśeya dharma //
analyzed: artha careya lokasya deva manuṣyāṇā deśeya dharma
translated: I will practice for the sake of the world, and teach the Dharma to gods and humans.

original: eva vineya satvā yathāya lokapradyoto //
analyzed: eva vineya satvā loka pradyotaḥ
translated: Thus, I will guide beings, just as the Light of the World does now.

original: buddho tuva hohisi lokanāyako anāgate imasmi bhadrakalpe /
analyzed: buddhaḥ tuva hohisi loka nāyakaḥ anāgate imasmi bhadra kalpe
translated: You will become a Buddha, a leader of the world, in the future, in this fortunate eon.

original: kapilāhūye ṛṣivadanasmi śākiyo tadā tava praṇidhivipāko bhaṣyati //
analyzed: śākiyaḥ tadā tava praṇidhi vipākaḥ bhaṣyati
translated: Then, in Kapilavastu, in the Deer Park at Rsipatana, your aspiration will come to fruition.

original: akhaṇḍa acchidramaśabalakalmāṣa paripūrṇa pariśuddha vrahmacarya caritvā kālagato tuṣite nāma devanikāye śvetaketurnāma devaputro maharddhiko
analyzed: akhaṇḍa acchidra maśabala kalmāṣa paripūrṇa pariśuddha vrahmacarya caritvā kālagataḥ tuṣite nāma devanikāye śvetaketuḥ nāma deva putraḥ maharddhikaḥ
translated: Having practiced celibacy perfectly, without blemish, without defect, without taint, complete, pure, he passed away and was reborn in the Tusita heaven as the deva-son Svetaketu, of great power,

original: mahānubhāvo so nyā devā divyehi daśahi sthānehi abhibhavati divyenāyuṣā divyena varṇena divyena sukhena divyena aiśvaryeṇa divyena parivāreṇa
analyzed: mahā anubhāvaḥ saḥ devāḥ divyehi daśahi sthānehi abhibhavati divyena āyuṣā divyena varṇena divyena sukhena divyena aiśvaryeṇa divyena parivāreṇa
translated: of great majesty. He surpasses the other devas in ten heavenly ways: in heavenly life span, heavenly complexion, heavenly happiness, heavenly glory, heavenly retinue,

original: divyena rūpeṇa divyehi śabdehi divyehi gandhehi divyehi rasehi divyehi praṣṭavyehi //
analyzed: divyena rūpeṇa divyehi śabdehi divyehi gandhehi divyehi rasehi divyehi praṣṭavyehi
translated: heavenly form, heavenly sound, heavenly smell, heavenly taste, and heavenly touch.

original: anye pi devaputrā na āpṛcche ya paripṛcchanīya iti /
analyzed: anye pi deva putrāḥ naḥ āpṛcche yaḥ paripṛcchanīyaḥ iti
translated: Other deva-sons do not ask what he asks.

original: aya śvetaketurnāma devaputro paṇḍito vyakto viśārado kuśalo medhāī catvāriśatīhi buddhasahasrehi anupravrājito /
analyzed: śvetaketuḥ nāma deva putraḥ paṇḍitaḥ vyaktaḥ viśāradaḥ kuśalaḥ medhāī catvāriśatīhi buddha sahasrehi anupravrājitaḥ
translated: This Devaputra named Śvetaketu is learned, eloquent, confident, skilled, and intelligent. He has gone forth under forty thousand Buddhas,

original: pacāśītīnā buddhasahasrāṇāmadhikārakarmāṇi kṛtāni ṣasmavatīhi pratyekabuddhakoṭīhi ko punarvādo śrāvakamaheśākhyehi //
analyzed: buddha sahasrāṇām adhikāra karmāṇi kṛtāni ṣasmavatīhi pratyekabuddha koṭīhi śrāvaka maheśākhyehi
translated: and has performed meritorious deeds for eighty thousand Buddhas, and for sixty koṭis of Pratyekabuddhas, not to mention the great Śrāvakas.

original: catvāriśa buddhasahasrāṇi nirvṛtā lokanāyakā buddhā /
analyzed: catvāriśa buddha sahasrāṇi nirvṛtāḥ loka nāyakāḥ buddhāḥ
translated: Forty thousand Buddhas, world-protectors, have passed away,

original: yeṣu jino acari brahmacarya prārthayamāno bhavanirodha //
analyzed: yeṣu jinaḥ acari brahmacarya prārthayamānaḥ bhava nirodha
translated: under whom the Victorious One practiced celibacy, aspiring to end existence.

original: pacāśa buddhasahasrāṇi nirvṛtā lokanāyakā buddhā /
analyzed: pacāśa buddha sahasrāṇi nirvṛtāḥ loka nāyakāḥ buddhāḥ
translated: Fifty thousand Buddhas, world-protectors, have passed away,

original: yehi jino akāsi kāla prārthayamāno bhavanirodha //🔽ṣasmavati pratyekabuddhakoṭīni nirvṛtāni svayabhuno /
analyzed: yehi jinaḥ kāla prārthayamānaḥ bhava nirodha  ṣasmavati pratyekabuddha koṭīni nirvṛtāni
translated: under whom the Victorious One made his time, aspiring to end existence.

original: yeṣu jina akāsi kāla prārthayamāno bhavanirodadha //
analyzed: yeṣu kāla
translated: Sixty koṭis of Pratyekabuddhas have passed away, under whom the Victorious One made his time, aspiring to end existence.

original: aparimitā arhantakoṭī nirvṛtā yeṣu mahādhyayīṣu /
analyzed: aparimitā arhanta koṭī nirvṛtā yeṣu mahādhyayīṣu
translated: Countless koṭis of Arhats have passed away under whom the great sages,

original: jino akāsi kāla prārthayamāno bhavanirodha //
analyzed: jinaḥ kāla prārthayamānaḥ bhava nirodha
translated: the Victorious One made his time, aspiring to end existence.

original: eteṣu pūrvayogā prakīrtitā śāstuno daśabalasya //
analyzed: eteṣu pūrva yogā prakīrtitā śāstunaḥ daśabalasya
translated: These past connections of the Teacher, the One with the Ten Powers, have been proclaimed.

original: alpā bhaṇitā bhū abhaṇitā yeṣu jino akāsi kāla prārthayamāno bhavanirodha //
analyzed: alpā bhaṇitā bhū a bhaṇitā yeṣu jinaḥ kāla prārthayamānaḥ bhava nirodha
translated: The Conqueror, who has attained the end of existence, has said little of those who have not attained it, though he has long desired to do so.

original: iti śrīmahāvastu avadāne jyotipālasya vyākaraṇa samāpta //
analyzed: iti śrī mahāvastu avadāne jyotipālasya vyākaraṇa samāpta
translated: Thus ends the prediction of Jyotipāla in the Mahāvastu-Avadāna.

original: rājavaśe ādi //
analyzed: rājavaśe ādi
translated: The story of the king's power begins.

original: bhavati bhikṣaḥ sa kālo bhavati sa samayo yadaya loko dīrghasvādhvano tyayena savartati /
analyzed: bhavati bhikṣaḥ sa kālaḥ bhavati sa samayaḥ yat aya lokaḥ dīrgha sva adhvanaḥ tyayena savartati
translated: Monks, there comes a time, there comes an occasion when, after the world has remained expanded for a long period, it begins to contract.

original: savartamāne ca punarbhikṣavo loke yobhūyena satvā ābhāsvare devanikāye upapadyanti //🔽bhavati bhikṣavaḥ sa kālo bhavati sa samayo yada loko dīrghasyādhvano atyayena vivartati //
analyzed: savartamāne ca punar bhikṣavaḥ loke yobhūyena satvāḥ ābhāsvare devanikāye upapadyanti  bhavati bhikṣavaḥ sa kālaḥ bhavati sa samayaḥ lokaḥ dīrghasya adhvanaḥ atyayena vivartati
translated: Monks, when the world is contracting, beings are for the most part reborn in the Ābhāsvara world.🔽Monks, there comes a time, there comes an occasion when, after the world has contracted, it begins to expand.

original: vivartamāne khalu punarbhikṣavo loke sasthite lokasanniveśe anyatarā satvā āyuḥkṣayāya ca karmakṣayāya ca ābhāsvarāto devanikāyāto cyavitvā
analyzed: vivartamāne khalu punar bhikṣavaḥ loke sasthite loka sanniveśe anyatarā satvā āyuḥ kṣayāya ca karma kṣayāya ca cyavitvā  /
translated: Monks, when the world is expanding, beings fall from the Ābhāsvara world, their life being exhausted.

original: icchatvamāgacchanti //
analyzed: icchatvam āgacchanti
translated: They come to the realm of desire.

original: te bhavanti satvā svayaprabhāḥ antarīkṣacarā manomayā prītibhakṣāḥ sukhasthāyino yenakāmagatāḥ //
analyzed: te bhavanti satvā svayam prabhāḥ antarīkṣa carāḥ manaḥ mayāḥ prīti bhakṣāḥ sukha sthāyinaḥ yena kāma gatāḥ
translated: Those beings become self-luminous, move through the air, are made of mind, feed on joy, and abide in a state of bliss. They go wherever they wish.

original: dharmatā khalu punarbhikṣavo ya teṣā satvānā svayaprabhāṇā antarīkṣacarāṇā manomayānā prītibha kṣāṇā sukhasthāyinā yenakāmagatānā
analyzed: dharmatā khalu punar bhikṣavaḥ ya teṣām satvānām svaya prabhāṇām antarīkṣa carāṇām manaḥ mayānā prīti bha kṣāṇām sukha sthāyinām yenakāma gatānām
translated: It is natural that when those beings were self-luminous, moving through space, consisting of mind, feeding on joy, living in bliss, and going wherever they wished,

original: ime candramasūryā loke na prajñāyensuḥ /🔽candramasūryehi loke aprajñāyantehi tārakarūpā loke na prajñāyensuḥ /
analyzed: ime candramas sūryāḥ loke na prajñāyensuḥ  candrama sūrye hi loke tāraka rūpāḥ loke na
translated: the moon and sun did not appear in the world.🔽When the moon and sun did not appear in the world, the stars did not appear in the world.

original: tārakarūpehi loke aprajñāyantehi nakṣatrapathā loke na prajñāyensuḥ nakṣatrapathehi loke na prajñāyantehi rātridivā loke na prajñāyensuḥ /
analyzed: tāraka rūpehi loke a prajñāyantehi nakṣatra pathāḥ loke na prajñāyensuḥ nakṣatra pathehi loke na prajñāyantehi rātri divāḥ loke na prajñāyensuḥ
translated: When the stars did not appear in the world, the directions did not appear in the world. When the directions did not appear in the world, the constellations did not appear in the world. When the constellations did not appear in the world, night and day did not appear in the world.

original: rātridivehi loke na prajñāyantehi māsārdhamāsā loke na prajñāyensuḥ /
analyzed: rātri dive hi loke na prajñāyante hi māsa ardha māsāḥ loke na prajñāyensuḥ
translated: When night and day did not appear in the world, the months and fortnights did not appear in the world.

original: māsārdhamāseṣu loke aprajñāyamāneṣu ṛtusavatsarā loke na prajñāyante //
analyzed: māsa ardha māseṣu loke a prajñāyamāneṣu ṛtu savatsarāḥ loke na prajñāyante
translated: When the months and fortnights did not appear in the world, the seasons and years did not appear in the world.

original: dharmatā khalu bhikṣavo ya teṣā satvānā svayaprabhāṇāmantarīkṣacarāṇā yāvadyenakāmagatānā //
analyzed: dharmatā khalu bhikṣavaḥ teṣām satvānām svaya prabhāṇām antarīkṣa carāṇām yāvat yenakāma gatānām
translated: It is natural that when those beings were self-luminous, moving through space, consisting of mind, feeding on joy, living in bliss, and going wherever they wished,

original: ayamapi mahāpṛthivī udakahda viya samudāgacchet //
analyzed: ayam api mahā pṛthivī samudāgacchet
translated: this great earth would have arisen like a lake of water.

original: sā cābhūdvarṇasampannā rasasampannā sayyathāpi nāma kṣudra madhvaneḍaka evamāsvādo sayyathāpi nāma kṣīrasantāna vā sarpisantāna vā eva
analyzed: sā ca abhūt varṇa sampannā rasa sampannā sa yyathā api nāma kṣudra evam āsvādaḥ sa yyathā api nāma kṣīra santāna vā sarpi santāna vā eva
translated: It was endowed with color and taste, just like honey from the honeycomb, or like cream of ghee.

original: varṇapratibhāso //
analyzed: varṇa pratibhāsaḥ
translated: It had a color and appearance

original: atha khalu bhikṣavo anyataraḥ satvaḥ capalo lolupajātīyo ta pṛthivīrasa agulīye āsvādesi //
analyzed: atha khalu bhikṣavaḥ anyataraḥ satvaḥ capalaḥ lolupa jātīyaḥ ta pṛthivī rasa agulīye āsvādesi
translated: Then, monks, a certain being, restless and of a greedy nature, tasted that earth essence with his finger.

original: tasya ta svādayati varṇenāpi gandhenāpi rasenāpi //
analyzed: tasya te svādayati varṇena api gandhena api rasena api
translated: It tasted good to him in color, smell, and taste.

original: anye pi satvā tasya satvasya dṛṣṭvānukṛtimāpadyante //
analyzed: anye pi tasya satvasya dṛṣṭvā anukṛtim āpadyante
translated: Other beings, seeing that being doing this, imitated him.

original: te pi pṛthivīrasamagulyāsvādayensu //
analyzed: te pi
translated: They too tasted the earth essence with their fingers.

original: teṣāmapi ta svādayati yāvat rasenāpi //
analyzed: teṣām api svādayati yāvat rasena api
translated: It tasted good to them also in color, smell, and taste.
