original: atha khalu bhikṣavaḥ so satvo aparakālena ta pṛthivīrasa ālopakāramāhāra āhāresi //
analyzed: atha khalu bhikṣavaḥ saḥ satvaḥ apara kālena ta pṛthivī rase ālopakāram āhāre āhāresi
translated: Then, monks, at another time that being took a mouthful of that earth essence and ate it.

original: anye pi satvā tasya satvasya dṛṣṭvānukṛtimāpadyante //
analyzed: anye pi tasya satvasya dṛṣṭvā anukṛtim āpadyante
translated: Other beings, seeing that being doing this, imitated him.

original: te pi ta pṛthivīrasa ālopakārakamāhāramāhārensuḥ //
analyzed: te pi ta pṛthivī rase ālopa kārakam āhāram āhārensuḥ
translated: They too took mouthfuls of that earth essence and ate it.

original: yato ca bhikṣavaste satvā ta pṛthivīrasamālopakārakamāhāramāharensuḥ atha teṣā kāye gurutva ca kharatva ca kakkhaṭatva ca upanipate //
analyzed: yatas ca bhikṣavaḥ te satvā pṛthivī rasa mālopakārakam āhāram āharensuḥ atha teṣām kāye guru tva ca khara tva ca kakkhaṭa tva ca upanipate
translated: And when, monks, those beings had made the earth’s rind their food for a long time, their bodies became heavy, rough, and hard, and they took on the appearance of the village pig.

original: yāpi cābhūtpūrva sāna svayaprabhatā antarīkṣacaratā manomayakāyatā prītibhakṣatā sukhasthāyitā yenakāmagamatā sā antarahāye //
analyzed: yā api svayaprabha tā antarīkṣa cara tā manaḥ maya kāya tā prīti bhakṣa tā sukha sthāyi tā yenakāma gama tā sā
translated: And then, monks, the self-luminous beings, who were of radiant body, moved through the air, were made of mind, fed on joy, lived in bliss, and went wherever they wished, lost that condition.

original: svayaprabhatāye antarīkṣacaratāye manomayatāye prītibhakṣatāye yenakāmagamatāye antarhitāye candrasūryā loke prajñāyensu //
analyzed: svayaprabhatāye antarīkṣa caratāye manaḥ maya tāye prīti bhakṣatāye yena kāma gamatāye antarhita aye candra sūryāḥ loke
translated: And when they had lost their self-luminosity, their movement through the air, their being made of mind, their feeding on joy, their living in bliss, and their going wherever they wished, then the moon and sun became known in the world.

original: candramasūryehi loke prajñāyantehi tārakarūpā loke prajñāyensu /🔽tārakarūpehi loke prajñāyantehi nakṣatrapathā loke prajñāyensu /
analyzed: candrama sūrye hi loke tāraka rūpāḥ loke  tāraka rūpehi loke prajñāyante hi nakṣatra pathāḥ loke prajñāyensu
translated: And when the moon and sun became known in the world, then the stars became known in the world.🔽And when the stars became known in the world, then the directions became known in the world.🔽And when the directions became known in the world, then the constellations became known in the world.

original: nakṣatrapathehi loke prajñāyantehi rātridivā loke prajñāyante /
analyzed: nakṣatra pathehi loke prajñāyante hi rātri divāḥ loke prajñāyante
translated: And when the constellations became known in the world, then night and day became known in the world.

original: rātridivasehi loke prajñāntehi māsārdhamāsā loke prajñāyante /🔽māsārdhamāsehi prajñāyantehi ṛtusavatsarā loke prajñāyensu //
analyzed: rātri divasehi loke māsa ardha māsāḥ loke prajñāyante 🔽māsa ardha māsehi ṛtu savatsarāḥ loke
translated: And when night and day became known in the world, then the months and fortnights became known in the world.🔽And when the months and fortnights became known in the world, then the seasons and the year became known in the world.

original: atha khalu bhikṣavaste satvā ta pṛthivīrasamāhāramāharantā tavarṇā tabhakṣā tadāhārā cira dīrghamadhvāna tiṣṭhensuḥ //
analyzed: atha khalu bhikṣavaḥ te satvā ta pṛthivī rasamāhāram āharantā ta varṇā ta bhakṣā tad āhārā cira dīrgham adhvāna tiṣṭhensuḥ
translated: Then, monks, those beings, feeding on the earth’s nutrient that had the colour, smell and taste of fresh butter, lived on it for a very long time.

original: ye sāna bahu āhāramāhārensu te abhūnsu durvārṇāḥ ye alpamāhāramāhāresuḥ varṇāvantā //🔽ye abhūnsuḥ varṇavantā te durvarṇā satvā avajānensuḥ //
analyzed: ye te abhūnsu durvārṇāḥ ye varṇāvantā  ye abhūnsuḥ varṇavantā te durvarṇā satvā avajānensuḥ
translated: Those who took a lot of the nutrient became ugly, while those who took little became good-looking.🔽Those who were good-looking despised those who were ugly, saying:

original: vayamasma varṇavanto satvā ime bhavanti durvarṇā //
analyzed: vayam asma varṇavantaḥ satvāḥ ime bhavanti durvarṇāḥ
translated: ‘We are good-looking, these are ugly.’

original: teṣā varṇābhivarṇapratyayānā mānābhimānajātīyānā viharatā pṛthiviraso antarahāye //
analyzed: teṣām varṇa abhivarṇa pratyayānām māna abhimāna jātīyānām viharatā
translated: While they were living in this state of pride and vanity, the earth’s nutrient disappeared.

original: bhūmiparpaṭaka prādurbhaveya sayyathāpi nāma cchātraka eva varṇapratibhāso //
analyzed: bhūmiparpaṭaka prādurbhaveya sayyathā api nāma chātrakaḥ eva varṇa pratibhāsaḥ
translated: In its place there appeared a creeper called bhūmiparpaṭaka, which was like a mushroom in appearance.

original: so ca abhūdvarṇasapanno ca gandhasapanno ca sayyathāpi nāma kṣudro madhu aneḍako evamāsvādo //
analyzed: saḥ ca abhūt varṇa sapannaḥ ca gandha sapannaḥ ca sa yyathā api nāma kṣudraḥ evam āsvādaḥ
translated: It had a good colour and smell, and was as sweet as pure honey.

original: atha khalu bhikṣavo te satvā asmi pṛthivīrase antarahite ima udānamudānayensu //
analyzed: atha khalu bhikṣavaḥ te satvā asmi pṛthivī rase antarahite ime udānam udānayensu
translated: Then, monks, when the earth’s nutrient had disappeared, those beings, in their search for food, discovered the taste of this creeper.

original: aho raso haro raseti //
analyzed: aho rasaḥ haraḥ rasa iti
translated: They exclaimed: ‘Ah, what a taste! Ah, what a taste!’

original: sayyathāpi nāma bhikṣava etarahi manuṣyā subhojanakhāditā sukhitā bhuktāvino ema udānamudānentīti //
analyzed: sayyathā api nāma bhikṣavaḥ etarahi manuṣyā su bhojana khāditā sukhitāḥ bhuktāvinaḥ eme udānam udānenti iti
translated: Just as people today, when they have eaten well and are satisfied, exclaim:

original: aho raso aho raso ti //
analyzed: aho rasaḥ aho rasaḥ ti
translated: 'What a taste! What a taste!'

original: tameva paurāṇamakṣaramagninya upanpate artha cāsya na vibhāvayensu /
analyzed: tam eva paurāṇam akṣaram agninyaḥ ca asya na
translated: But they did not understand the meaning of it.

original: atha khalu bhikṣavaste satvāsta bhūmiparpaṭaka āhāra āharantā tadvarṇā tadbhakṣāstadāhārā cira dīrghamadhvāna tiṣṭhensu //
analyzed: atha khalu bhikṣavaḥ te satvāḥ ta bhūmiparpaṭake āhāre āharantā tad varṇā tad bhakṣāḥ tad āhārā cira dīrgham adhvāna
translated: Then, monks, those beings, taking the earth-puddings as their food, remained for a long time feeding on them, living on them, subsisting on them.

original: ye sāna bahu āhāra āhārensu abhūnsu ye alpa āhāra āhārensu te abhūnsu varṇavanto //
analyzed: ye sāna bahu āhāra āhārensu abhūnsu ye alpa āhāra āhārensu te abhūnsu varṇavantaḥ
translated: Those who took a lot of the earth-puddings became ugly, while those who took little of them became well-formed.

original: ye suvarṇavanto te durvarṇā satvā avanānensuḥ //
analyzed: ye suvarṇavantaḥ te durvarṇāḥ satvāḥ avanānensuḥ
translated: Those who were well-formed looked down on those who were ugly, saying:

original: vayamasma varṇavantā ime bhavanti satvā durvarṇā //
analyzed: vayam asma varṇavantaḥ ime bhavanti satvāḥ durvarṇā
translated: 'We are well-formed, these beings are ugly.'

original: teṣā varṇābhivarṇapratyayānā mānābhimānajātīyānā viharatā bhūmiparpaṭakamantarahāre vanalā prādurbhūtā //
analyzed: teṣām varṇa abhivarṇa pratyayānām māna abhimāna jātīyānām viharatā bhūmiparpaṭakam antarahāre vanalā prādurbhūtā
translated: While they lived in this way, conceited about their own beauty and despising others, the earth-puddings disappeared.

original: sayyathāpi nāma kalambukā eva varṇapratibhāsāpi abhū varṇasampannāpi gandhasampannāpi rasasapannāpi tadyathāpi nāma kṣudra madhumaneḻaka
analyzed: sayyathā api nāma kalambukā eva varṇa pratibhāsā api varṇa sampannā api gandha sampannā api rasa sapannā api tat yathā api nāma kṣudra madhumaneḍaka
translated: They were of good colour and appearance, and were endowed with a good colour, a good smell, and a good taste, just like fresh ghee or butter.

original: evamāsvādā //
analyzed: evam āsvādā
translated: They were so delicious.

original: atha khalu bhikṣavo te satvā bhūmiparpaṭake antarhite anustanayensu //
analyzed: atha khalu bhikṣavaḥ te satvāḥ bhūmiparpaṭake antarhite anustanayensu
translated: Then, monks, when the earth-mushrooms disappeared, those beings cried out:

original: aho vadi aho vadīti //🔽tadyathāpi nāma bhikṣava etarahi satvā kenacideva duḥkhadharmeṇa spṛṣṭā anustanayensu aho vadi aho vadīti tameva paurāṇamakṣaramagninya
analyzed: aho vadi aho vadi iti  tat yathā api nāma bhikṣavaḥ etarahi satvā kenacid eva duḥkha dharmeṇa spṛṣṭāḥ anustanayen su aho vadi aho vadi iti tam eva paurāṇam akṣaram agninya
translated: ‘Alas! Alas!’

original: upanipate artha ca na vibhāvayensuḥ /
analyzed: upanipate artha ca na vibhāvayensuḥ
translated: Just as people now, when touched by something painful, cry out: ‘Alas! Alas!’ and use that ancient word, though they do not understand its meaning,

original: evameva bhikṣavaste satvāstasmi bhūmiparpaṭake antarhite anustanayensuḥ /
analyzed: evam eva bhikṣavaḥ te satvāḥ tasmi bhūmiparpaṭake antarhite anustanayensuḥ
translated: so, monks, did those beings, when the earth-mushrooms disappeared, cry out:

original: aho vadi aho vadīti //
analyzed: aho vadi aho vadi iti
translated: ‘Alas! Alas!’

original: ata khalu bhikṣavaste satvāstasmi bhūmiparpaṭake antarahite vanalatā āhāramāharantā tavarṇā tabhakṣā tadāhārā cira dīghamadhāna tiṣṭhensu
analyzed: atas khalu bhikṣavaḥ te satvāḥ tasmin bhūmiparpaṭake anta rahite vana latāḥ āhāram āharantā ta varṇā ta bhakṣā ta āhārā cira tiṣṭhen
translated: Then, monks, when the earth-mushrooms had disappeared, those beings, living on the wild jujube, having the wild jujube for their sustenance, remained for a long, long time.

original: ye sāna bahu āhāra āhārensuḥ te abhūnsuḥ durvarṇā ye alpāhāra āhārenu abhūnsu vaṇavano /
analyzed: ye sāna bahu āhāra āhārensuḥ te abhūnsuḥ durvarṇā ye alpāhāra āhārenu abhūnsu
translated: Those who ate a lot became ugly, while those who ate little remained beautiful.

original: te tā durvarṇā satvā avajānensu /
analyzed: te tā durvarṇā satvāḥ avajānensu
translated: The ugly beings despised the others,

original: vayamasma varṇavanto ime bhavani satvā duvarṇā //🔽teṣā vaṇābhivarṇapratyayānā mānābhimānajātīyānā vanalatā antarahāye //
analyzed: vayam asma varṇavantaḥ ime bhavani satvā duvarṇā  teṣām vaṇa abhivarṇa pratyayānām māna abhimāna jātīyānām vana latāḥ antara hāye
translated: saying: “We are beautiful, these beings are ugly.”🔽Because of their pride and conceit in their beauty and ugliness, the creeper disappeared.

original: śāli akaṇo atuṣaḥ surabhitaṇḍulaḥ prādurbhaveyā sāya lūno so kālya bhavati jāto pakvo virūḍho avadāna pi se na prajñāyati //
analyzed: a kaṇaḥ a tuṣaḥ surabhi taṇḍulaḥ prādurbhaveyā sāya lūnaḥ saḥ kālya bhavati jātaḥ pakvaḥ virūḍhaḥ avadāna pi se na prajñāyati
translated: Then rice appeared, without powder or husk, fragrant and clean. It was harvested in the evening and grew again by the morning, ripe and unripe mixed together.

original: so pi kālya lūno sāya bhavati jāto pakvo virūḍhī avadāna cāsya na prajñāyati //
analyzed: saḥ pi kālya lūnaḥ sāya bhavati jātaḥ pakvaḥ virūḍhī avadāna ca asya na prajñāyati
translated: It was harvested in the morning and grew again by the evening, ripe and unripe mixed together.

original: atha khalu bhikṣavo te satvā tasmi vanalate antarhite anustanayensuḥ //
analyzed: atha khalu bhikṣavaḥ te satvā tasmi vana late antarhite anustanayensuḥ
translated: Then, monks, when that creeper disappeared, those beings lamented:

original: aho veda aho veda ti //
analyzed: aho veda aho veda ti
translated: “Ah! Food! Ah! Food!”

original: tadyathāpi nāma bhikṣavo etarahi satvā kenacideva duḥkhadharmeṇa spṛṣṭā anustanayensu /🔽tameva paurāṇamakṣaramagnintha upanipate artha cāsya na vibhāvayensu //
analyzed: tat yathā api nāma bhikṣavaḥ etarahi satvā kenacid eva duḥkha dharmeṇa spṛṣṭāḥ 🔽tam eva paurāṇam akṣaram upanipate
translated: Just as people now, when touched by some painful feeling, lament:🔽“Ah! Pain! Ah! Pain!”

original: atha khalu bhikṣavaste satvā tasmi vanalate antarhite ta śāli akaṇa atuṣa surabhitaṇḍulaphala āhāramāharantā cira dīrghamadhvāna tiṣṭhensu
analyzed: atha khalu bhikṣavaḥ te satvā tasmi vana late antarhite āhāram āharantā cira dīrgham adhvāna tiṣṭhen
translated: Monks, when that forest creeper disappeared, those beings continued to live for a very long time, subsisting on that rice which was without powder or husk, had a sweet scent, and was fully cooked.

original: yato ca bhikṣavaste satvāsta śāli akaṇa atuṣa surabhitaṇḍulaphala āhāramāhārensu atha sāna strīṇā strīvyajanāni prādurbhavensuḥ puruṣāṇā
analyzed: yatas ca bhikṣavaḥ te satvāḥ ta śāli a kaṇa a tuṣa surabhi taṇḍula phala āhāram āhārensu atha sāna strīṇā strī vyajanāni prādurbhavensuḥ puruṣāṇā
translated: Monks, when those beings began to subsist on that rice which was without powder or husk, had a sweet scent, and was fully cooked, then the signs of female and male appeared among them.

original: puruṣavyajanāni prādurbhavensuḥ //🔽ativela raktacittā anyonya upanidhyāyensu //
analyzed: puruṣa vyajanāni prādurbhavensuḥ  rakta cittāḥ anyonyaḥ upanidhyāyen
translated: The women had the signs of women, and the men had the signs of men.🔽They became excessively lustful, and they began to look at each other with lustful thoughts.

original: anyonya raktacittā anyonya upaidhyāya te anyamanya sarañjensu anyamanya saraktā anyamanya dūṣayensuḥ //
analyzed: rakta cittāḥ anyonya upaidhyāya te anyam anya sa rañjensu anyam anya sa raktāḥ anyam anya dūṣayensuḥ
translated: With lustful thoughts, they approached each other and had sexual intercourse. They became defiled by lust.

original: ye khalu punarbhikṣavaḥ satvānpaśyensu dūṣyamāṇā te tatra daṇḍa pi kṣipensu leṣṭu pi kṣipensu pāśu kṣipensu //
analyzed: ye khalu punar bhikṣavaḥ satvān paśyensu dūṣyamāṇā te tatra kṣipensu kṣipensu
translated: Monks, those beings who saw them being defiled by lust threw sticks, clods, and rubbish at them,

original: adharmo bhavanto loke prādurbhūto asaḍvarmo bhavanto loke prādurbhūtaḥ yatra hi nāma satvo satva dūṣayati //
analyzed: adharmaḥ bhavantaḥ loke prādurbhūtaḥ asaṭ varmaḥ bhavantaḥ loke prādurbhūtaḥ yatra hi nāma satvaḥ satva dūṣayati
translated: saying, Unrighteousness has appeared in the world, bad conduct has appeared in the world, when a being defiles another being.

original: tadyathāpi nāma bhikṣavaḥ etarahi dārikāye vuhyantīye daṇḍa nikṣipanti teṣṭu pi nikṣipanti ta eva paurāṇamakṣaramagninya upanipate artha
analyzed: tat yathā api nāma bhikṣavaḥ etarahi nikṣipanti nikṣipanti te eva paurāṇam akṣaram agninyaḥ upanipate
translated: Just as now, monks, when a girl is in labor, they place a stick or a knife in her hand, thinking that when she holds it, she will give birth. But those ancient letters and words did not make sense to them.

original: cāsya na vibhāvayensu //
analyzed: ca asya na vibhāvayet su
translated: And they could not understand their meaning.

original: tadā khalu punasta bhikṣavaḥ adharmasamata ayajñasamata ca avinayasamata ca /
analyzed: tadā khalu punar te bhikṣavaḥ adharma samata ayajña samata ca avinaya samata ca
translated: Then, monks, there was non-Dharma, non-rite, and non-discipline.

original: etarahi khalu punasta bhikṣavaḥ dharmasamata ca yajñasamata vinayasamata ca //
analyzed: etarahi khalu punar ta bhikṣavaḥ dharma samata ca yajña samata vinaya samata ca
translated: But now, monks, there is Dharma, rite, and discipline.

original: atha khalu bhikṣavaste satvā tena adharmeṇa artīyantā vijigupsitā ekāha pi vipravasensu dvyaha pi vipravasensu tryaha pi vipravasensu
analyzed: atha khalu bhikṣavaḥ te satvā tena adharmeṇa artīyantā vijigupsitāḥ eka aha pi vipravasensu dvi aha pi vipravasensu tri aha pi vipravasensu
translated: Then, monks, those beings, being disgusted with that non-Dharma, would stay away for one day, two days, three days,

original: caturahi pi vipravasensu pacāha pi pakṣa pi māsa pi vipravasensu gṛhakarmāntā pi kārayensu yāvadeva tasyaiva adharmasya praticchadanārtha
analyzed: vipravasensu paca aha pi pakṣa pi māsa pi vipravasensu gṛha karmāntā pi kārayensu yāvat eva tasya eva adharmasya
translated: four days, five days, half a month, or a whole month. They would even have their household tasks done, just to conceal that very non-Dharma.

original: atha khalu bhikṣava anyatarasya satvasya śālihāraka gatasya etadabhavat //
analyzed: atha khalu bhikṣavaḥ anyatarasya satvasya śāli hāraka gatasya etat abhavat
translated: Then, monks, it occurred to one being who had gone to gather rice:

original: kimasya nāma ha kilamāmi katha purāha kilamāmi sāya sāyamāsāya prāta prātarāsāya //
analyzed: kim asya nāma ha kilamāmi katha purā āha kilamāmi sāya sāya māsāya prāta prātarāsāya
translated: What is its name? I am tired. How did I get tired? In the evening for the evening meal, in the morning for the morning meal.

original: ya nūnāha sakṛdeva daivasa sāyaprātika śāli hareya //
analyzed: ya nūna aha sakṛt eva daivasa sāyaprātika śāli hareya
translated: What if I were to take the rice for one day at once, both for the evening and morning?

original: āhare khalu bhikṣavo so satvo sakṛdeva daivasa sāyaprātika śāli //
analyzed: khalu bhikṣavaḥ saḥ satvaḥ sakṛt eva daivasa sāyaprātika
translated: Monks, that being did indeed take the rice for one day at once, both for the evening and morning.

original: atha khalu bhikṣavaḥ anyataro satvo ta satvame taduvāca //
analyzed: atha khalu bhikṣavaḥ anyataraḥ satvaḥ tat uvāca
translated: Then, monks, another being said to that being:

original: ehi bho satva śālihāra gamiṣyāmaḥ //
analyzed: ehi bho satva śālihāra gamiṣyāmaḥ
translated: Come, friend being, let us go to gather rice.

original: evamukte bhikṣavaḥ so satvo ta satvametaduvāca //
analyzed: evam ukte bhikṣavaḥ saḥ satvaḥ satvam etat uvāca
translated: When this was said, monks, that being said to that being:

original: gaccha tuva satva ānīto mayā sakṛdeva sāyaprātiko śāliḥ //
analyzed: gaccha satvaḥ ānītaḥ mayā sakṛt eva sāyaprātikaḥ śāliḥ
translated: Go, friend being, I have already brought the rice for one day at once, both for the evening and morning.

original: atha khalu bhikṣavastasyāpi satvasya etadabhavat //
analyzed: atha khalu bhikṣavaḥ tasya api satvasya etat abhavat
translated: Then, monks, that being thought:

original: eva pi kriyamāṇa śobhana bhavati /
analyzed: eva pi kriyamāṇa śobhana bhavati
translated: This is also good, that it is done like this.

original: ya nūnāha pi sakṛdeva dvyahika trīhika ta śāli hareya //
analyzed: ya nūna aha pi sakṛt eva dvyahika trīhika ta śāli hareya
translated: What if I were to take the rice for two days at once, for three days at once?

original: āhare khalu bhikṣavaḥ so pi satvo sakṛdeva dvīhika trīhika śāli //
analyzed: khalu bhikṣavaḥ saḥ pi satvaḥ sakṛt eva
translated: Monks, that being did indeed take the rice for two days at once, for three days at once.

original: atha khalu bhikṣavaḥ anyataro satvo ta satvametaduvāca //
analyzed: atha khalu bhikṣavaḥ anyataraḥ satvaḥ satvam etat uvāca
translated: Then, monks, another being said to that being:

original: ehi bho satva śālihāra gamiṣyāma //
analyzed: ehi bho satva śālihāra gamiṣyāma
translated: Come, let's go to the rice field.

original: evamukte so satvo ta satvametaduvāca //
analyzed: evam ukte saḥ satvaḥ satvam etat uvāca
translated: When this was said, that being replied to the other being:

original: gaccha tva bho satva ānīto mayā sakṛdeva dvīhiko trīhiko śāliḥ //
analyzed: gaccha tva bho satva ānītaḥ mayā sakṛt eva dvīhikaḥ trīhikaḥ śāliḥ
translated: Go, good being, I have already brought rice for two or three days.

original: atha khalu bhikṣavastasyāpi satvasya etadabhavat //
analyzed: atha khalu bhikṣavaḥ tasya api satvasya etat abhavat
translated: Then, monks, that being thought:

original: eva pi dāni kriyamāṇa śobhana bhavati /
analyzed: eva pi dāni kriyamāṇa śobhana bhavati
translated: Even this is good when done.

original: ya nūnāha pi caturahika pacāhika śālimāhareya //
analyzed: ya nūna aha pi caturahika pacāhika śālim āhareya
translated: What if I were to bring rice for four or five days?

original: āhare khalu bhikṣavo so pi satvo sakṛdeva caturahika pacāhika śāli //
analyzed: khalu bhikṣavaḥ saḥ pi satvaḥ sakṛt eva caturahika pacāhika
translated: Monks, that being also brought rice for four or five days at a time.

original: yato ca bhikṣavaḥ te satvā ta śāli akaṇa atuṣa surabhitaṇḍulaphala sanidhikāra paribhujensu atha khalu tasya śālisya kaṇo ca tuṣo ca 🔽prādurbhavati //
analyzed: yato ca bhikṣavaḥ te satvā ta śāli a kaṇa a tuṣa surabhi taṇḍula phala sa nidhi kāra atha khalu tasya śālisya kaṇaḥ ca tuṣaḥ ca  prādurbhavati
translated: Monks, when those beings began to consume that rice with its husk, chaff, and fragrant grain as a stored product, then, monks, the rice began to have a husk and chaff.

original: so pi sāya lūno kālya na jāto bhavati na pakvo na virūḍho avadāna cāsya prajñāyati //
analyzed: saḥ pi sāya lūnaḥ kālya na jātaḥ bhavati na pakvaḥ na virūḍhaḥ avadāna ca asya prajñāyati
translated: And that rice, when cut in the evening, did not sprout, ripen, or grow by the morning. And its cutting was seen.

original: atha khalu bhikṣavaste satvā sadhāvensuḥ saghāvitvā sanipatitvā mantrā mantrayansuḥ //
analyzed: atha khalu bhikṣavaḥ te satvā sadhāvensuḥ saghāvitvā sanipatitvā mantrāḥ mantrayansuḥ
translated: Then, monks, those beings, having gathered together, having gathered together, having assembled, discussed this matter:🔽What if we were to appoint one being who would be the distributor of rice for all beings?

original: vaya bhavanto svayaprabhā antarīkṣacarā manomayā prītibhakṣā sukhasthāyino yenakāmagamāḥ //
analyzed: vaya bhavantaḥ svaya prabhāḥ antarīkṣa carāḥ manaḥ mayāḥ prīti bhakṣā sukha sthāyinaḥ yena kāma gamāḥ
translated: We were self-luminous, moved through space, were made of mind, fed on joy, lived in bliss, and went wherever we wanted.

original: teṣāmasmāka svayaprabhāṇāmantarīkṣacarāṇā manomayānā prītibhakṣāṇā sukhasthāyinā yenakāmagamānā candramasūryā loke na prajñāyensu //
analyzed: teṣām asmāka svaya prabhāṇām antarīkṣa carāṇām manaḥ mayānām prīti bhakṣāṇām sukha sthāyinā yenakāma gamānā candrama sūryāḥ loke na
translated: But when we became self-luminous, moving through space, made of mind, fed on joy, living in bliss, and going wherever we wanted, the moon and sun did not appear in the world.

original: candramasūryehi loke aprajñāyantehi tārakasūpā na prajñāyante /🔽tārakarūpehi loke aprajñāyantehi nakṣatrapathā loke na prajñāyante /
analyzed: candrama sūrye hi loke a prajñāyanta hi tāraka sūpāḥ na prajñāyante  tāraka rūpehi loke a prajñāyante hi nakṣatra pathāḥ loke na prajñāyante
translated: When the moon and sun did not appear in the world, the stars did not appear.🔽When the stars did not appear in the world, the directions did not appear.

original: nakṣatrapathehi loke aprajñāyantehi rātridivā na prajñāyensu /🔽rātridivehi aprajñāyantehi māsārdhamāsā na prajñāyansu //
analyzed: nakṣatra pathehi loke rātri divāḥ na  rātri divehi māsa ardha māsāḥ na
translated: When the directions did not appear in the world, night and day did not appear.🔽When night and day did not appear, months and fortnights did not appear.

original: māsārdhamāsehi aprajñāyantehi ṛtusavatsarā na prajñāyensu //
analyzed: māsa ardha māsehi a prajñāyantehi ṛtu savatsarāḥ na
translated: When months and fortnights did not appear, seasons and years did not appear.

original: ayamapi mahāpṛthivī udakahda viya samudāgacchati //
analyzed: ayam api mahā pṛthivī samudāgacchati
translated: This great earth became like a lake of water.

original: tadyathāpi nāma sarpisantāna vā kṣīrasatāna vā eva varṇapratibhāsā abhūṣi varṇasapannā ca gandhasapannā ca rasasapannā ca tadyathāpi
analyzed: tat yathā api nāma sarpi santāna vā kṣīra santāna vā eva varṇa pratibhāsā varṇa sapannā ca gandha sapannā ca rasa sapannā ca tat yathā api
translated: Just as if there were a lump of butter or a lump of sugar, which in colour and appearance would be like the essence of the earth, and would be endowed with colour, smell and taste,

original: nāma kṣudro madhu anelako evamāsvādo //
analyzed: nāma kṣudraḥ madhu evam āsvādaḥ
translated: just like small honey, without bitterness, so was its taste.

original: atha khalu bhavanto anyataro satvo capalo lolupajātīyo ta pṛthivīrasa agulīye āsvādayate //
analyzed: atha khalu bhavantaḥ anyataraḥ satvaḥ capalaḥ lolupa jātīyaḥ ta pṛthivī rasa agulīye āsvādayate
translated: Then, venerable friends, a certain being, who was restless and of a greedy disposition, tasted that essence of the earth with his finger.

original: tasya tamāsvādayati varṇenāpi gandhenāpi rasenāpi //
analyzed: tasya tam āsvādayati varṇena api gandhena api rasena api
translated: He tasted it and liked its colour, smell and taste.

original: atha khalu bhavanto so satvo ta pṛthivīrasamaparakālena ālopakārakamāhāra āhāresi //
analyzed: atha khalu bhavantaḥ saḥ satvaḥ ta pṛthivī rasam apara kālena ālopa kārakam āhāre āhāresi
translated: Then, venerable friends, that being, at a later time, took a mouthful of that essence of the earth and ate it as food.

original: vaya tasya satvasya dṛṣṭvānukṛtimāpadyantā ta pṛthivīrasa ālopakārakamāhāra āharema //
analyzed: vaya tasya satvasya dṛṣṭvā anukṛtim āpadyanta ta pṛthivī rase ālopa kārakam āhāre āharema
translated: Seeing that, venerable friends, we too imitated it and took a mouthful of that essence of the earth and ate it as food.

original: yato ca vaya bhavanto pṛthivīrasamālopakārakamāhāra āharema athāsmāka kāye gurutva ca kharatva ca kakkhaṭatva ca upanipate //
analyzed: yatas ca vaya bhavantaḥ pṛthivī rasa mālopakārakam āhāra āharema atha asmāka kāye guru tva ca khara tva ca kakkhaṭa tva ca upanipate
translated: But, venerable friends, as soon as we ate that essence of the earth as food in mouthfuls, our bodies became heavy, rough, and hard.

original: yāpi sā pūrva abhūṣi svayaprabhatā antarīkṣacaratā manomayakāyatā prītibhakṣatā sukhasthāyitā yenakāmagamatā sā antarahāyi //
analyzed: yā api sā svayaprabha tā antarīkṣa cara tā manaḥ maya kāya tā prītibhakṣa tā sukha sthāyi tā yenakāma gama tā sā antarahāyi
translated: And the self-luminousness, the power of going through space, the body composed of mind, the food of joy, the abiding in bliss, and the going wherever one wishes, all these disappeared.

original: teṣā bhavanto svayaprabhatāye antarīkṣacaratāye manomayakāyatāye prītibhakṣatāye sukhasthāyitāye yenakāmagamatāye antarahitāye candramasūryā 🔽loke prajñāyensuḥ /
analyzed: teṣā bhavantaḥ antarīkṣa caratāye manaḥ maya kāyatāye prīti bhakṣatāye sukha sthāyi tāye yena kāma gamatāye antarahitāye candramasūryā  loke prajñāyensuḥ
translated: And that self-luminousness, that moving through space, that having a body made of mind, that feeding on rapture, that abiding in bliss, that going wherever one wishes, all disappeared.🔽And then, friends, the moon and sun appeared in the world,

original: candramasūryehi loke prajñāyantehi tārakarūpā prajñāyensuḥ /🔽tārakarūpehi prajñāyantehi nakṣatrapathā prajñāyensuḥ /
analyzed: candrama sūrye hi loke tāraka rūpā  tāraka rūpehi prajñāyante hi nakṣatra pathā
translated: and the moon and sun having appeared, the stars and constellations appeared,🔽and the stars and constellations having appeared, the paths of the stars appeared,

original: nakṣatrapathehi prajñāyantehi rātridivā prajñāyensuḥ /🔽rātridivehi prajñāyantehi māsārdhamāsā prajñāyensuḥ /
analyzed: nakṣatra pathehi rātri divā  rātri divehi māsa ardha māsā
translated: and the paths of the stars having appeared, night and day appeared,🔽and night and day having appeared, months and fortnights appeared,

original: māsārdhamāsehi prajñāyantehi ṛtusavatsarā prajñāyensuḥ //
analyzed: māsa ardha māsehi ṛtu sa vatsarā
translated: and months and fortnights having appeared, the seasons and years appeared.

original: te vaya bhavanto ta pṛthivīrasamāhāramāharantā tavarṇā tabhakṣā tadāhārā cira dīrghamadhvāna tiṣṭhema //
analyzed: te vaya bhavantaḥ ta pṛthivī rasam āhāram āharantā ta varṇā ta bhakṣā tad āhārā cira dīrgham adhvāna tiṣṭhema
translated: And then, friends, we lived on for a very long time feeding on that essence of earth, which was so beautiful and fragrant, and we remained there for a very long time.

original: yato ca sāna kecitpāpakā akuśalā dharmā prajñāyensuḥ yato ca mo kecidbhavanto pāpakā akuśalā dharmāḥ prajñāyensuḥ atha so pṛthivīraso antarhāye
analyzed: yatas ca kecid pāpakāḥ akuśalāḥ dharmāḥ prajñāyensuḥ yatas ca mo kecid bhavantaḥ pāpakāḥ akuśalāḥ dharmāḥ prajñāyensuḥ atha saḥ pṛthivī rasaḥ antarhāye  /
translated: But when these evil and unwholesome things became known, then the taste of the earth disappeared.

original: bhūmiparpaṭaka prādurbhave //
analyzed: bhūmiparpaṭaka
translated: And in its place there appeared earth-paddy,

original: tadyathā chātraka eva varṇapratibhāso pi abhūṣi varṇasampanno ca gandhasapanno ca //
analyzed: tat yathā chātrakaḥ eva varṇa pratibhāsaḥ varṇa sampannaḥ ca gandha sapannaḥ ca
translated: which was of good colour, smell and taste, like rice of the first dressing.

original: tadyathāpi nāma kṣudramadhu aneḍako evamāsvādo //
analyzed: tat yathā api nāma kṣudra madhu evam āsvādaḥ
translated: It was sweet as pure honey.

original: te vaya bhavanto bhūmiparpaṭaka āhāramāharantā tavarṇā tabhakṣā tadāhārā cira dīrghamadhvāna tiṣṭhema //
analyzed: te vaya bhavantaḥ bhūmiparpaṭake āhāram āharantā ta varṇā ta bhakṣā ta āhārā cira dīrgham adhvāna tiṣṭhema
translated: And so, honoured sirs, we lived on this earth-paddy for a very long time, making it into cakes to eat.

original: yato ca sāna kecitpāpakā anuśalā dharmā prajñāyensu atha so bhūmiparpaṭaka antarahāye vanalatā prādurbhavet /
analyzed: atha saḥ kecid pāpakāḥ anuśalāḥ dharmāḥ atha saḥ vana latā prādurbhavet
translated: But when these evil and unwholesome things became known, then the earth-paddy disappeared, and in its place there appeared forest creepers,

original: tadyathāpi nāma kalambukā eva varṇapratibhāsā sāpi abhūṣi varṇasampannā ca gandhasampannā ca rasasapannā ca //
analyzed: tat yathā api nāma kalambukā eva varṇa pratibhāsā sā api varṇa sampannā ca gandha sampannā ca rasa sapannā ca
translated: which were of good colour, smell and taste, like rice of the first dressing.

original: sayyathāpi nāma kṣudro madhu aneḍako evamāsvādaḥ //
analyzed: sayyathā api nāma kṣudraḥ madhu evam āsvādaḥ
translated: They were sweet as pure honey.

original: te vaya bhavanto tā vanalatāmāhāramāharantā tavarṇā tabhakṣā tadāhārā dīrghamadhvāna tiṣṭhema //
analyzed: te vaya bhavantaḥ tā vana latām āhāram āharantā ta varṇā ta bhakṣā tad āhārā dīrgham adhvāna tiṣṭhema
translated: We, Sirs, living on that creeper, having its colour, its smell, its taste, remained for a long time.

original: yato ca sāna kecitpāpakā akuśalā dharmā prajñāyensuḥ yato ca mo bhavanto kecitpāpakā akuśalā dharmā prajñāpayensuḥ atha sā vanalatā antarahāye
analyzed: yatas ca kecid pāpakāḥ akuśalāḥ dharmāḥ prajñāyensuḥ yatas ca mā u bhavanto kecid pāpakāḥ akuśalāḥ dharmāḥ prajñāpayensuḥ atha sā vana latā antarahāye
translated: But when some bad unwholesome states appeared among us, Sirs, then that creeper disappeared.

original: śāli akaṇa atuṣa surabhitaṇḍulaphala prādurbhaveyā //
analyzed: śāli a kaṇa a tuṣa surabhi taṇḍula phala
translated: And rice appeared, without powder or husk, fragrant and clean.

original: sāya lūno so kālya bhavati jāto pakvo virūḍho avadāna pi ca se na prajñāyati //
analyzed: sāya lūnaḥ saḥ kālya bhavati jātaḥ pakvaḥ virūḍhaḥ avadāna ca se na prajñāyati
translated: It was reaped in the evening and by morning it was ripe, and no difference was seen in the ears.

original: te vaya bhavanto ta śāli akaṇa atuṣa surabhitaṇḍulaphala āhāramāharantā tavarṇā tabhakṣā tadāhārā cira dīrghamadhvāna hi tiṣṭhema
analyzed: te vaya bhavanta āhāram āharantā ta varṇā ta bhakṣā tad āhārā cira dīrgham adhvāna hi tiṣṭhema
translated: We, Sirs, living on that rice, having its colour, its smell, its taste, remained for a long time.

original: yato ca sāna kecitpāpakā akuśalā dharmā prajñāyensuḥ atha se śālisya kaṇo ca tuṣo ca paryavanahe //
analyzed: yatas ca kecid pāpakāḥ akuśalāḥ dharmāḥ prajñāyensuḥ atha se śālisya kaṇaḥ ca tuṣaḥ ca
translated: But when some bad unwholesome states appeared among us, then the rice became covered with powder and husk.

original: yo ca sāya lūno so kāsya na jāto na pakvo na virūḍho avadāna pi ca se prajñāyati //
analyzed: yaḥ ca sāya lūnaḥ saḥ kā asya na jātaḥ na pakvaḥ na virūḍhaḥ ca se prajñāyati
translated: And that which was reaped in the evening was not ripe by morning, and the ears were seen.

original: yo pi kāsya lūno so sāya na jāto na pakvo na viruḍho avadāna pi ca se prajñāyati /🔽ya nūna vaya śālikṣetrāṇi vibhajema sīmā nayemaḥ //
analyzed: yaḥ pi kāsya lūnaḥ saḥ sāya na jātaḥ na pakvaḥ na viruḍhaḥ ca se prajñāyati  ya nūna śālikṣetrāṇi vibhajema sīmāḥ nayemaḥ
translated: Whatever was cut down by him did not grow again, was not ripe, and did not sprout. And the harvest was seen to be exhausted.🔽Let us now divide the rice fields and set boundaries.

original: ima bhavantānā śālikṣetra imamasmāka māpayemaḥ //
analyzed: ima śālikṣetre imam asmāka māpayemaḥ
translated: These rice fields are yours, these are ours.

original: atha khalu bhikṣavaste satvāḥ śālikṣetrāṇā sīmā nayensuḥ /
analyzed: atha khalu bhikṣavaḥ te satvāḥ śālikṣetrāṇā sīmāḥ nayensuḥ
translated: Then, monks, those beings set boundaries for the rice fields.

original: ima bhavantānā śālikṣetra imamasmāka //
analyzed: imam śālikṣetre imam asmāka
translated: These rice fields are yours, these are ours.

original: atha khalu bhikṣavaḥ anyatarasya satvasya śālihāra gatasya etadabhavat //
analyzed: atha khalu bhikṣavaḥ anyatarasya satvasya śālihāra gatasya etat abhavat
translated: Then, monks, it occurred to one being who had gone to gather rice,

original: ki sya nāma aha bhaviṣya kena sya nāma jīvita kalpeṣya svake śālibhāge kṣīṇe //
analyzed: ki sya nāma aha bhaviṣya kena sya nāma jīvita kalpeṣya svake śālibhāge kṣīṇe
translated: What will I become? By what means will I be able to make a living? When my share of rice is exhausted.

original: ya nūnāha adinnā anyātaka śālimādiyeya //
analyzed: ya nūna aha adinnā anyātaka śālim ādiyeya
translated: What if I were to steal others' rice that has not been given to me?

original: atha khalu bhikṣavo so satvo svaka śālibhāga parirakṣano adinnamanyātaka śālibhāgamādiyeya //
analyzed: atha khalu bhikṣavaḥ saḥ satvaḥ svaka śāli bhāga parirakṣanaḥ adinnamanyātaka śāli bhāgam ādiyeya
translated: Then, monks, that being, in order to protect his own share of rice, stole others' rice that had not been given to him.

original: adrākṣīdbhikṣavo nyataraḥ satvo ta satvamadinnamanyātaka śāli ādiyanta dṛṣṭvā ca punaryena so satvo tenopasakramitvā ta satvametadavocat
analyzed: adrākṣīt bhikṣavaḥ nyataraḥ satvaḥ ta satvam dṛṣṭvā ca punar yena saḥ satvaḥ tena upasakramitvā ta satvam etat avocat
translated: Monks, another being saw that being taking unowned and unproclaimed rice. Having seen it, he approached that being and said to him:

original: api āma tva bho satva adinnamanyātaka śālimādiyasi //
analyzed: api tva bho satva adinnamanyātaka
translated: Hey, you there, are you taking unowned and unproclaimed rice?

original: evamukte bhikṣavaḥ so satvasta satvametadavocat //
analyzed: evam ukte bhikṣavaḥ saḥ satvaḥ satvam etat avocat
translated: When this was said, monks, that being said to the other being:

original: tena hi bho satva na punareva bhaviṣyati //
analyzed: tena hi bho satva na punar eva bhaviṣyati
translated: Well then, friend, let it not happen again.

original: dvitīya pi bhikṣavastasya satvasya śālihāra gatasya etadabhavat //🔽ki sya nāma aha bhaviṣya kena sya nāma aha jīvikā kalpeṣya svake śālibhāge kṣīṇe //
analyzed: dvitīya pi bhikṣavaḥ tasya satvasya śālihāra gatasya etat abhavat  ki sya nāma aha bhaviṣya kena sya nāma aha jīvikā svake śālibhāge kṣīṇe
translated: Monks, for a second time, when that being went to take rice, this thought occurred to him:🔽What will I become? By what means will I make a living when my share of rice is exhausted?

original: ya nūnāha adinnamanyātaka śālimādiyeya //
analyzed: ya nūna aha adinna manyātaka śālim ādiyeya
translated: What if I were to take unowned and unproclaimed rice?

original: dvitīya pi bhikṣavaḥ so satvo svaka śālibhāga parirakṣanto adinnamanyātaka śālimādiyet //
analyzed: dvitīya pi bhikṣavaḥ saḥ satvaḥ svaka śāli bhāga parirakṣantaḥ
translated: Monks, for a second time, that being, while protecting his own share of rice, took unowned and unproclaimed rice.

original: dṛṣṭvā ca punaryena so satvo tenopasakramitvā ta satvametadavocat /
analyzed: dṛṣṭvā ca punar yena saḥ satvaḥ tena upasakramitvā tam satvam etat avocat
translated: Having seen it, he approached that being and said to him:

original: asti nāma tva bho satva yāvadvitīyaka pi adinnamanyātaka śālimādiyasi //
analyzed: asti nāma tva bho satva yāvadvitīyaka
translated: ‘You, sir, are a being who has taken unowned and unallotted rice.’

original: dvitīya pi bhikṣavaḥ so satvo ta satvametadavocat //
analyzed: bhikṣavaḥ saḥ satvaḥ satvam etat avocat
translated: For a second time, monks, that being said to that being,

original: tena hi bho satva na punareva bhaviṣyati //
analyzed: tena hi bho satva na punar eva bhaviṣyati
translated: ‘Well then, sir, let there be no more of it.’

original: tṛtīyaka pi bhikṣavaḥ tasya satvasya śālihāra gatasyaitadabhavat //
analyzed: tṛtīyaka pi bhikṣavaḥ tasya satvasya śālihāra gatasya etat abhavat
translated: For a third time, monks, when that being had gone to gather rice, he thought,

original: ki sya nāma aha bhaviṣya kena sya nāma jīvikā kalpayiṣya svake śālibhāge kṣīṇe //
analyzed: ki sya nāma aha bhaviṣya kena sya nāma jīvikā kalpayiṣya svake śālibhāge kṣīṇe
translated: ‘What will become of me? How shall I manage to live? When my share of the rice is exhausted,

original: ya nūnāhamadinnamanyātaka śālimādiyeya //🔽tṛtīyaka pi bhikṣavaḥ so satvo svaka śālibhāga parirakṣanto adinnamanyātaka śālimādiyati //
analyzed: ya nūna aham adinna manyātaka śālim ādiyeya  tṛtīyaka pi bhikṣavaḥ saḥ satvaḥ svaka śāli bhāga parirakṣantaḥ
translated: what if I were to take unowned and unallotted rice?’🔽For a third time, monks, that being, while guarding his own share of rice, took unowned and unallotted rice.

original: adrākṣīdbhikṣavaḥ so satvo ta satva tṛtīyaka pi adinnamanyātaka śālimādiyanta //
analyzed: adrākṣīt bhikṣavaḥ saḥ satvaḥ satva tṛtīyaka
translated: Monks, that being saw that being for a third time taking unowned and unallotted rice.

original: dṛṣṭvā ca punaryena so satvo tenapusakramitvā ta satva daṇḍena paritāḍayanto emāha /
analyzed: dṛṣṭvā ca punar yena saḥ satvaḥ tena pusa kramitvā ta satva daṇḍena
translated: And having seen him, he went up to him, and, striking him with a stick, said,

original: 'sti nāma tva bho satva yāvattṛtīyaka pi adinnamanyātaka śālimādiyasi //
analyzed: sti nāma tva bho satva yāvat tṛtīyaka
translated: ‘You, sir, are a being who has taken unowned and unallotted rice for a third time.’

original: atha khalu bhikṣavaḥ so satvo ubhau bāhā pragṛhya vikrande vikrośe //
analyzed: atha khalu bhikṣavaḥ saḥ satvaḥ ubhau bāhau pragṛhya vikrande vikrośe
translated: Then, monks, that being, stretching out both arms, wailed and cried out:

original: adharmo bhavanto loke prādurbhūtaḥ asaddharmo loke prādurbhūtaḥ yatra nāma loke daṇḍādāna prajñāyati //
analyzed: adharmaḥ bhavantaḥ loke prādurbhūtaḥ asat dharmaḥ loke prādurbhūtaḥ yatra nāma loke prajñāyati
translated: ‘Unrighteousness, good sirs, has appeared in the world, evil has appeared in the world, since in the world the taking up of a stick is seen.’

original: atha khalu bhikṣavaḥ so satvo pṛthivīya daṇḍamāveṣṭitvā ubhau bāhū pragṛhya vikrande vikrośe //
analyzed: atha khalu bhikṣavaḥ saḥ satvaḥ pṛthivīya daṇḍam āveṣṭitvā ubhau bāhū pragṛhya vikrande vikrośe
translated: Then, monks, that being, taking a stick from the earth, stretching out both arms, wailed and cried out:

original: adharmo bhavanto loke prādurbhūto asaddharmo bhavanto loke prādurbhūtaḥ yatra hi nāma adinnādāna ca mṛṣavāda ca loke prajñāyati //
analyzed: adharmaḥ bhavantaḥ loke prādurbhūtaḥ asat dharmaḥ bhavantaḥ loke prādurbhūtaḥ yatra hi nāma adinnādāna ca mṛṣavāda ca loke prajñāyati
translated: ‘Unrighteousness, good sirs, has appeared in the world, evil has appeared in the world, since in the world the taking up of a stick and the taking up of what was not given and lying are seen.’🔽And so, monks, these three evil and unwholesome things appeared in the world for the first time, namely, the taking up of a stick, lying and the taking up of what was not given.

original: eva ca punarbhikṣavaḥ imeṣā trayāṇā pāpakānā akuśalānā dharmāṇā prathama evameva loke prādurbhāvo tadyathādinnādānasya mṛṣāvādasya daṇḍādānasya 🔽ca //
analyzed: eva ca punar bhikṣavaḥ imeṣā trayāṇā pāpakānā akuśalānā dharmāṇā prathamaḥ evam eva loke tat yathā dinna ādānasya mṛṣāvādasya daṇḍa ādānasya  ca
translated: And so, monks, these three evil and unwholesome things appeared in the world for the first time, namely, the taking up of a stick, lying and the taking up of what was not given.

original: atha khalu bhkṣaḥ te satvā sadhāvensuḥ sanipatensuḥ sadhāvitvā sanipatitvā samantrensuḥ //
analyzed: atha khalu bhkṣaḥ te satvā sadhāvensuḥ sanipatensuḥ sadhāvitvā sanipatitvā samantrensuḥ
translated: Then, monks, those beings assembled, gathered together and lamented:🔽‘Alas! Alas! Evil has appeared in the world, evil has appeared in the world, since in the world the taking up of a stick and the taking up of what was not given and lying are seen.’

original: ya nūna vaya bhavanto yo asmāka satvo sarvaprāsādiko sarvamaheśākhyo ca ta samanyemaḥ yo asmāka nigrahāraha ca nigṛhlīyā pragrhāraha
analyzed: ya nūna vaya bhavantaḥ yaḥ asmāka satvaḥ sarva prāsādikaḥ sarva maheśākhyaḥ ca ta samanyemaḥ yaḥ asmāka ca
translated: Let us, sirs, agree upon that one among us who is the most handsome, the most majestic, and the most worthy, and let him punish those who deserve punishment and reward those who deserve rewards.

original: ca pragṛhleyā deśaye cāya svakasvakeṣu śālikṣetreṣu śālibhāga //
analyzed: ca svaka svakeṣu śāli kṣetreṣu śālibhāga
translated: Let us now, sirs, elect that being who is the most handsome and most majestic among us, who will punish those who deserve punishment and reward those who deserve reward, and who will distribute the shares of rice in our respective rice fields.

original: atha khalu bhikṣavaḥ te satvā yo sāna satvo abhūṣi sarvaprāsādiko ca sarvamaheśākhyo ca ta samanyensuḥ //
analyzed: atha khalu bhikṣavaḥ te satvāḥ ca sarva maheśākhyaḥ ca
translated: Then, monks, those beings elected that being who was the most handsome and most majestic among them,

original: bhavānasmāka satva nigrahāraha ca nigṛhlātu pragrahāraha ca pragṛhlātu vaya te sarvasatvānā agratāye samanyema svakasvakeṣu śālikṣetreṣu
analyzed: bhavān asmāka satva nigrahāraha ca nigṛhlātu pragrahāraha ca pragṛhlātu vaya te sarva satvānā agratāye samanyema svaka svakeṣu śāli kṣetreṣu
translated: saying, You, sir, punish those who deserve punishment and reward those who deserve reward, and we all elect you as the foremost of all beings in our respective rice fields,

original: ṣaṣṭha śālibhāga dadāma //🔽mahatā janakāyena samato ti mahāsammato ti sajñā udapāsi /
analyzed: ṣaṣṭha śālibhāga dadāma  mahatā jana kāyena samataḥ ti mahā sammataḥ ti sajñā udapāsi
translated: and we will give you a sixth of the rice.

original: arahati śālikṣetreṣu śālibhāge ti rājā ti sajñā udapāsi /🔽samyak rakṣati paripāleti mūrdhnābhiṣiktāḥ //
analyzed: arahati śāli kṣetreṣu śālibhāge ti rājā ti sajñā udapāsi  samyak rakṣati paripāla iti mūrdhnā abhiṣiktāḥ
translated: And because he was elected by the great multitude, he came to be known as Mahāsammata, and because he was worthy of receiving a share of rice in the rice fields, he came to be known as King.

original: sajñā udapāsi /
analyzed: sajñāḥ udapāsi
translated: He was anointed on the head by the people.🔽He was worthy of receiving a share of rice in the rice fields.🔽 And because he was anointed on the head by the people, he came to be known as King.🔽He was worthy of receiving a share of rice in the rice fields.🔽 And because he was anointed on the head by the people, he came to be known as King.

original: mātāpitṛsamo naigamajānapadeṣu tti jānapadasthāmavīryaprāpto ti sajñā usapāsi //
analyzed: mātā pitṛ samaḥ naigama jānapadeṣu tti jānapada sthāma vīrya prāptaḥ ti sajñāḥ
translated: He was like a father and mother to the people of the towns and the provinces, and so he was known as Janaka, the one who gained strength and power in the provinces.

original: tenāha rājā kṣatriyo mūrdhnābhiṣikto janapadasthāmavīryaprāpto ti //
analyzed: tena āha rājā kṣatriyaḥ mūrdhnā abhiṣiktaḥ janapada sthāma vīrya prāptaḥ ti
translated: Thus it is said that the king, the anointed Kshatriya, gained strength and power in the provinces.

original: rājño sammatasya putro kalyāṇo kalyāṇasya putro ravo ravasya putro upoṣadho upoṣadhasya putro rājā māndhāto //
analyzed: rājñaḥ sammatasya putro kalyāṇaḥ kalyāṇasya putraḥ ravaḥ ravasya putraḥ upoṣadhaḥ upoṣadhasya putraḥ rājā māndhātaḥ
translated: The son of King Sammata was Kalyana, the son of Kalyana was Rava, the son of Rava was Uposhadha, and the son of Uposhadha was King Mandhata.

original: rājño māndhātasya putrapautrikāyo naptapranaptikāyo bahūni rājasahasrāṇi /
analyzed: rājñaḥ māndhātasya putra pautrikāyaḥ napta pranaptikāyaḥ bahūni rāja sahasrāṇi
translated: King Mandhata had many thousands of sons, grandsons, great-grandsons, and great-great-grandsons.

original: paścimako śākete mahānagare sujāto nāma ikṣākurājā abhūṣi //
analyzed: paścimakaḥ śākete mahā nagare sujātaḥ nāma ikṣāku rājā
translated: The last of them was King Sujata of the Ikshvaku dynasty in the great city of Saketa.

original: sujātasya khalu ikṣākurājño paca putrā abhūṣi opuro nipuro karakaṇḍako ulkāmukho hastikaśīrṣo /
analyzed: sujātasya khalu ikṣāku rājñaḥ paca putrāḥ opuraḥ nipuraḥ karakaṇḍakaḥ ulkāmukhaḥ hastikaśīrṣaḥ
translated: King Sujata of the Ikshvaku dynasty had five sons: Opara, Nipara, Karakandaka, Ulkamukha, and Hastikasirsha.

original: paca ca dhītaro kumāriyo śuddhā vimalā vijitā jalā jalī //
analyzed: paca ca dhītaraḥ kumāriyo śuddhā vimalā vijitā
translated: He also had five daughters: Shuddha, Vimal, Vijita, Jala, and Jali.

original: jento nāma kumāro vailāsikāye putro //
analyzed: jentaḥ nāma kumāraḥ putraḥ
translated: Prince Jenta was the son of a courtesan.

original: tasya mātā jentī nāma //🔽tāye rājā sujāto strīdharmeṇa ārādhito /
analyzed: tasya mātā jentī nāma  rājā su jātaḥ strī dharmeṇa ārādhitaḥ
translated: His mother was named Jenti.🔽She pleased King Sujata with her feminine wiles.

original: tasya rājā prīto savṛtto //
analyzed: tasya rājā prītaḥ sa vṛttaḥ
translated: The king was pleased with her conduct.

original: prītena rājñā jentī vareṇa pravāritā //
analyzed: prītena rājñā jentī vareṇa pravāritā
translated: and the king, being pleased, granted her a boon.

original: jentī vareṇa pravāremi /
analyzed: jentī vareṇa pravāremi
translated: Jentī said, “I choose a boon from the king.

original: ya me vara yācasi ta te vara dadāmi //
analyzed: ya me vara yācasi ta te vara dadāmi
translated: Whatever boon you ask of me, I will grant it to you.”

original: sā dāni āha //
analyzed: sā dāni āha
translated: She said,

original: mahārāja yāvatā khu mātāpitara āpṛcchāmi tato devasya sakāśāto vara yāciṣyāmi //
analyzed: mahā rāja yāvatā khu mātā pitaraḥ āpṛcchāmi tatas devasya sakāśātas vara yāciṣyāmi
translated: “Great king, since I must ask my parents, then I will ask for a boon from the king.”

original: tāye mātāpitṛṇā ārocita //
analyzed: mātā pitṛṇau ārocita
translated: She then informed her parents,🔽“The king has granted me a boon. Tell me, what boon shall I ask of the king?”

original: rājñāha vareṇa pravāritā tadyuṣmāka ki varamucyati ki rājño vara yācāmi //🔽tehi dāni yasya ya mata so ta jalpati //
analyzed: rājñā āha vareṇa pravāritā tat yuṣmāka ki varam ucyati ki rājñaḥ vara yācāmi  tehi dāni yasya ya mata saḥ ta jalpati
translated: They said,

original: grāmavara yācāhi tti //
analyzed: grāma vara yācāhi tti
translated: “Ask for a boon of a village.”

original: tarhi aparā parivrājikā paṇḍitā nipuṇā medhāvinī //
analyzed: tarhi aparā parivrājikā paṇḍitā nipuṇā medhāvinī
translated: Then another female ascetic, who was wise, clever, and intelligent,

original: sā āha //
analyzed: sā āha
translated: said,

original: jenti tva vailāsikāye dhītā tava putro na nicitpaitṛkasya dravyasya prabhavati ki puna rājyasya //
analyzed: dhītā tava putraḥ na nicit paitṛkasya dravyasya prabhavati ki punar rājyasya
translated: “Jentī, you are the daughter of a courtesan. Your son will not be able to inherit his grandfather’s wealth, let alone the kingdom.

original: ete paca kumārā kṣatriyakanyāputrāḥ te paitṛkasya rājyasya ca dravyasya ca prabhavanti //
analyzed: ete paca kumārā kṣatriya kanyā putrāḥ te paitṛkasya rājyasya ca dravyasya ca prabhavanti
translated: But these five princes, the sons of a kṣatriya princess, will be able to inherit their grandfather’s kingdom and wealth.”

original: tva ca rājñā vareṇa pravāritā rājā ca sujāto aprativacano satyavādī yathāvādī tathākārī ta tuva rājño vara yācāhi //
analyzed: tva ca rājñā vareṇa pravāritā rājā ca sujātaḥ aprativacanaḥ satya vādī yathāvādī tathākārī ta tuva rājñaḥ vara yācāhi
translated: You have been granted a boon by the king, and King Sujata is one who cannot be refused, who is truthful, who does as he says, so ask for a boon from the king.

original: ete paca kumārā rājyāto vipravāsetvā mama mutra jenta kumāra yuvarājye abhiṣicāhīti //
analyzed: ete paca kumārāḥ rājyātaḥ mama mutra jenta kumāra yuvarājye abhiṣicāhi iti
translated: Banish these five princes from the kingdom and anoint my son Jenta as crown prince.'

original: eṣa devasya atyayena śākete mahānagare rājā bhaviṣyatīi //
analyzed: eṣa devasya atyayena śākete mahā nagare rājā bhaviṣyati ii
translated: 'He will be king in the great city of Shakala after your majesty's demise.'

original: tato tava sarva eva bhaviṣyati //
analyzed: tatas tava sarvaḥ eva bhaviṣyati
translated: 'Then it will all be yours.'

original: tāye rājā sujāto eva vara yācito //
analyzed: rājā sujātaḥ eva vara yācitaḥ
translated: So she asked for the boon from King Sujata.

original: mahārāja etā paca kumārā rājyāto vipravāsetvā jenta kumāra yuvarājye abhiṣicāhi /
analyzed: mahā rāja etā paca kumārā rājyātaḥ jenta kumāra yuvarājye abhiṣicāhi
translated: 'Great king, banish these five princes from the kingdom and anoint my son Jenta as crown prince.

original: athaiṣo devasya atyayena śākete mahānagare rājā bhaveya //
analyzed: atha eṣaḥ devasya atyayena śākete mahā nagare rājā bhaveya
translated: Then after your majesty's demise, he will be king in the great city of Shakala.

original: eta me vara detu rājā //
analyzed: eta me vara detu rājā
translated: Let the king grant me this boon.'

original: sujāto śrutvā durmanā savṛtto teṣā kumārāṇā premnena na ca śakya vara dattvā anyathā kartu //
analyzed: sujātaḥ śrutvā durmanāḥ sa vṛttaḥ teṣām kumārāṇām premnena na ca śakya vara dattvā anyathā kartu
translated: When Sujata heard this, he became distressed. Out of love for those princes, he could not give the boon and then act otherwise.

original: rājā jentīye devīye āha //
analyzed: rājā jentīye devīye āha
translated: The king said to Queen Jentī:

original: evamastu dinna kumāra vailāsikāye putra yuvarājye abhiṣiciṣyatīti //
analyzed: evam astu dinna kumāra vailāsika āye putra yuvarājye abhiṣiciṣyati iti
translated: 'So be it. I will give the boon to Prince Jenta and anoint him as crown prince.'

original: tatra janakāye utkaṇṭho kumārāṇā guṇamāhātmyena yā kumārāṇā gatiḥ sā asmāka gatiḥ //
analyzed: tatra jana kāye utkaṇṭhaḥ kumārāṇā guṇa māhātmyena yā kumārāṇā gatiḥ sā asmāka gatiḥ
translated: There the people were eager, because of the greatness of the virtues of the princes, and said: “Whatever may be the fate of the princes, that will be our fate.”

original: rājñā sujātena śruta mahājanakāyo śāketāto janapadāto kumārehi sārdha vipravasiṣyanti iti //
analyzed: rājñā sujātena śruta mahā jana kāyaḥ śāketātaḥ janapadātaḥ kumārehi sārdha vipravasiṣyanti iti
translated: King Sujāta heard that a great crowd of people would leave Śāketa with the princes.

original: tena śākete mahānagare ghoṣaṇā kārāpitā //
analyzed: tena śākete mahā nagare ghoṣaṇā kārāpitā
translated: He had an announcement made in the great city of Śāketa:

original: yo kumārehi saha śāketāto vipravasiṣyati tasya yena kārya ta rājakṛtyā kośāto dīṣyati //
analyzed: yaḥ kumārehi saha śāketa atas vipravasiṣyati tasya yena kārya rāja kṛtyā kośātaḥ
translated: “Whoever will leave Śāketa with the princes, whatever he needs will be given to him from the royal treasury.”

original: yeṣā hastihi kārya aśvehi rathehi vā yugyehi vā yānehi vā śakaṭehi vā pravahaṇehi vā balivardehi vā masniyehi vā ajehi vā eḍakehi vā dhanehi
analyzed: rathehi vā yugyehi vā yānehi vā śakaṭehi vā pravahaṇehi vā balivardehi vā masniyehi vā ajehi vā eḍakehi vā dhanehi  /
translated: For those who needed elephants, horses, chariots, carriages, vehicles, carts, boats, oxen, sheep, goats,

original: vā cānyena vā vastreṇa vā ala kārehi vā dāsehi vā dāsīhi vā ta sarva rājakṛtyā kośāto dīṣyati //
analyzed: vā ca anyena vā vastreṇa vā ala kārehi vā dāsehi vā dāsīhi vā ta sarva rājakṛtyā kośātaḥ dīṣyati
translated: or any other goods, clothes, ornaments, male or female slaves, all of that was given to them from the royal treasury.

original: kumārehi sārdha vipravasantānā rājāṇattīye amātyehi eva kośakoṣṭhāgārā mukta yo ya yācati tasya ta dīyati eva te kumārā śāketāto anekehi
analyzed: kumārehi sārdha rājāṇattīye amātyehi eva kośa koṣṭhāgārāḥ yaḥ ya yācati tasya ta dīyati eva te kumārā anekehi  /
translated: Those who were leaving with the princes, by the king's order, the ministers opened the treasuries and storehouses. Whatever anyone asked for, that was given to him. Thus those princes left Śāketa with many

original: jānapadasahasrehi sārdha mahatā balakāyena anekehi śakaṭayugyayānasahasrehi śāketāto nagarāto niryātā uttarāmukha prayātā //
analyzed: jānapada sahasrehi sārdha mahatā balakāyena anekehi śakaṭa yugya yāna sahasrehi śāketātaḥ nagarātaḥ niryātā uttarā mukha prayātā
translated: He set out from the city of Śāketa with a great army of thousands of people from the provinces, with many thousands of carts and carriages, and went north.

original: kāśikośaleana rājñā pragṛhītā //
analyzed: rājñā pragṛhītā
translated: He was seized by the king of Kāśi and Kośala.

original: kumārā kṛtapuṇyā ca maheśākhyā ca nivātā ca sukhasasparśā ca puṇyavantā ca dhārmikā ca /
analyzed: kumārā kṛta puṇyā ca maheśākhyā ca nivātā ca sukha sasparśā ca puṇyavantā ca dhārmikā ca
translated: The princes were virtuous, of great power, peaceful, pleasant to the touch, meritorious, and righteous.

original: teṣā sarva kāśikośalakā manuṣyā mūlāto prītā //
analyzed: teṣām sarva kāśi kośalakāḥ manuṣyāḥ prītāḥ
translated: All the people of Kāśi and Kośala were delighted from the root.

original: aho yāva kalyāṇā kumārā dhārmikā ca //
analyzed: aho kalyāṇā kumārā dhārmikā ca
translated: Oh, how virtuous and righteous the princes are!

original: tasya rājño yathokta bhagavatā śakrapraśneṣu //
analyzed: tasya rājñaḥ yathā ukta bhagavatā śakra praśneṣu
translated: As it was said by the Blessed One in the Questions of Śakra:

original: īrṣyāmātsaryasayojanasaprayuktā devamanuṣyā asurā garuḍā gandharvā yakṣā rākṣasā piśācā kumbhāṇḍā ye vā punaranye santi pṛthukāyāḥ //
analyzed: īrṣyā mātsarya sayojana sa prayuktāḥ deva manuṣyāḥ asurāḥ garuḍāḥ gandharvāḥ yakṣāḥ rākṣasāḥ piśācāḥ kumbhāṇḍāḥ ye vā punar anye santi pṛthu kāyāḥ
translated: Gods, humans, asuras, garuḍas, gandharvas, yakṣas, rākṣasas, piśācas, kumbhāṇḍas, and whatever other beings there are with various bodies, are bound by envy and stinginess.

original: tasya kāśikośalarājño īrṣyādharma savṛtta //
analyzed: tasya kāśi kośala rājñaḥ īrṣyā dharma savṛtta
translated: For that king of Kāśi and Kośala, the quality of envy arose.

original: yathaiva eṣo janakāyo imeṣā kumārāṇā guṇagṛhīto sthānametadvidyati ya ete mama jīvitāto vyaparopetvā ato kumārā rājye abhiṣicensu //
analyzed: yathā eva eṣaḥ jana kāyaḥ kumārāṇā guṇa gṛhītaḥ sthānam etat vidyati ye ete mama jīvitātaḥ vyaparopetvā atas kumārāḥ rājye abhiṣicensu
translated: Just as this multitude of people is captivated by the qualities of these princes, it is possible that they will deprive me of my life and consecrate the princes in the kingdom.

original: te dāni tenāpi kāśikośalena rājñā vipravāsitā //
analyzed: te dāni tena api kāśikośalena rājñā vipravāsitā
translated: They were banished by the king of Kāśi and Kośala.

original: anuhimavante kapilo nāma ṛṣiḥ prativasati pacābhijño caturdhyānalābhī maharddhiko mahānubhāvo //
analyzed: anu himavante kapilaḥ nāma ṛṣiḥ prativasati catur dhyāna lābhī maharddhikaḥ mahā anubhāvaḥ
translated: In the Himalayas there lived a seer named Kapila, who possessed the five superknowledges, had attained the four meditations, and was of great magic and power.

original: tasya ta āśramapada mahāvistīrṇa ramaṇīya mūlapuṣpopeta patropeta phalopeta pānīyopeta mūlasahasra upaśobhita maha cātra śākoṭavanakhaṇḍa
analyzed: tasya te āśrama pada mahā vistīrṇa ramaṇīya mūla puṣpa upeta patra upeta phala upeta pānīya upeta mūla sahasre upaśobhita ca atra śākoṭa vana khaṇḍa
translated: His hermitage was large, delightful, and well supplied with roots, flowers, leaves, fruits, and water. It was adorned with a thousand trees and was a great forest grove of śākoṭa trees.

original: te dāni kumārā tahi pi śākoṭavanakhaṇḍe āvāsitā //
analyzed: te dāni kumārā tahi pi śākoṭa vanakhaṇḍe āvāsitā
translated: The princes lived in that śākoṭa forest grove.

original: tatra samanukrāntā vāṇijakā kāśikośalā janapadā gacchanti va //
analyzed: tatra samanukrāntāḥ kāśi kośalāḥ janapadāḥ gacchanti
translated: Some merchants from the country of Kāśi and Kośala came that way.

original: te vāṇijakā janena pṛcchīyanti kuto āgacchatha tti //
analyzed: te vāṇijakāḥ janena pṛcchīyanti kutas āgacchatha tti
translated: The merchants were asked, “Where do you come from?”

original: te āhansuḥ /
analyzed: te āhansuḥ
translated: They replied,

original: amukāto śākoṭavanakhaṇḍāto //
analyzed: amukātaḥ śākoṭa vanakhaṇḍātaḥ
translated: “From the śākoṭa forest grove.”

original: śāketā api kośalā vāṇijakā tahi pi gacchanti śākoṭavanakhaṇḍe //
analyzed: śāketāḥ api gacchanti śākoṭa vanakhaṇḍe
translated: The merchants from Śākya and Kośala also went to the śākoṭa forest grove.

original: te pi pṛcchīyanti //
analyzed: te pi pṛcchīyanti
translated: They were asked,

original: kahi gamiṣyatha tti //
analyzed: kahi gamiṣyatha tti
translated: “Where are you going?”

original: te pi āhansuḥ //
analyzed: te pi āhansuḥ
translated: They replied,

original: śākoṭavanakhaṇḍa anuhimavanta //
analyzed: śākoṭa vanakhaṇḍa anu himavanta
translated: “To the śākoṭa forest grove in the Himalayas.”

original: tehi dāni kumārehi mā mo jātisadoṣa bhaviṣyatīti jātisadoṣabhayena svakasvakā yeva mātṛyo bhaginīyo parasparasya vivāhitā //
analyzed: tehi dāni kumārehi mā mā u jāti sa doṣa bhaviṣyati iti jāti sa doṣa bhayena svaka svakāḥ yā iva mātṛyaḥ parasparasya vivāhitā
translated: But the princes, fearing the reproach of inbreeding, married their own sisters, the daughters of their mothers, each to the other.

original: rājā sujāto amātyānā pṛcchati //
analyzed: rājā sujātaḥ amātyānā pṛcchati
translated: King Sujāta asked his ministers,

original: bho amātyā kumārā kahi āvasanti //
analyzed: bho amātyā kumārā kahi āvasanti
translated: “Ministers, where do the princes live?”

original: amātyā āhansuḥ //
analyzed: amātyāḥ āhansuḥ
translated: The ministers replied,

original: mahārāja anuhimavante mahāśākoṭakavanakhaṇḍa tahi kumārā prativasanti //
analyzed: mahā rāja anu himavante kumārā prativasanti
translated: “Great king, the princes live in the great Śākoṭa forest in the Himalayas.”

original: rājā amātyānā pṛcchati //
analyzed: rājā amātyānā pṛcchati
translated: The king asked his ministers,

original: kuto kumārehi dārāṇi ānītāni //
analyzed: kutas kumārehi dārāṇi ānītāni
translated: “Where did the princes get their wives from?”

original: amātyā āhansuḥ //
analyzed: amātyāḥ āhansuḥ
translated: The ministers replied,

original: śruta mo mahārāja kumārehī jātisadoṣabhayena svakasvakā yeva mātṛyo bhaginīyo parasparasya vivāhitāyo mā mo jātisadoṣa bhaviṣyatīti //
analyzed: śruta mā u mahā rāja jāti sa doṣa bhayena svaka svakāḥ yā iva mātṛyaḥ bhaginīyaḥ parasparasya bhaviṣyati iti
translated: “We have heard, great king, that the princes, fearing the reproach of inbreeding, married their own sisters, the daughters of their mothers, each to the other, so that there would be no reproach of inbreeding.”

original: rājñā dāni sujātena purohito ca anye ca brāhmaṇapaṇḍitā pṛcchitā //
analyzed: rājñā dāni sujātena purohito ca anye ca brāhmaṇa paṇḍitā pṛcchitā
translated: Then King Sujāta asked his priest and other learned brahmins,

original: śakyā etameva kartu yathā tehi kumārehi kṛta //
analyzed: śakyāḥ etam eva kartu yathā tehi kumārehi kṛta
translated: “Can this be done as it was done by those princes?”🔽The learned brahmins headed by the priest replied,

original: te purohitapramukhā brāhmaṇapaṇḍitā āhansuḥ //
analyzed: te purohita pramukhāḥ brāhmaṇa paṇḍitāḥ āhansuḥ
translated: The wise brāhmans, headed by the priest, said:

original: śakya mahārāja kumārā tato nidāna doṣeṇa na lipyanti //
analyzed: śakya mahā rāja kumārā tatas nidāna doṣeṇa na lipyanti
translated: It is possible, Your Majesty, that the princes will not be tainted by that fault.”

original: rājā sujāto brāhmaṇapaṇḍitānā śrutvā hṛṣṭo tuṣṭo āttamanā ima udānamudānaye //
analyzed: rājā su jātaḥ brāhmaṇa paṇḍitānā śrutvā hṛṣṭaḥ tuṣṭaḥ ātta manāḥ ime udānam udānaye
translated: When King Sujāta heard the words of the wise brahmins, he was delighted, pleased, and overjoyed, and he exclaimed:

original: śakyā punarbhavanto kumārā //
analyzed: śakyā punarbhavanto kumārā
translated: “It is possible, my princes,

original: teṣā dāni kamārāṇā śakya śākiyā ti samākhyāsamājñāprajñapti udapāsi //
analyzed: teṣām dāni kamārāṇām śakya śākiya ti samākhyā samājñā prajñapti
translated: and so the name Śākya, Śākya, Śākya, was given, known, and announced to those princes.

original: teṣā dāni kumārāṇā etadabhavat /
analyzed: teṣām dāni kumārāṇām etat abhavat
translated: Then those princes thought:

original: kevattaka vaya iha śākoṭakavanakhaṇḍe nivāsa kalpeṣyāmaḥ /
analyzed: kevattaka vayaḥ iha śākoṭaka vana khaṇḍe nivāsa kalpeṣyāmaḥ
translated: “How long will we live in this Śāketa forest grove?

original: mahāśca aya janakāyo āgacchati //
analyzed: mahāḥ ca jana kāyaḥ āgacchati
translated: And this great crowd of people is coming.

original: ya nūna vaya nagara māpayemaḥ //
analyzed: ya nūna vaya nagara māpayemaḥ
translated: What if we were to found a city?”

original: te dāni kumārā kapilasya ṛṣisya sakāśa sakrāntā //
analyzed: te dāni kumārā kapilasya ṛṣisya sakāśa sakrāntā
translated: And those princes, having gone to the sage Kapila,

original: te ṛṣisya pādau vanditvā āhansuḥ //
analyzed: te ṛṣisya pādau vanditvā āhansuḥ
translated: bowed their heads at the sage’s feet and said:

original: yadi bhagavā kapilo anujāneyyā vaya imasmi nagara māpayemaḥ ṛṣisya nāmena kapilavastu //
analyzed: yadi bhagavā kapilaḥ nagara māpayemaḥ ṛṣisya nāmena kapilavastu
translated: “If the Blessed One Kapila would allow us, we would found a city here, and name it Kapilavastu after the sage.”

original: ṛṣi āha //
analyzed: ṛṣi āha
translated: The sage said:

original: yadi mama idamāśrama rā jakula kṛtvā nagara māpetha tato anujānāmi //
analyzed: yadi mama tatas anujānāmi
translated: “If you make this my hermitage a royal residence and found a city, then I allow it.”🔽The princes said to the sage:

original: te kumārā ṛṣisya āhansuḥ //
analyzed: te kumārāḥ ṛṣisyaḥ āhansuḥ
translated: The princes said to the seer:🔽

original: yathā ṛṣisya abhiprāyo tathā kariṣyāmaḥ //
analyzed: yathā ṛṣisya abhiprāyo tathā kariṣyāmaḥ
translated: We will do as the sage intends.”

original: imamāśrama rājakula kṛtvā nagara māpeṣyāmaḥ //
analyzed: imam āśrama rājakula kṛtvā nagara mā āpeṣyāmaḥ
translated: “Let us make this hermitage into a royal palace and build a city here.”

original: ṛṣiṇā ta vastu teṣā kumārāṇā karaka gṛhya udakena dinna //
analyzed: ṛṣiṇā ta vastu teṣām kumārāṇām karaka gṛhya udakena dinna
translated: The sage then took a water pot and gave it to the princes.

original: kumārehi pi ta ṛṣisya āśrama rājakula kṛtvā nagara māpita //
analyzed: kumārehi pi te ṛṣi sya āśrama rājakula kṛtvā nagara māpita
translated: The princes then made the sage’s hermitage into a royal palace and built a city.

original: kapilena ṛṣiṇā vastu dinna ti kapilavastusamākhyā udapāsi //
analyzed: kapilena ṛṣiṇā vastu kapilavastu samākhyā
translated: Since the sage Kapila gave them a place, the name Kapilavastu arose.

original: eva kapilavastumahānagara ṛddho ca sphīto ca kṣemo ca subhikṣo ca ākīrṇajanamanuṣyo ca bahujanamanuṣyo sukhitajanamanuṣyo vistīrṇajanaparivāro
analyzed: eva kapilavastu mahā nagaraḥ ṛddhaḥ ca sphītaḥ ca kṣemaḥ ca subhikṣaḥ ca ākīrṇa jana manuṣyaḥ ca bahu jana manuṣyaḥ sukhita jana manuṣyaḥ vistīrṇa jana parivāraḥ
translated: Thus the great city of Kapilavastu became prosperous, flourishing, secure, well-supplied with food, populous, crowded with people, happy, with an abundance of all things,

original: ca savṛtto diśi vidiśi viśruto ca savṛtto utsavasamājabahulo vaṇijapriyo vyavahārasampanno //
analyzed: ca sa vṛttaḥ diśi vidiśi ca sa vṛttaḥ utsava samāja bahulaḥ vaṇija priyaḥ vyavahāra sampannaḥ
translated: and it was well-known in all directions, full of festivals and gatherings, dear to merchants, and prosperous in commerce.

original: teṣā dāni pacānā kumārāṇā opurasya nipurasya karaṇḍakasya uklāmukhasya hastikaśīrṣasya ca opuro kumāro jyeṣṭho //
analyzed: teṣām dāni pacānā kumārāṇā opurasya nipurasya karaṇḍakasya uklāmukhasya hastikaśīrṣasya ca opuraḥ kumāraḥ jyeṣṭhaḥ
translated: Now among those five princes, Opura, Nipura, Karaṇḍaka, Ukklamukha, and Hastikaśīrṣa, Opura was the eldest.

original: so kapilavastusmi rājye cābhiṣikto //
analyzed: saḥ kapilavastusmi rājye ca abhiṣiktaḥ
translated: He was consecrated as king in the kingdom of Kapilavastu.

original: opurasya rājño putro nipuro nipurasya rājño putro karakaṇḍo karakaṇḍakasya rājño putro ulkāmukho ulkāmukhasya putro hastikaśīrṣo hastikaśīṣasya 🔽putro sihahanuḥ //
analyzed: opurasya rājñaḥ putraḥ nipuraḥ nipurasya rājñaḥ putraḥ karakaṇḍo karakaṇḍakasya rājñaḥ putraḥ ulkāmukhaḥ ulkāmukhasya putraḥ hastikaśīrṣaḥ hastikaśīṣasya  sihahanuḥ
translated: Opuṣa had a son named Nipuṣa, Nipuṣa had a son named Karakaṇḍa, Karakaṇḍa had a son named Ulkāmukha, Ulkāmukha had a son named Hastikaśīrṣa, Hastikaśīrṣa had a son named Siṃhahanu.

original: sihahanusya rājño catvāri putrāḥ śuddhodano dhautodano śuklodano amṛtodano amitā ca nāma dārikā //
analyzed: sihahanusya rājñaḥ catvāri putrāḥ śuddhodanaḥ dhautodanaḥ śuklodanaḥ amṛtodanaḥ amitā ca nāma dārikā
translated: Siṃhahanu had four sons: Śuddhodana, Dhautodana, Śuklodana, and Amṛtodana, and a daughter named Amitā.

original: tahi dāni aparasya śākiyasya mahattarasya dhītā prāsādikā darśanīyā akṣudrāvakāśā paramapuṣkaratayā samanvāgatā tasyā dārikāye kuṣṭhavyādhi 🔽utpannaḥ //
analyzed: tahi dāni aparasya śākiyasya mahattarasya dhītā prāsādikā darśanīyā akṣudra avakāśā parama puṣkara tayā samanvāgatā tasyāḥ dārikāye kuṣṭha vyādhi  utpannaḥ
translated: Now, a certain Śākya elder had a daughter who was lovely, beautiful, with an exquisite and perfect body. This girl contracted leprosy.

original: sā dāni tena kuṣṭhavyādhinā grastā //
analyzed: sā dāni tena kuṣṭha vyādhinā grastā
translated: She was seized by this disease of leprosy.

original: vaidyā ghaṭanti sarvakriyā kriyanti na ca vārttobhavati ālepanapratyālepanāni vamanavirecanāni ca kriyanti na ca kuṣṭhavyādhi praśāmyati //
analyzed: vaidyāḥ ghaṭanti sarva kriyā kriyanti na ca vārttaḥ bhavati ālepana pratyālepanāni vamana virecanāni ca kriyanti na ca kuṣṭha vyādhi praśāmyati
translated: The physicians tried their best, but she did not recover. They tried ointments and counter-ointments, emetics and purges, but the disease of leprosy was not cured.

original: sarva śaīramekavraṇa //
analyzed: sarva śaīram eka vraṇa
translated: All the Śākyas had one and the same disease.

original: sarvasya janasya tā dṛṣṭvā ghṛṇā utpadyati //
analyzed: sarvasya janasya tā dṛṣṭvā ghṛṇā utpadyati
translated: When all the people saw this, they were filled with compassion.

original: sādāni bhrātṛhi yānake ārūpiya anuhimavanta nītā //
analyzed: sādāni bhrātṛhi yānake ārūpiya anuhimavanta nītā
translated: Then they took her in a vehicle to the Himalayas, to the country of the Mallas.

original: tatra utsagaparvate guhā khanāpayitvā sā dārik praveśitā prabhūta ca khādyabhojya udaka ca upastaraṇaprāvaraṇa sthāpetvā guhāye dvāra
analyzed: tatra utsaga parvate guhā khanāpayitvā sā dārik praveśitā prabhūta ca khādya bhojya udaka ca upastaraṇa prāvaraṇa
translated: There, having had a cave dug on the mountain of Utpala, they placed the girl in it, and put in plenty of food and drink, bedding and covering. Having closed the door of the cave

original: suṣṭhu pidhitvā mahāpāśurāśi kṛtvā nagara kapilavastu praviṣṭāḥ //
analyzed: suṣṭhu pidhitvā mahā pāśurāśi kṛtvā nagara kapilavastu praviṣṭāḥ
translated: well, they made a great heap of grass and entered the city of Kapilavastu.

original: tasyā dāni dārikāye tahi guhāye vasantīye tena nivātena ca sarodhena ca tasyā guhāye uṣmeṇa sarva ca kuṣṭhavyādhi visruta śarīra caukṣa
analyzed: tasyāḥ dāni dārikāye tahi guhāye vasantīye tena nivātena ca sa rodhena ca tasyāḥ guhāye uṣmeṇa sarva ca kuṣṭha vyādhi visruta śarīra caukṣa
translated: Now while that girl was living in that cave, by the still air and the closed door, and by the warmth of the cave, all her leprosy was cured. Her body became clean,

original: nirvraṇa savṛtta uttamarūpasajāta nāpi jñāyate mānuṣikā eṣā ti //
analyzed: nirvraṇa uttama rūpa sajāta na api jñāyate
translated: without sores, and of the most excellent and beautiful complexion. It was not known that she was a human being.

original: tahi dāni uddeśe vyāghro paryāhiṇḍanto āgato //
analyzed: tahi dāni uddeśe vyāghraḥ paryāhiṇḍantaḥ āgataḥ
translated: Now a tiger came wandering through that place.

original: ghrāṇaiḥ paśyanti paśavaḥ vedaiḥ paśyanti brāhmaṇāḥ /
analyzed: ghrāṇaiḥ paśyanti paśavaḥ vedaiḥ paśyanti brāhmaṇāḥ
translated: Animals see with their noses, Brahmins see with the Vedas,

original: cāraiḥ paśyanti rājāno cakṣubhyāmitarā prajā iti //
analyzed: cāraiḥ paśyanti rājāno cakṣubhyām itarā prajāḥ iti
translated: kings see with spies, and other people see with their eyes.

original: so dāni vyāghro ta manuṣyagandhamupajighrati //
analyzed: saḥ dāni vyāghraḥ ta manuṣya gandham upajighrati
translated: And that tiger smelled the human scent.

original: tena dāni ta manuṣyagandhamupajighritvā ta mahāpāśurāśi pādehi apakarṣita //
analyzed: tena dāni ta manuṣya gandham upajighritvā ta mahā pāśurāśi pādehi apakarṣita
translated: The lion, smelling the scent of a human being, dragged the heap of flesh with his feet.

original: tatra ca avidūre kālo nāma rājaṛṣiḥ prativasati pacābhijño caturdhyānalābhī //
analyzed: tatra ca avidūre kālaḥ nāma rāja ṛṣiḥ prativasati catur dhyāna lābhī
translated: Not far from there lived a royal seer named Kāla, who possessed the five superknowledges and had attained the four meditations.

original: tasya ta āśramapada mūlopeta patropeta puṣpopeta phalopeta pānīyopeta nānāvṛkṣasampanna ramaṇīya //
analyzed: tasya te āśrama pada mūla upeta patra upeta puṣpa upeta phala upeta pānīya upeta nānā vṛkṣa sampanna ramaṇīya
translated: His hermitage was well-supplied with roots, leaves, flowers, fruits, and water, and was delightful with various trees.

original: so dāni ṛṣi āśramapada anucakramanto anuvicaranto ta deśamāgato yatra sā śākyakanyā guhāya nihitikā //
analyzed: saḥ dāni ṛṣi āśrama pada anucakramantaḥ anuvicarantaḥ ta deśam āgataḥ yatra sā śākya kanyā guhāya nihitikā
translated: As the seer was wandering about and roaming through the hermitage, he came to the place where the Śākya girl was hidden in the cave.

original: tenāpi vyāghreṇa sarva ta pāśurāśi pādena apakarṣita kāṣṭhāvaśeṣa savṛtta //🔽so dāni vyāghro ta ṛṣi dṛṣṭvā osakkito ṛṣiṇā //
analyzed: tena api vyāghreṇa sarva ta pāśurāśi pādena apakarṣita kāṣṭha avaśeṣa sa vṛtta  saḥ dāni vyāghraḥ te ṛṣi dṛṣṭvā osakkitaḥ ṛṣiṇā
translated: The tiger had dragged away the whole heap of flesh with his feet, leaving only the bones.🔽When the tiger saw the seer, he ran away.

original: vyāghreṇa tatpāśu apakarṣitaka dṛṣṭvā ṛṣisya kautūhala sajāta //
analyzed: vyāghreṇa dṛṣṭvā ṛṣisya kautūhala sajāta
translated: Seeing that the tiger had dragged away the heap of flesh, the seer became curious.

original: tena dāni ṛṣiṇā tāni kāṣṭhāni apakarṣitāni tasyā guhāye dvāramapāvṛta //
analyzed: tena dāni ṛṣiṇā tāni kāṣṭhāni apakarṣitāni tasyāḥ dvāram apāvṛta
translated: The seer dragged away the pieces of flesh, and opened the door of the cave.

original: tena śākyakanyā dṛṣṭā uttamavīryeṇa nāpi jñāyati mānuṣikā ti //
analyzed: tena śākya kanyā dṛṣṭā uttama vīryeṇa na api jñāyati
translated: He saw the Śākya girl, and though she was of the highest beauty, he did not recognize her as a human being.🔽The seer asked:

original: eṣo ṛṣi pṛcchati //
analyzed: eṣā u ṛṣi pṛcchati
translated: What are you?

original: bhadre kā tva ti //
analyzed: bhadre kā tva
translated: What are you, my dear?

original: mānuṣikā sā āha //
analyzed: mānuṣikā sā āha
translated: The human woman replied, I am a human woman.

original: aha kapilavastuto amukasya śākyasya dhītā //
analyzed: aha kapilavastutaḥ amukasya śākyasya dhītā
translated: She said, I am the daughter of such-and-such a Shakya from Kapilavastu.

original: sāha kuṣṭhavyādhinā parigatā iha jīvantikā eva vivarjitā //
analyzed: sā āha kuṣṭha vyādhinā parigatā iha jīvantikā eva vivarjitā
translated: She said, I am afflicted with the disease of leprosy. I am alive here, but abandoned.

original: tasya tā śākyakanyā dṛṣṭvā uttamarūpadharā tīvro rāgo prādurbhūtaḥ //
analyzed: tasya tā śākya kanyāḥ dṛṣṭvā uttama rūpa dharā tīvraḥ rāgaḥ prādurbhūtaḥ
translated: When he saw that Shakya maiden, who was endowed with supreme beauty, a strong passion arose in him.

original: kicāpi tāvaccirabrahmacārī na cāsya rāgānuśayo samūhato /
analyzed: tāvat cira brahmacārī na ca asya rāga anuśayaḥ
translated: Even though he had practiced celibacy for so long, the latent tendencies of passion had not been uprooted.

original: puno pi so rāgaviṣo prakupyati tiṣṭha yathā kāṣṭhagata anūhata //
analyzed: punar pi saḥ rāga viṣaḥ prakupyati tiṣṭha yathā kāṣṭha gata
translated: Again, that poison of passion became agitated, Stay as you are, not uprooted like a tree.

original: so dāni rājarṣiḥ tāye śākyakanyāye sārdha sayoga gato dhyānehi ca abhijñāhi ca abhijñāhi ca bhraṣṭo //
analyzed: saḥ dāni rājarṣiḥ tāye śākyaka nyāye sārdha sayoga gataḥ dhyānehi ca abhijñāhi ca abhijñāhi ca bhraṣṭaḥ
translated: Then that royal sage, together with that Shakya maiden, fell from his meditative absorptions and higher knowledges due to his attachment.

original: so dāni tā śākyakanyā gṛhya āśramapada gato //
analyzed: saḥ dāni tā śākya kanyā gṛhye āśrama pada gataḥ
translated: Then he took that Shakya maiden and went to his hermitage.

original: sā dāni śākyakanyā tahi āśramapade kolena rājarṣiṇā sārdha savasati //
analyzed: sā dāni śākya kanyā tahi āśramapade kolena rājarṣiṇā sārdha savasati
translated: And that Shakya maiden lived together with the royal sage Kolita in that hermitage.

original: ṣoḍaśa bālā yamalā putrā prajātā //
analyzed: ṣoḍaśa bālā yamalā putrā prajātā
translated: She gave birth to sixteen twin boys.

original: dvātriśa ṛṣikumārā prāsādikā darśanīyā ajinajaṭādharāḥ //
analyzed: dvātriśas ṛṣi kumārā prāsādikāḥ darśanīyāḥ ajina jaṭā dharāḥ
translated: There were thirty-two young sages, handsome and beautiful, wearing antelope skins and matted hair.

original: te dāni ya kāla vivṛddhā ṛṣikumārā tato mātare kapilavastu visarjitā //
analyzed: te dāni ya kāla vivṛddhāḥ ṛṣi kumārā tatas mātare kapilavastu visarjitā
translated: When they had grown up, they were sent by their mother to Kapilavastu.

original: gacchatha putrā kapilavastu mahānagara amuko nāma śākiyo mama pitā vo mātāmaho /
analyzed: gacchatha putrā kapilavastu mahā nagara amukaḥ nāma śākiyaḥ mama pitā vaḥ mātāmahaḥ
translated: “Go, my sons, to the great city of Kapilavastu. There is a Śākyan named so-and-so, who is your father and my father-in-law.

original: tasya amukasya putrā te vo mātulakā yobhūyena śākyamahattarakā jñātikā mahanto vo kulavaśo //
analyzed: tasya amukasya putrā te vaḥ mātulakāḥ yobhūyena śākya mahattarakāḥ jñātikāḥ mahantaḥ vaḥ
translated: He has a son named so-and-so, who is your uncle. He is a very wealthy Śākyan, and you have a large family connection there.

original: te yuṣmāka vṛtti savidheṣyanti //
analyzed: te yuṣmāka vṛtti savidheṣyanti
translated: They will provide for your livelihood.”

original: tāye śikṣitā yathā śākyānā samudācāra //
analyzed: tāye śikṣitāḥ yathā śākyānā samudācāra
translated: They were taught how to behave among the Śākyans.

original: eva vo śākyapariṣā upasakramitavyā /
analyzed: eva vaḥ śākya pariṣā upasakramitavyā
translated: “Thus are you to approach the assembly of Śākyans.

original: evamabhivādana kartavya /
analyzed: evam abhivādana kartavya
translated: Thus are you to greet them.

original: eva niṣīditavya //
analyzed: eva niṣīditavya
translated: Thus are you to sit down.”

original: sarve śākyasamudācāra sadiśitvā visarjitā //
analyzed: sarve
translated: Having been instructed in all the behaviour of the Śākyans, they were dismissed.

original: te mātāpitṛṇāmabhivādetvā pradakṣiṇa kṛtvā gatā anupūrveṇa kapilavastumanuprāptāḥ //
analyzed: te mātā pitṛṇām abhivādetvā pradakṣiṇa kṛtvā gatāḥ anupūrveṇa kapilavastum anuprāptāḥ
translated: They bowed at the feet of their mother and father, circumambulated them to the right, and departed. In due course they reached Kapilavastu.

original: sarve yathāyuṣkāye paṭipāṭikāy kapilavastu praviśanti /
analyzed: sarve yathā āyuṣkāye kapilavastu praviśanti
translated: All of them entered Kapilavastu in the order of their age.

original: tānṛṣikumārā dṛṣṭvā mahājanakāyo samanvāharati //
analyzed: tān ṛṣi kumārāḥ dṛṣṭvā mahā jana kāyaḥ samanvāharati
translated: When the people saw those young seers, they were impressed.

original: aho yādṛśā ṛṣikumārāḥ prāsādikā darśanīyā ca ajinajaṭādhāriṇo //
analyzed: aho yādṛśāḥ ṛṣi kumārāḥ prāsādikāḥ darśanīyā ca ajina jaṭā dhāriṇaḥ
translated: “Ah! What young seers they are! They are lovely and beautiful, wearing antelope skins and matted hair!”
