original: te dāni mahatā janakāyena parivāritā śākyānā sasthāgāramupasakrāntāḥ //
analyzed: te dāni mahatā jana kāyena parivāritā śākyānā sasthāgāram upasakrāntāḥ
translated: And they, surrounded by a great crowd of people, went to the assembly hall of the Śākyas.

original: pacamātrāṇi ca śākyaśatāni sasthāgāre sanniṣasmāni abhūnsu sanipatitāni kenacideva karaṇīyena //
analyzed: paca mātrāṇi ca śākya śatāni sasthāgāre sanniṣasmāni abhūnsu sanipatitāni kenacid eva karaṇīyena
translated: And just then five hundred Śākyas had assembled in the assembly hall for some business.

original: te dāni yathā tāye mātari sadiṣṭā tena samudācāreṇa śākyapariṣāmupasakrāntā //
analyzed: te dāni yathā tāye mātari sadiṣṭā tena samudācāreṇa śākya pariṣām upasakrāntā
translated: Then, as they had been instructed by their mother, they went to the assembly of the Śākyas with that greeting.

original: śākyapariṣā ṛṣikumārāṇā ta śākyasamudācāra dṛṣṭvā vismitā //
analyzed: śākya pariṣā ṛṣi kumārāṇā te śākya samudācāra dṛṣṭvā vismitā
translated: And when the assembly of the Śākyas saw the greeting of the young seers, they were amazed.

original: tena dāni śākyā ṛṣikumārāṇā pṛcchanti //
analyzed: tena dāni śākyāḥ ṛṣi kumārāṇā pṛcchanti
translated: Then the Śākyas asked the young seers,

original: kuto yūya ti //
analyzed: kutas yūya ti
translated: Where do you come from?

original: tehi ta prakṛti sarva ācikṣita yathā tāye mātari sadiṣṭā //
analyzed: tehi ta prakṛti sarvaḥ ācikṣita yathā tāye mātari sadiṣṭā
translated: They told them the whole story, as they had been instructed by their mother.

original: anuhimavante amukāto āśramapadāto kālasya rājaṛṣisya putrāḥ amukasya śākyasya dhītā sā mo mātā //
analyzed: anu himavante kālasya rāja ṛṣisya putrāḥ amukasya śākyasya dhītā sā mama mātā
translated: We are the sons of Kāla, the royal seer, from the hermitage in the Himalayas, and that is our mother, the daughter of such-and-such a Śākya.

original: yathā sā śākyakanyā tatra uddeśe visarjitā tathā tehi mātuḥ śrutvā śākyānā sarvamācikṣita //
analyzed: yathā sā śākya kanyā tatra uddeśe visarjitā tathā mātuḥ śrutvā śākyānā sarvam ācikṣita
translated: As the Śākya maiden was dismissed in that place, so they heard from their mother and told it all to the Śākyas.

original: śākyā śrutvā prītāḥ //
analyzed: śākyā śrutvā prītāḥ
translated: When the Śākyas heard it, they were delighted.

original: so pi sāna mātāmaho śākyamahattarako jīvati mahānta ca kulavaśa //
analyzed: saḥ pi sāna mātāmahaḥ śākya mahattarakaḥ jīvati
translated: That maternal grandfather of ours, the Śākya elder, is still alive, and his family is very great.

original: so pi kolo rājarṣi vārāṇasīto jyeṣṭhakumāra rājyābhiṣicitvā ṛṣipravajito diśāsu abhijñātaparijñāto mahātmā rājarṣiḥ //
analyzed: saḥ pi kolaḥ rājarṣi vārāṇasī taḥ jyeṣṭha kumāra rājyā abhiṣicitvā ṛṣi pravajitaḥ diśāsu abhijñāta parijñātaḥ mahātmā rājarṣiḥ
translated: Koli, the royal sage, was consecrated as the eldest prince in Benares, and then retired to the forest as a sage. He became a great and famous royal sage in all the regions.

original: te dāni śākyā prītā savṛttāḥ rājarṣiṇā ime jātā na prākṛtena puruṣeṇa //
analyzed: te dāni śākyā prītā savṛttāḥ rājarṣiṇā ime jātāḥ na prākṛtena puruṣeṇa
translated: The Śākyas were delighted and said, These princes are born from a royal sage, not from an ordinary man.

original: teṣā śākyānā bhavati //
analyzed: teṣām śākyānā bhavati
translated: The Śākyas thought:

original: ime kumārā asmāka sujātā pi imeṣā ca śākyakanyā dīyantu vṛttiśca //
analyzed: ime kumārāḥ asmāka sujātā pi imeṣā ca śākya kanyā dīyantu vṛttiḥ ca
translated: These princes are well-born to us. Let this Śākya maiden be given to them and let them have a livelihood.

original: tehi teṣā kumārāṇā śākyakanyāyo ca dinnāyo karṣaṇāni ca dinnāni sajanapadāni /
analyzed: tehi teṣām kumārāṇām ca dinnāyo karṣaṇāni ca dinnāni sa janapadāni
translated: They gave the princes Śākya maidens and gave them fields with villages.

original: tadyathā nāmāśrama nigama sumukta karkarabhadra aparāṇi ca karṣaṇāni sajanapadāni prabhūta svāpateya //
analyzed: tat yathā nāma āśrama nigama sumukta karkarabhadra aparāṇi ca karṣaṇāni sa janapadāni prabhūta svāpateya
translated: Such as the hermitage named Nigama, Sumukta, Karkarabhadra, and other fields with villages, with much wealth.

original: kolena ṛṣiṇā jātā tti koliyā tti samājñā vyāghrāpadyā samājñā ca //
analyzed: kolena ṛṣiṇā jātā tti koliyā tti samājñā vyāghrāpadyā samājñā ca
translated: Because they were born from the sage Koli, they were known as Koliyas, and also by the name of Vyaghrapadī.

original: iti śrīmahāvastu avadāne koliyānāmutpatti samāpta //
analyzed: iti śrī mahāvastu avadāne koliyānām utpatti
translated: Thus ends the origin of the Koliyas in the Mahāvastu-Avadāna.

original: atha śākyānā devaḍaho nāma nigamo //
analyzed: atha śākyānā devaḍahaḥ nāma nigamaḥ
translated: Now there was a town of the Śākyas named Devadaha.

original: tahi subhūtirnāma śākyānā mahattarako tena amukāto nigamāto koliyakanyā nāma bhāryā ānītā //
analyzed: subhūtiḥ nāma śākyānā mahattarakaḥ tena amukātaḥ nigamātaḥ koliyakanyā nāma bhāryā ānītā
translated: Now there was a great Śākyan, named Subhūti, who had brought a wife from a certain town, a Koliyan maiden, named Koliyagrāhikā.

original: tasyā sapta dhītaro jātā māyā mahāmāyā atimāyā anantamāyā cūlīyā kolīsovā mahāprajāpatī //
analyzed: tasyāḥ sapta dhītaraḥ jātāḥ māyā mahāmāyā atimāyā anantamāyā cūlīyā kolīsovā mahāprajāpatī
translated: She had seven daughters, Māyā, Mahāmāyā, Atimāyā, Anantamāyā, Cūlī, Kolī, and Mahāprajāpatī.

original: māyāutpatti //
analyzed: māyā utpatti
translated: The birth of Māyā

original: rājño sihahanusya śākyarājño catvāri putrā dārikā ca ekā śuddhodano śuklodano dhutodano amṛtodano amitā ca dārikā //
analyzed: rājñaḥ sihahanusya śākya rājñaḥ catvāri putrāḥ dārikā ca ekā śuddhodano śuklodanaḥ dhutodanaḥ amṛtodanaḥ amitā ca dārikā
translated: King Siṃhahanu had four sons and one daughter. Śuddhodana, Śuklodana, Dhautodana, Amṛtodana, and the daughter Amitā.

original: rājñā sihahanunā kālagatena śuddhodanena rājya pratilabdha //
analyzed: rājñā sihahanunā kālagatena śuddhodanena rājya pratilabdha
translated: When King Siṃhahanu died, Śuddhodana obtained the kingdom.

original: rājñā śuddhodanena amātyā āṇattā sadṛśā me dārikā ānetha yā bhaveya prāsādikā ca kulīnā ca //
analyzed: rājñā śuddhodanena amātyā āṇattā sadṛśāḥ me dārikāḥ ānetha yā bhaveya prāsādikā ca kulīnā ca
translated: King Śuddhodana ordered his ministers, “Bring me a suitable wife, one who is lovely and of good family.”

original: tehi amātyehi samantato brāhmaṇā visarjitā paṇḍitā ca bahuśrutā ca strīlakṣaṇapuruṣalakṣaṇadārikālakṣaṇāvidhijñā //
analyzed: tehi amātyehi samantataḥ brāhmaṇā visarjitā paṇḍitā ca bahu śrutā ca strī lakṣaṇa puruṣa lakṣaṇa dārikā lakṣaṇā vidhi jñā
translated: The ministers sent out brahmans in all directions, who were wise and learned, skilled in the rules of the characteristics of women, men and girls.

original: gacchatha dārikā vijānatha yā rājño śuddhodanasya yogyā bhaveyā //
analyzed: gacchatha dārikāḥ vijānatha yā rājñaḥ śuddhodanasya yogyā bhaveyā
translated: “Go,” said they, “and find a girl who will be suitable for King Śuddhodana.”

original: tehi brāhmaṇehi grāmanigamanagarajanapadehi aṇvantehi śākyānā devaḍahe nigame subhūtisya śākyasya sapta dhītaro dṛṣṭā tāsā saptānā dhītarāṇa
analyzed: tehi brāhmaṇehi grāma nigama nagara janapadehi aṇu antehi śākyānā devaḍahe nigame subhūtisya śākyasya sapta dṛṣṭā tāsā saptānā
translated: Those brahmins, while wandering through villages, towns, cities, and countries, saw in the city of Devadaha of the Śākyas the seven daughters of the Śākya Subhūti. Of those seven daughters,

original: māyā sarvapradhānā kṛtsne ca jabudvīpe tādṛśā kanyā sudurlabhā //
analyzed: māyā sarva pradhānā kṛtsne ca jabudvīpe tādṛśā kanyā su durlabhā
translated: Māyā was the eldest, and in all of Jambudvīpa such a maiden was very difficult to find.

original: tehi rājño nivedita nigame subhūtisya śākyasya sapta dhītaro prāsādikā darśanīyā ca ekā cātra sarvāsā saptānā bhaginīnā pradhānā rūpeṇāpi
analyzed: tehi rājñaḥ nivedita nigame subhūtisya śākyasya sapta prāsādikā darśanīyā ca ekā ca atra sarvāsā saptānā bhaginīnā pradhānāḥ rūpeṇa api
translated: They reported to the king: In the city, the seven daughters of the Śākya Subhūti are pleasing and beautiful. And among them all, the eldest sister,🔽named Māyā, is endowed with all good qualities in terms of form,

original: tejenāpi prajñāye pi sarvaguṇasampannā māyā nāma //
analyzed: tejena api sarva guṇa sampannā māyā nāma
translated: radiance, and wisdom.

original: yattakā asmābhiḥ grāmanagaranigamajanapadā aṇvitā na khalvasmābhissadṛśā kanyā dṛṣṭapūrvā yādṛśī māyā sūbhūtisya śākyasya dhītā /
analyzed: yattakāḥ asmābhiḥ grāma nagara nigama janapadāḥ aṇvitāḥ na khalu asmābhiḥ sadṛśā kanyā dṛṣṭa pūrvā yādṛśī māyā sūbhūtisya śākyasya dhītā
translated: As many villages, towns, cities, and countries as we have wandered, we have never seen a maiden like Māyā, the daughter of the Śākya Subhūti.

original: śuddhodanena subhūtisya preṣita //
analyzed: śuddhodanena subhūtisya preṣita
translated: Śuddhodana sent to Subhūti:

original: māyā dhītā mama bhāryārtha dehīti agramahiṣī bhaviṣyati //
analyzed: māyā dhītā mama bhāryā artha dehi iti agramahiṣī bhaviṣyati
translated: Give me your daughter Māyā as a wife, she will be the chief queen.

original: subhūtirāha dūtānā //
analyzed: subhūtiḥ āha
translated: Subhūti said to the messengers:

original: māyāye ṣaḍdārikāyo jyeṣṭhatarikāyo yāva tāyo vuhyanti tato māyā mahārājasya dīyiṣyati /
analyzed: ṣaṣ dārikāyaḥ jyeṣṭhatarikāyaḥ tatas māyā mahā rājasya dīyiṣyati
translated: The six elder daughters, through the power of Māyā, will be carried away, and then Māyā will be given to the great king.

original: tehi dūtehi rājño śuddhodanasya nivedita //
analyzed: tehi dūtehi rājñaḥ śuddhodanasya nivedita
translated: The messengers reported this to King Śuddhodana:

original: mahārāja eva subhūti śākyo āha //
analyzed: mahā rājaḥ eva subhūti śākyaḥ āha
translated: Great king, the Śākya Subhūti says:

original: yāvadimā jyeṣṭhatarikā ṣaḍdārikāyo vuhyanti tato māyā mahārājasya dīyiṣyatīti /
analyzed: yāvat imāḥ jyeṣṭhatarikāḥ ṣaṣ dārikāyaḥ vuhyanti tatas māyā mahā rājasya dīyiṣyati iti
translated: 'As long as these six elder daughters are carried away, then Māyā will be given to the great king.'

original: rājā śuddhodanena bhūyo dūto subhūtisya śākyasya preṣito /
analyzed: rājā śuddhodanena bhūyas dūtaḥ subhūtisya śākyasya preṣitaḥ
translated: King Śuddhodana again sent a messenger to the Śākya Subhūti:

original: sarvā me sapta dhītarā dehi //
analyzed: sarvā me sapta dhītarā dehi
translated: 'Give me all your seven daughters.'

original: tehi dūtehi subhūtisya śākyasya ārocita //
analyzed: tehi dūtehi subhūtisya śākyasya ārocita
translated: The messengers reported this to the Śākya Subhūti:

original: rājā śuddhodano āha /
analyzed: rājā śuddhodanaḥ āha
translated: 'King Śuddhodana says:'

original: sarvā me sapta dhītaro dehīti //
analyzed: sarvāḥ me sapta dhītaraḥ dehi iti
translated: 'Give me all your seven daughters.'

original: subhūtinā śākyena rājño śuddhodanasya sadiṣṭa //
analyzed: subhūtinā śākyena rājñaḥ śuddhodanasya sadiṣṭa
translated: The Śākya Subhūti replied to King Śuddhodana:

original: mahārāja dinnā te bhavantu //
analyzed: mahā rāja dinnā te bhavantu
translated: 'Great king, let them be given to you.'

original: tā dāni sarvāyo sapta dārikāyo rājñā śuddhodanena mahatā rājaṛddhīye mahatā rājānubhāvena mahatā rājasamṛddhīye ānītā devaḍahāto nigamāto
analyzed: tāḥ dāni sapta dārikāyaḥ rājñā śuddhodanena mahatā rājaṛddhīye mahatā rāja anubhāvena mahatā rājasamṛddhīye ānītāḥ
translated: Then all those seven daughters were brought by King Śuddhodana with great royal splendor, great royal majesty, and great royal wealth from the town of Devakūṭa

original: kapilavastu //
analyzed: kapilavastu
translated: to Kapilavastu.

original: rājā śuddhodanena dve dārike svamantaḥ pura praveśitā māyā ca mahāprajāpatī ca /
analyzed: rājā śuddhodanena dve dārike svam antar pura praveśitāḥ māyā ca mahāprajāpatī ca
translated: King Śuddhodana took two girls into his harem, Māyā and Mahāprajāpatī.

original: paca dārikā pacabhratṛṇā dinnā //
analyzed: paca dārikā pacabhratṛṇā dinnā
translated: Sixteen girls were given to the sixteen princes.

original: dvādaśehi varṣehi bodhisatvo tuṣitabhavanāto cyaviṣyati //
analyzed: dvādaśehi varṣehi bodhisatvaḥ tuṣita bhavanātaḥ cyaviṣyati
translated: In twelve years the Bodhisattva will descend from the Tuṣita heaven.

original: śuddhāvāsā devā jabudvīpe pratyekabuddhānāmārocayanti bodhisatvo cyaviṣyati ricatha buddhakṣetra //
analyzed: śuddha āvāsāḥ devāḥ jabudvīpe pratyekabuddhānām ārocayanti cyaviṣyati ricatha buddhakṣetra
translated: The Śuddhāvāsa devas announced to the Pratyekabuddhas in the Rose-apple-tree isle that the Bodhisattva would descend, and that they should leave the Buddha-field.

original: tuṣitabhavanādatiyaśo cyaviṣyati anantajñānadarśāvī /
analyzed: tuṣita bhavanāt ati yaśo cyaviṣyati ananta jñāna darśāvī
translated: From the Tuṣita heaven will descend the very famous one, the seer of infinite knowledge.

original: ricatha buddhakṣetra varalakṣaṇadharasya //
analyzed: ricatha buddhakṣetra vara lakṣaṇa dharasya
translated: Leave the Buddha-field of him who bears the marks of excellence.

original: te śrutva buddhaśabda pratyekajinā maheśvaravarāṇā /
analyzed: te śrutva buddha śabda pratyeka jināḥ maheśvara varāṇā
translated: When they heard the word Buddha, the Pratyekabuddhas, the best of the great lords,

original: nirvāsu muktacittā svayabhuno cittavaśavartī //
analyzed: citta vaśavartī
translated: were emancipated, their minds freed, self-dependent, their minds in control.

original: te dāni pratyekabuddhāḥ svakasvakāni vyākaraṇāni vyākaritvā pāranivṛtāḥ //
analyzed: te dāni pratyekabuddhāḥ svaka svakāni vyākaraṇāni vyākaritvā pāra nivṛtāḥ
translated: And these Pratyekabuddhas, after proclaiming their several achievements, passed entirely away.

original: vārāṇasyā sārdhayojane mahāvanakhaṇḍa tatra paca pratyekabuddhaśatāni prativasensu //
analyzed: vārāṇasyā sārdha yojane mahā vana khaṇḍa tatra paca pratyekabuddha śatāni
translated: Two yojanas from Benares there was a great forest tract, and there dwelt five hundred Pratyekabuddhas.

original: te pi svakasvakāni vyākaraṇāni vyākaritvā parinirvṛtā /
analyzed: te pi svaka svakāni vyākaraṇāni vyākaritvā parinirvṛtā
translated: And they, after proclaiming their several achievements, passed entirely away.

original: ālabdhavīryā satatānuyogī udagracittā akuśīdavartī /
analyzed: ālabdha vīryā satata anuyogī udagra cittā
translated: Endowed with acquired energy, always persevering, with uplifted mind, not indolent,

original: dṛḍhavikramā vīryabalopapetā ekacarā khaḍgaviṣāṇakalpā //
analyzed: dṛḍha vikramā vīrya bala upapetā ekacarā khaḍga viṣāṇa kalpā
translated: Firm in resolve, possessing the strength of energy, solitary, like a rhinoceros.

original: vaihāyasamabhyudgamya tejodhātu samāpadyitvā anupādāya parinirvṛtā //
analyzed: vaihāyasam abhyudgamya tejaḥ dhātu samāpadyitvā an upādāya parinirvṛtā
translated: Rising up into the sky, entering the fire element, he attains parinirvāṇa without remainder.

original: svakāye tejodhātūye mānsaśoṇita dhyāpita /
analyzed: sva kāye tejaḥ dhātūye mānsa śoṇita dhyāpita
translated: In his own body, the fire element burns up his flesh and blood.

original: śarīrāṇi patitāni / ///
analyzed: śarīrāṇi patitāni
translated: The bodies fall down.

original: upekṣā karuṇā ca bhāvya āsevamāno muditā ca kāle /
analyzed: upekṣā karuṇā ca bhāvyaḥ āsevamānaḥ mudi tā ca kāle
translated: Cultivating equanimity, compassion, and sympathetic joy in time,🔽With a mind of loving-kindness, wishing for the benefit of all, solitary, like a rhinoceros,

original: maitreṇa cittena hitānukapi eko care khaḍgaviṣāṇakalpo sarveṣu prāṇeṣu nidhāya daṇḍa aviheṭhako anyatare pi teṣā /🔽nikṣiptadaṇḍo trasasthāvareṣu eko care khaḍgaviṣāṇakalpo //🔽otārayitvā gṛhivyajanāni saśīrṇapatro yathā pāripātro /
analyzed: maitreṇa cittena ekaḥ care khaḍga viṣāṇa kalpaḥ sarveṣu prāṇeṣu nidhāya daṇḍa a viheṭhakaḥ anyatare pi teṣām  nikṣipta daṇḍaḥ trasa sthāvareṣu ekaḥ care khaḍga viṣāṇa kalpaḥ  otārayitvā gṛhi vyajanāni sa śīrṇa patraḥ yathā pāripātraḥ
translated: One should practice, having laid down the rod against all beings, not harming even the smallest of creatures.🔽Having laid down the rod against trembling and unmoving beings, one should practice, solitary, like a rhinoceros.🔽Having abandoned the household requisites, like a leafless tree,

original: kāṣāyavastro abhiniṣkramitvā eko care khaḍgaviṣāṇakalpo //🔽sadārayitvā gṛhivyajanāni śikhiryathā bhasmani ekacārī /
analyzed: kāṣāya vastraḥ abhiniṣkramitvā ekaḥ care khaḍga viṣāṇa kalpaḥ  sa dārayitvā gṛhi vyajanāni śikhiḥ yathā bhasmani ekacārī
translated: Having gone forth in the saffron robe, one should practice, solitary, like a rhinoceros.🔽Having abandoned the household requisites, like a flame in ashes, solitary,

original: kāṣāyavastro abhiniṣkramitvā eko care khaḍgaviṣāṇakalpo //
analyzed: kāṣāya vastraḥ abhiniṣkramitvā ekaḥ care khaḍga viṣāṇa kalpaḥ
translated: Having gone forth in the saffron robe, one should practice, solitary, like a rhinoceros.

original: sasevamānasya siyātisneho snehānvaya duḥkhamida prabhoti /
analyzed: sa sevamānasya siyā ati snehaḥ sneha anvaya duḥkham idam
translated: If one associates, there can be excessive affection, and suffering arises from the continuity of affection.

original: sasevamāna tu jugupsamāno eko care khaḍgaviṣāṇakalpo //
analyzed: sa sevamāna tu jugupsamānaḥ ekaḥ care khaḍga viṣāṇa kalpaḥ
translated: But if one associates while feeling disgust, one should go forth alone like a rhinoceros.

original: sasevamānasya siyātisneho snehānvaya duḥkhamida prabhoti /
analyzed: sa sevamānasya siyā ati snehaḥ sneha anvaya duḥkham idam
translated: If one associates, there can be excessive affection, and suffering arises from the continuity of affection.

original: priyātisneha vijigupsamāno eko care khaḍgaviṣāṇakalpo //
analyzed: priya ati sneha vijigupsamānaḥ ekaḥ care khaḍga viṣāṇa kalpaḥ
translated: Desiring to overcome excessive affection for loved ones, one should go forth alone like a rhinoceros.

original: sasevamānasya siyātisneho snehānvaya duḥkhamida prabhoti /
analyzed: sa sevamānasya siyā ati snehaḥ sneha anvaya duḥkham idam
translated: If one associates, there can be excessive affection, and suffering arises from the continuity of affection.

original: priyā viyoga vijugupsamāno eko care khaḍgaviṣāṇakalpo //
analyzed: priyā viyoga vijugupsamānaḥ ekaḥ care khaḍga viṣāṇa kalpaḥ
translated: Desiring to overcome separation from loved ones, one should go forth alone like a rhinoceros.

original: sasevamānasya siyātisneho snehānvaya duḥkhamida prabhoti /
analyzed: sa sevamānasya siyā ati snehaḥ
translated: If one associates, there can be excessive affection, and suffering arises from the continuity of affection.

original: mitreṣu ādīnava samṛśanto eko care khaḍgaviṣāṇakalpo //
analyzed: mitreṣu ādīnava samṛśantaḥ ekaḥ care khaḍga viṣāṇa kalpaḥ
translated: Contemplating the dangers in friendships, one should go forth alone like a rhinoceros.

original: sasevamānasya siyātisneho snehānvaya duḥkhamida prabhoti /
analyzed: sa sevamānasya siyā ati snehaḥ sneha anvaya duḥkham idam
translated: If one associates, there can be excessive affection, and suffering arises from the continuity of affection.

original: putreṣu ādīnava samṛśanto eko care khaḍgaviṣāṇakalpo //
analyzed: putreṣu ādīnava samṛśantaḥ ekaḥ care khaḍga viṣāṇa kalpaḥ
translated: Contemplating the dangers in sons, one should go forth alone like a rhinoceros.

original: putrā sahāyānavalokayanto hāpeti artha pratibaddhacitto /
analyzed: sahāyān avalokayantaḥ
translated: Looking for sons as companions, one abandons one's purpose with a bound mind.

original: na putramiccheya kuto sahāyān eko care khaḍgaviṣāṇakalpo //
analyzed: na putram iccheya kutas sahāyān ekaḥ care khaḍga viṣāṇa kalpaḥ
translated: One should not desire a son, let alone companions, one should go forth alone like a rhinoceros.

original: jñātī sahāyānavalokayanto hāpeti artha pratibaddhacitto /
analyzed: sahāyān avalokayantaḥ
translated: He who looks to kinsmen and friends loses his wealth and his mind is bound to it.

original: jñātī na iccheya kuto sahayā eko care khaḍgaviṣāṇakalpo //
analyzed: jñātī naḥ iccheya kutas ekaḥ care khaḍga viṣāṇa kalpaḥ
translated: He should not desire kinsmen, how much less friends? He should go forth alone like a rhinoceros.

original: sarvā khaḍgaviṣāṇagāthā vistareṇa kartavyā //
analyzed: sarvā khaḍga viṣāṇa gāthā vistareṇa kartavyā
translated: All the verses of the rhinoceros should be done in detail.

original: pamcānā pratyekabuddhaśatānāmekaeka gāthā //
analyzed: pamcānā pratyekabuddha śatānām ekaika gāthā
translated: Each verse is for five hundred Pratyekabuddhas.

original: ṛṣayo ca patitā ṛṣipatana //
analyzed: ṛṣayaḥ ca patitāḥ ṛṣipatana
translated: And the Rishis fell into the Rishis' fall.

original: tahi vanakhaṇḍe rāhako nāma mṛgarājā sahasramṛgayūtha pariharati //
analyzed: vanakhaṇḍe rāhakaḥ nāma mṛga rājā sahasra mṛga yūtha pariharati
translated: In that forest grove, there was a king of deer named Rahu who looked after a herd of a thousand deer.

original: tasya duve putrā nyagrodho ca nāma viśākho ca //
analyzed: tasya duve putrāḥ nyagrodho ca nāma viśākho ca
translated: He had two sons named Nyagrodha and Vishakha.

original: tena dāni mṛgarājena ekasyāpi putrasya paca mṛgaśatāni dinnāni aparasyāpi putrasya paca mṛgaśatāni dinnāni //
analyzed: tena dāni mṛga rājena ekasya api putrasya paca mṛga śatāni dinnāni aparasya api putrasya paca mṛga śatāni dinnāni
translated: That king of deer gave fifty deer to each of his sons.

original: brahmadatto kāśirājā abhīkṣṇa mṛgavya nirdhāvati ta vanaṣāṇḍa parisamanta tatra ca mṛgāni hanti //
analyzed: brahmadattaḥ kāśi rājā abhīkṣṇa mṛgavya nirdhāvati tatra ca mṛgāni hanti
translated: King Brahmadatta of Kashi often went out on a deer hunt and surrounded that forest grove and killed the deer there.

original: na tattakā mṛgā svaya upajīvati yattakāni āhatakāni vanagulmeṣu ca vanagahaneṣu ca śarahāreṣu ca naḍakahāreṣu ca kaṇṭakahāreṣu ca praviśitvā
analyzed: na tattakā mṛgā svayas upajīvati yattakāni āhatakāni vana gulmeṣu ca vana gahaneṣu ca śara hāreṣu ca naḍaka hāreṣu ca kaṇṭaka hāreṣu ca praviśitvā
translated: He did not live off as many deer as were wounded and entered the forest thickets, the forest thickets, the arrow traps, the reed traps, the thorn traps, and the brambles.

original: maranti //
analyzed: maranti
translated: they die.

original: te tatra kākaśa kuntehi khajjanti //
analyzed: te tatra kākaśa kuntehi khajjanti
translated: There they are devoured by crows and vultures.

original: nyagrodho mṛgarājā ta bhrātara viśākha āha //
analyzed: nyagrodhaḥ mṛga rājā ta bhrātara viśākhaḥ āha
translated: The king of the deer, Nyagrodha, said to his brother Vishakha:

original: viśākha eta kāśirāja vijñāpema //
analyzed: viśākhaḥ eta kāśirāja vijñāpema
translated: Vishakha, let us inform the king of Kasi:

original: na tattakā tva mṛgā svaya upajīvasi yattakā āhatakā gahanehi pradeśehi praviśitvā maranti kākaśakuntehi khādyanti //
analyzed: na tattakā tva mṛgā svayas upajīvasi yattakāḥ āhatakāḥ gahanehi pradeśehi praviśitvā maranti kāka śakuntehi khādyanti
translated: 'You do not use as much meat as is lost when the deer, wounded by you in the thickets, enter the forest and die there, to be devoured by crows and vultures.'

original: vaya rājño eka mṛga daivasika dāsyāmaḥ yo tava svaya mahānasa praviśiṣyati //
analyzed: vaya rājñaḥ eka mṛga daivasika dāsyāmaḥ yaḥ tava svaya mahānasa praviśiṣyati
translated: We will give the king one deer a day, which will enter his kitchen of its own accord.

original: ima ca mṛgayūtha na eva anayavyasanamāpadyiṣyanti //
analyzed: ca mṛga yūtha naḥ eva anaya vyasanam āpadyiṣyanti
translated: And this herd of deer will not come to ruin and destruction.

original: tasya bhrātā viśākho āha //
analyzed: tasya bhrātā viśākhaḥ āha
translated: His brother Vishakha said:

original: eva bhavatu vijñāpema //
analyzed: eva bhavatu vijñāpema
translated: So be it, let us inform him.

original: so dāni rājā mṛgavya nirdhāvito //
analyzed: saḥ dāni rājā mṛgavya nirdhāvitaḥ
translated: Then the king went out on a hunting expedition.

original: tehi yūthapatīhi mṛgarājehi so rājā dṛṣṭo dūrata eva āgacchanto sabalavāhano asidhanuśaktitomaradharehi saparivṛtto //
analyzed: tehi yūtha patīhi mṛgarājehi saḥ rājā dṛṣṭaḥ dūratas eva āgacchantaḥ sa bala vāhanaḥ asi dhanu śakti tomara dharehi sa parivṛttaḥ
translated: The leaders of the herds, the kings of the deer, saw the king coming from afar, with his army and vehicles, surrounded by men armed with swords, bows, spears and lances.

original: te dāni da rājāna dṛṣṭvā yena rājā tena abhimukhā pratyudgatā abhītā anuttrastā ātmāna parityajitvā //
analyzed: te dāni da rājāna dṛṣṭvā yena rājā tena abhimukhā pratyudgatā abhītāḥ anuttrastāḥ ātmāna parityajitvā
translated: And when they saw the king, they went towards him, unafraid and undaunted, ready to sacrifice themselves.

original: tena dāni kāśirājñā mṛgarājānau dṛṣṭā dūrata eva abhimukhā āgacchantā //
analyzed: tena dāni kāśi rājñā mṛga rājānau dṛṣṭā dūratas eva abhimukhā āgacchantā
translated: The king of Kāśi saw the two kings of the deer coming towards him from a distance.

original: tena svakasya balāgrasya āṇatti dinnā //
analyzed: tena svakasya balāgrasya āṇatti dinnā
translated: He gave orders to his army, saying,

original: na kenacidete mṛgā āgacchanto vihaṭhayitavyā ko jānāti kimatra antara yathaite valāgra dṛṣṭvā na palāyanti mama abhimukhā āgacchanti //
analyzed: na kenacid ete mṛgāḥ āgacchantaḥ vihaṭhayitavyāḥ kaḥ jānāti kim atra yathā ete vala agra dṛṣṭvā na palāyanti mama abhimukhāḥ āgacchanti
translated: “Let no one molest these deer as they come. Who knows what there is in this matter, since they do not flee when they see the army, but come towards me?”

original: balāgreṇa teṣā mṛgāṇāmantaro dinno vāmadakṣiṇabhūto so balāgro //
analyzed: bala agreṇa teṣām mṛgāṇām antaraḥ dinnaḥ vāma dakṣiṇa bhūtaḥ saḥ bala agraḥ
translated: The army made way for the deer, and the army stood on one side to the right and on the other to the left.

original: te mṛgā yena rājā tenopasakramitvā rājño jānuhi praṇipatitāḥ /
analyzed: te mṛgāḥ yena rājā tena upasakramitvā rājñaḥ jānuhi praṇipatitāḥ
translated: The deer went up to the king and fell on their knees before him.

original: rājā teṣā mṛgarājānā pṛcchati //
analyzed: rājā teṣām mṛgarājānā pṛcchati
translated: The king asked the kings of the deer,

original: kā vo vijñaptiḥ vijñāpetha ya vo kārya //
analyzed: kā vaḥ vijñaptiḥ vijñāpetha
translated: “What is your business? Tell me what I can do for you.”

original: te dāni mānuṣāye vācāye ta rājāna vijñāpenti //
analyzed: te dāni mānuṣāye vācāye ta rājāna vijñāpenti
translated: And they made their request in human speech, saying to the king,

original: mahārāja vijñāpāma //
analyzed: mahā rāja vijñāpāma
translated: “Great king, we make our request.

original: vaya tava iha rājye atra vanakhaṇḍe jātā savṛddhā anye pi bahūni mṛgaśatāni //
analyzed: vaya tava iha rājye atra vana khaṇḍe jātā sa vṛddhāḥ anye pi bahūni mṛga śatāni
translated: We were born and grew up in your realm in this forest grove, and there are many hundreds of other deer besides.

original: vayanteṣā mṛgāṇā dve bhrātarau yūthapatinau iha mahārājasya vijite prativasāmaḥ //
analyzed: dve bhrātarau yūtha patinau iha mahā rājasya vijite prativasāmaḥ
translated: We are two brothers, kings of the deer, and we dwell in your majesty’s realm.

original: yathaiva mahārājasya nagarā paṭṭanā ca grāmā ca janapadā ca janena śobhanti gobalivardehi ca anyehi pi prāṇasahasrehi dvipadacatuṣpadehi evametāni
analyzed: yathā eva mahā rājasya nagarā paṭṭanā ca grāmā ca janapadā ca janena śobhanti go balivardehi ca anyehi pi prāṇa sahasrehi dvipada catuṣpadehi evam etāni
translated: Just as the king's cities, towns, villages, and provinces are adorned with people, with cattle, buffaloes, and with other thousands of living beings, both bipeds and quadrupeds, in the same way

original: vanakhaṇḍān āśramāṇi ca nadīyo ca prasravaṇīyo ca etehi mṛgapakṣehi śobhanti //
analyzed: vanakhaṇḍān āśramāṇi ca ca etehi mṛga pakṣehi śobhanti
translated: these forests, hermitages, rivers, and streams are adorned with these deer and birds.

original: eva mahārāja etasya adhiṣṭhānasya alakāro //
analyzed: eva mahā rāja etasya adhiṣṭhānasya
translated: This is the ornament of this realm, great king.

original: sarve ete mahārāja dvipadacatuṣpadā yattakā mahārājasya vijite vasanti grāmagatā vāraṇyagatā vā parvatagatā vā mahārājasya śaraṇa gatāḥ
analyzed: sarve ete mahā rāja dvipada catuṣpadāḥ yattakāḥ mahārājasya vijite vasanti grāma gatāḥ vā araṇya gatāḥ vā parvata gatāḥ vā mahārājasya śaraṇa gatāḥ  /
translated: All these bipeds and quadrupeds, as many as there are living in the king's realm, whether in villages, forests, or mountains, have taken refuge in the great king.

original: sarve te mahārāja cintanīyā paripālanīyā ca //
analyzed: sarve te mahā rāja cintanīyā paripālanīyā ca
translated: All of them, great king, should be considered and protected.

original: mahārājā ca teṣā prabhavati anyo rājā na //
analyzed: mahā rājā ca teṣām prabhavati anyaḥ rājā na
translated: And the great king has power over them, not any other king.

original: ya vela mahārājā mṛgavya niṣkāsati tataḥ bahūni mṛgaśatāni anayavyasanamāpadyanti /
analyzed: mahā rājā mṛgavya niṣkāsati tatas bahūni mṛga śatāni anaya vyasanam āpadyanti
translated: When the great king goes out on a hunt, then many hundreds of deer come to ruin and destruction.

original: na tattakā mahārājasya upajīvyā bhavanti yattakā śarehi āhatakā atra vanagahaneṣu ca naḍagahaneṣu śarahāreṣu ca kāśahāreṣu ca praviśiya maranti
analyzed: na tattakāḥ mahā rājasya upajīvyāḥ bhavanti yattakā śarehi āhatakā atra vana gahaneṣu ca naḍa gahaneṣu śara hāreṣu ca kāśa hāreṣu ca maranti  /
translated: Not so many, sire, are the animals that are hit by arrows and die here in the thickets of the forest, in the thickets of reeds, in the thickets of cane and in the thickets of grass.

original: kāka śakuntehi khādyante mahārājā ca adharmeṇa lipyati //
analyzed: kāka śakuntehi khādyante mahārājā ca adharmeṇa lipyati
translated: But the king is defiled by sin.

original: yadi mahārājasya prasādau bhaveya vaya dve yūthapatino mahārājasya daivasika ekamṛga visarjayiṣyāmaḥ yo tava mahānasa svaya praviśiṣyati
analyzed: yadi mahārājasya prasādau bhaveya dve yūthapatinaḥ mahārājasya daivasikaḥ eka mṛga visarjayiṣyāmaḥ tava mahānasa svayam praviśiṣyati
translated: If, sire, you will grant us this favour, we two leaders of herds will send you one animal a day.

original: ekāto yūthāto eka divasa dvitīyāto yūthāto dvitīya divasa eka mṛga visarjayiṣyāmaḥ mahārājasya ca mṛgamānsena avibhakṣaṇa bhaviṣyati
analyzed: eka divasa dvitīyātaḥ yūthātaḥ dvitīya divasa eka mṛga visarjayiṣyāmaḥ mahā rājasya ca bhaviṣyati  /
translated: From one herd one animal will be sent on the first day, and from the second herd on the second day. In this way the king will not be without meat,

original: ime ca mṛgā eva anayavyasana nopapadyiṣyanti //
analyzed: ime ca mṛgāḥ eva anaya vyasana na upapadyiṣyanti
translated: and these animals will not come to destruction.”

original: tena dāni rājñā teṣā mṛgayūthapatīnā vijñapti dinnā //
analyzed: tena dāni rājñā teṣām mṛga yūtha patīnām vijñapti dinnā
translated: Then the king granted the request of the leaders of the herds, saying,

original: yathā yuṣmākamabhiprāyo tathā bhavatu gacchatha abhītā anuttrastā vasatha mama ca eka mṛga divasedivase visarjetha //
analyzed: yathā tathā bhavatu gacchatha abhītāḥ anuttrastāḥ vasatha mama ca eka mṛga divasedivase visarjetha
translated: “As you wish, so be it. Go in safety and without fear. Dwell here and send me one animal a day.”

original: rājā teṣā vijñapti dattvā amātyānāmāha //
analyzed: rājā teṣām vijñapti dattvā amātyānām āha
translated: The king, having given his orders, said to his ministers,

original: na kenacit mṛgā viheṭhayitavyā //
analyzed: na kenacid mṛgā viheṭhayitavyā
translated: ‘Let no one molest the deer.’

original: evamājñā dattvā nagara praviṣṭo //
analyzed: evam ājñāḥ dattvā nagara praviṣṭaḥ
translated: Having given this order, he entered the city.

original: tehi yūthapatīhi te mṛgā sarve samānītā āśvāsitā ca //🔽mā bhāyatha evamasmābhiḥ rājā vijñāpito yathā rājā na bhūyo mṛgavya nirdhāviṣyati na kvacit mṛgā viheṭhayiṣyati rājño ca divasedivase eko
analyzed: tehi yūtha patīhi te mṛgā sarve samānītāḥ āśvāsitā ca  mā bhāyatha evam asmābhiḥ rājā vijñāpitaḥ yathā rājā na bhūyas mṛgavya nirdhāviṣyati na kvacid mṛgāḥ viheṭhayiṣyati ca divase divase ekaḥ
translated: The leaders of the herds brought together all the deer and comforted them, saying,

original: mṛgo visarjetavyaḥ eka divasa ekato yūthāto apara divasa aparāto yūthāto //
analyzed: mṛgaḥ visarjetavyaḥ eka divasa ekatas apara divasa
translated: ‘Do not fear. We have so arranged that the king will no more go out hunting, and that no one will molest the deer. But every day one deer must be sent to the king’s kitchen. One day it shall be the turn of one herd, and the next day of the other.’

original: tehi mṛgehi sarvā ca tā mṛgā ubhayehi yūthehi gaṇetvā yūthātoyūthāto osara kṛta //
analyzed: tehi mṛgehi sarvā ca tā mṛgāḥ ubhayehi yūthehi gaṇetvā kṛta
translated: The deer counted all the deer in the two herds and fixed the order in which they were to go.

original: ekāto yūthāto eka divasa mṛgo gacchati rājño mahānasa aparāto yūthāto apara divasa gacchati //
analyzed: ekātas eka divasa mṛgaḥ gacchati rājñaḥ mahānasa aparātas yūthātas apara divasa gacchati
translated: One day a deer from one herd went to the king’s kitchen, and the next day a deer from the other herd.

original: kadci viśākhasya yūthāto osarasmi guviṇīye mṛgīye vāro rājño mahānasa gamanāya //
analyzed: viśākhasya guviṇīye mṛgīye vāraḥ rājñaḥ mahānasa gamanāya
translated: Now it was the turn of Viśākha’s herd, and a pregnant doe was due to go to the king’s kitchen.

original: sā dāni mṛgī āṇāpakena mṛgena vucyati /
analyzed: sā dāni mṛgī āṇāpakena mṛgena vucyati
translated: The doe was told by the deer who was the king’s messenger,🔽‘To-morrow it is your turn to go to the king’s kitchen.’

original: tav adya osaro gaccha rājño mahānasa ti //
analyzed: tava adya osaraḥ gaccha rājñaḥ mahānasa ti
translated: Today it is your turn to go to the king’s kitchen.

original: sā āha //
analyzed: sā āha
translated: She replied:

original: aha gurviṇī dve me potakā kukṣismi anya tāva āṇāpehi ya vela prasūtā bhaviṣyāmi tataḥ gamiṣyāmi /
analyzed: aha gurviṇī dve me potakā kukṣismi prasūtā bhaviṣyāmi tatas gamiṣyāmi
translated: I am pregnant and have two young ones in my womb. Order another. When I have given birth I will go.

original: te dāni ekasyārthe trivarga cariṣyāmaḥ //
analyzed: te dāni ekasya arthe trivarga cariṣyāmaḥ
translated: We will all three go for the sake of one.

original: yuṣmāka eva ciratarakena vāro bhaviṣyati iemehi duvehi potakehi jātehi //
analyzed: yuṣmākaḥ eva ciratarakena vāraḥ bhaviṣyati duvehi potakehi jātehi
translated: It will be a long time before it is your turn again, when the two young ones are born.

original: tena āṇāpakena mṛgena eta kārya yūthapatisya ārocita //
analyzed: tena āṇāpakena mṛgena eta kārya yūthapatisya ārocita
translated: The king’s messenger deer reported this to the chief of the herd.

original: yūthapati āha //
analyzed: yūthapati āha
translated: The chief of the herd said:

original: anya mṛga āṇāpehi yo etasyā mṛgīye antareṇa //
analyzed: anya mṛga āṇa apehi yā u etasyāḥ mṛgīye antareṇa
translated: Order another deer who is between this doe and the king’s kitchen.

original: eṣā mṛgī prasūtā samānā paścādgamiṣyati //
analyzed: eṣā mṛgī prasūtā samānā paścāt gamiṣyati
translated: When this doe has given birth she will go later.

original: tena āṇāpakena mṛgena tā mṛgīmatikramitvā yo tasyā mṛgīye antareṇa so āṇatto gaccha rājño mahānasanti //
analyzed: tena āṇāpakena mṛgena tā mṛgīm atikramitvā tasyāḥ mṛgīye antareṇa saḥ āṇattaḥ gaccha rājñaḥ
translated: The king’s messenger deer passed over those does and ordered the one who was between the doe and the king’s kitchen to go.

original: so pi āha //
analyzed: saḥ pi āha
translated: He replied:

original: na mama adya adya osaro amukāye mṛgīye adya osaro eva tāvadantara jīviṣya //
analyzed: na mama adya adya osaro amu kāye mṛgīye adya osaro eva tāvat antara jīviṣya
translated: Today it is not my turn. It is the turn of the doe so-and-so. I will live for a while yet.

original: eva aparāpare pi vucyanti na ca anosarā gacchanti /
analyzed: eva aparāpare pi vucyanti na ca anosarāḥ gacchanti
translated: Others were ordered in the same way, but they did not go because it was not their turn.

original: sarve jalpanti //
analyzed: sarve jalpanti
translated: All of them said:

original: amukāye mṛgīye osaro sā gacchatūti //
analyzed: amu kāye mṛgīye osaraḥ sā gacchatu uti
translated: It is the turn of the doe so-and-so. Let her go.

original: sā mṛgī vucyati //
analyzed: sā mṛgī vucyati
translated: The doe was told:

original: bhadre na kocidicchati anosareṇa gantu /
analyzed: bhadre na kocid icchati anosareṇa gantu
translated: “Good doe, no one is willing to go in place of one whose turn it is not.

original: tava osaro tva eva gacchāhi rājño mahānasa //
analyzed: tava osaro tvaḥ eva gacchāhi rājñaḥ mahānasa
translated: It is your turn. You must go to the king’s kitchen.”

original: sā dāni mṛgī yā velā na mucyati sā teṣā potakānā premnena mama sanipātena ete pi ghātayiṣyantīti ta dvitīya mṛgayūtha gatā //
analyzed: sā dāni mṛgī yā velā na mucyati sā teṣā potakānā premnena mama sanipātena ete pi ghātayiṣyanti iti ta dvitīya mṛga yūtha gatā
translated: Then the doe, out of love for her young, thought: “If I do not go when it is my turn, they will kill my young ones too.” So she went to the second herd of deer.

original: gacciya tasya yūthapatisya praṇipatitā //
analyzed: tasya yūtha patisya praṇipatitā
translated: And when she had gone there she fell in with the herd.

original: so nā yūthapatiḥ pṛcchati //
analyzed: saḥ nā yūtha patiḥ pṛcchati
translated: The leader of the herd asked her:

original: ki eta bhadre kimāṇāpesi ki kārya //
analyzed: ki bhadre kimāṇāpesi ki
translated: “What is it, good doe? What do you want? What is the matter?”

original: sā āha //
analyzed: sā āha
translated: She replied:

original: adya tato yūthāto mama vāro rājño mahānasa gamanāye mama ca duve potakā kukṣismi tato me so viśākho yūthapati vijñapto //
analyzed: adya tatas yūthātaḥ mama vāraḥ rājñaḥ mahānasa mama ca tatas me saḥ viśākhaḥ yūtha pati vijñaptaḥ
translated: “To-day it was my turn to go from that herd to the king’s kitchen, and as I have two young ones in my womb, the leader of the herd, Viśākha, was informed.

original: mama adya osaro ime ca duve potakā kukṣismi /
analyzed: mama adya osaraḥ ime ca duve potakā kukṣismi
translated: ‘To-day it is my turn, but I have two young ones in my womb.

original: anyā preṣehi ya vela prasūtā bhaviṣya tato gamiṣyāmi //
analyzed: anyā preṣehi tatas gamiṣyāmi
translated: Send another in my place, and when I have been delivered I will go.’

original: tena ca yūthapatinā ye anye āṇāpiyanti te pi na icchanti gantu nāsmākamosaro amukāye mṛgīye osaro sā gacchatūti //
analyzed: tena ca yūtha patinā ye anye te pi naḥ icchanti gantu na asmākam osaraḥ amu kāye mṛgīye osaraḥ sā gacchatu uti
translated: And when the leader of the herd ordered the others to go, they refused, saying, It is not our turn, it is that doe’s turn. Let her go.

original: sā aha tehi na mucyāmi osarāto vucyāmi gacchāhi tava osaro ti tadicchāmi mṛgarājena ato anya mṛga visarjamāna ya vela aha prasūtā bhaviṣyāmi
analyzed: sā aha na mucyāmi osara atas vucyāmi gacchāhi tava ti tat icchāmi mṛgarājena atas anya mṛga visarjamāna aha prasūtā bhaviṣyāmi
translated: But she was not released from her turn. She was told, Go, it is your turn. So she said, ‘I will not go until the king of the deer has ordered another deer to go in my place.

original: tato gamiṣyāmi //
analyzed: tatas gamiṣyāmi
translated: When I have given birth, then will I go.’

original: so mṛgarājā mṛgīmāha //
analyzed: saḥ mṛga rājā mṛgīm āha
translated: The king of the deer said to the doe,

original: tāva mā bhāyāhi anya visarjayiṣya //🔽tena mṛgarājena āṇāpako mṛgo āṇatto ito yūthāto yasya mṛgasya osaro ta āṇāpehi etāye mṛgīye mayā abhaya dinna //
analyzed: tāva mā bhāyāhi anya visarjayiṣya  tena mṛgarājena āṇāpakaḥ mṛgaḥ āṇattaḥ itas yasya mṛgasya osaraḥ te āṇāpehi etāye mṛgīye mayā abhaya dinna
translated: ‘Do not be afraid. will order another to go in your place.’🔽The king of the deer ordered a deer who was a messenger, saying, ‘Go and tell the deer whose turn it is to go to the king’s kitchen that the doe has been granted immunity by me.’

original: tena āṇāpakena yasya mṛgasya osaro ta āṇāpyati //
analyzed: tena āṇāpakena yasya mṛgasya osaraḥ te āṇāpyati
translated: The messenger went and told the deer whose turn it was.

original: gaccha rājño mahānasa //
analyzed: gaccha rājñaḥ mahānasa
translated: ‘Go to the king’s kitchen.’

original: so pi āha //
analyzed: saḥ pi āha
translated: But the deer replied,

original: na asmāka yūthasya adya vāro viśākhasya vāro yasyā mṛgīye vāro sā gurviṇī duve potakā kukṣismi /
analyzed: na asmāka yūthasya adya vāraḥ viśākhasya vāraḥ yasyāḥ mṛgīye sā gurviṇī
translated: ‘It is not our turn today. It is Viśākha’s turn. The doe whose turn it is is pregnant and has two young ones in her womb.

original: tehi na mucyati tava osaro tva gacchāhīti //
analyzed: tehi na mucyati tava osaro tva gacchāhi iti
translated: She is not released, but is told, “It is your turn. You go.”’

original: tāye ca mṛgīye tato amucyantiye iha yuthamāgatvā nyagrodho yūthapati vijñapto //
analyzed: ca mṛgīye iha yutham āgatvā nyagrodhaḥ yūtha pati
translated: And when the deer was released by her, she came to the herd and informed Nyagrodha, the king of the deer.

original: nyagrodhena yūthapatinā tasyā mṛgīye abhaya dinna //
analyzed: nyagrodhena yūtha patinā tasyāḥ mṛgīye abhaya dinna
translated: Nyagrodha, the king of the deer, granted immunity to the doe.

original: yūthapatinā āṇatta //🔽yasya ito yūthāto osaro ta visarjehi iti //
analyzed: yūtha patinā āṇatta  yasya itas visarja ihi iti
translated: The king of the deer ordered:🔽Let him go whose turn it is from this herd.

original: tava ito yūthato osaro tva gacchāhi //
analyzed: tava itas yūthataḥ osaro tva gacchāhi
translated: It is your turn from this herd. Go.

original: so āha //
analyzed: sā u āha
translated: He replied:

original: dvitīyasya adya osaro ta nāha anosare gaccheya //
analyzed: dvitīyasya adya osara ta nāha anosare gaccheya
translated: It is the turn of the second one today. I will not go out of turn.

original: eva yoyo āṇāpyati soso pi na icchati anosare gantu //
analyzed: eva sosaḥ pi naḥ icchati anosare gantu
translated: And whoever was ordered did not want to go out of turn.

original: tena āṇāpakena mṛgeṇa nyagrodhasya mṛgapatisya ārocita //
analyzed: tena āṇāpakena mṛgeṇa nyagrodhasya mṛgapatisya ārocita
translated: The deer who was ordered reported to Nyagrodha, the king of the deer:

original: na koci icchati anosareṇa gantu jalpanti nāsmākamadya osaro dvitīyasya mṛgayūthasya adya osaro //
analyzed: na koci icchati anosareṇa gantu jalpanti na asmākam adya osaraḥ dvitīyasya mṛga yūthasya adya osaraḥ
translated: No one wants to go out of turn. They say, 'It is not our turn today. It is the turn of the second herd of deer today.'

original: mṛgarājā āha //
analyzed: mṛgarājā āha
translated: The king of the deer said:

original: millehi maye imasyā mṛgīye abhaya dinna /
analyzed: millehi maye imasyā mṛgīye abhaya dinna
translated: I have granted immunity to this doe.

original: na śakyā saiṣā bhūyo tatra mahānasa visarjayitu /
analyzed: na śakyā sā eṣā tatra mahānasa visarjayitu
translated: It is not possible to send her back to the kitchen again.

original: aha svaya gamiṣyāmi //
analyzed: aha svaya gamiṣyāmi
translated: I myself will go.

original: so mṛgarājā tato vanaṣaṇḍāto panthamotaritvā vārāṇaṣī gacchati //
analyzed: saḥ mṛga rājā tatas vārāṇaṣī gacchati
translated: And the king of the deer, descending from the forest path, went to Benares.

original: yoyo puruṣo ta mṛgarāja paśyati gacchanta soso etamanugacchati //
analyzed: puruṣaḥ ta mṛgarāja paśyati gacchanta etam anugacchati
translated: Whoever saw the king of deer going, they all followed him.

original: mṛgo darśanīyo rūpeṇa citropacitro raktehi khurehi añjanehi akṣīhi prabhāsvarehi darśanīyehi //
analyzed: mṛgaḥ darśanīyaḥ rūpeṇa citra upacitraḥ raktehi khurehi añjanehi akṣīhi prabhāsvarehi darśanīyehi
translated: The deer was beautiful in form, variegated and colorful, with red hooves and eyelashes, and shining and beautiful eyes.

original: mahatā janakāyena agratokṛto gacchati yāvadabhyantara nagara praviṣṭo nāgarehi dṛṣṭo abhijñāto so mṛgarājā mahato janakāyasya //
analyzed: mahatā jana kāyena agratokṛtaḥ gacchati yāvat abhyantara nagara praviṣṭaḥ nāgarehi dṛṣṭaḥ abhijñātaḥ saḥ mṛga rājā mahataḥ jana kāyasya
translated: He was led by a large crowd of people as he went, and when he entered the city he was seen and recognized by the citizens as the king of deer, and he became known to a large crowd of people.

original: te ta paśyitvā mṛgarājamutkaṇṭhitā tantattaka mṛgayūtha sarva kṣapita aya yūthapatiḥ svayamāgato //
analyzed: te ta paśyitvā mṛgarājam utkaṇṭhitā mṛga yūtha sarva kṣapita yūtha patiḥ svayam āgataḥ
translated: Seeing the king of deer, they were eager, and the entire herd of deer was destroyed. The leader of the herd came himself.

original: gacchāma rājāna vijñāpemaḥ yathaiṣo mṛgarājā mucyeyā na hanyeyā alakāro imasya adhiṣṭhānasya cakṣuramaṇīyo jāto nirdhāvanto udyāne ca taḍāge 🔽ca //
analyzed: gacchāma rājāna vijñāpemaḥ yathā eṣaḥ mṛga rājā mucyeyāḥ na hanyeyāḥ alakāraḥ imasya adhiṣṭhānasya cakṣu ramaṇīyaḥ jātaḥ nirdhāvantaḥ udyāne ca taḍāge  ca
translated: We will go and inform the king so that this king of deer may be released and not killed. He is an ornament to this place and has become a delight to the eyes, running in the gardens and ponds.

original: te ta mṛga paśyitvā cakṣuḥprītibhanubhavanti //
analyzed: te ta mṛga paśyitvā
translated: Seeing that deer, they experience joy for the eyes.

original: tenaiva samahattarakena mahatā janakāyena sārdha mṛgarājasya anupṛṣṭhato rājakula praviṣṭam //
analyzed: tena eva sa mahattarakena mahatā jana kāyena sārdha mṛgarājasya anu pṛṣṭhatas rājakula praviṣṭam
translated: With that very large crowd of people, he entered the royal palace behind the king of deer.

original: mṛgarājā ca mahānasa praviṣṭo imehi ca naigamehi rājā arthakaraṇasmi upaviṣṭo vijñapto //
analyzed: mṛga rājā ca mahānasa praviṣṭaḥ imehi ca naigamehi rājā upaviṣṭaḥ vijñaptaḥ
translated: The king of deer entered the kitchen, and the city-dwellers, who were sitting in the king’s court on some business, made a report.

original: mahārāja tattaka mṛgayūtha sarva kṣīṇa //
analyzed: mahā rāja tattaka mṛga yūtha sarva kṣīṇa
translated: “Great king, that herd of deer has been completely destroyed.

original: aheṭhakā śuṣkārdrāṇi tṛṇāni bhakṣayanti na kasyaci aparādhyanti te ca sarve kṣapitā aya so yūthapati svayamāgato //
analyzed: śuṣka ārdrāṇi tṛṇāni bhakṣayanti na kasyacid aparādhyanti te ca sarve kṣapitāḥ saḥ yūtha pati svayam āgataḥ
translated: They were harmless, eating dry and green grass, and did not offend anyone, but they have all been destroyed. Now the leader of the herd has come himself.

original: durlabho mahārāja edṛśo mṛgarājā prāsādiko darśanīyo janasya cakṣuramaṇīyo //
analyzed: durlabhaḥ mahā rāja edṛśaḥ mṛgarājā prāsādikaḥ darśanīyaḥ janasya cakṣu ramaṇīyaḥ
translated: Great king, it is difficult to find such a beautiful and handsome deer, pleasing to the eyes of the people.

original: nagarāto janā nirdhāvanti udyāna vā taḍāga vā ārāma vā puṣkariṇī vā ca te pi ta mṛgarāja paśyitvā prītā bhavanti alakārabhūta nagaropavanasya
analyzed: nagarātaḥ janāḥ nirdhāvanti udyāna vā taḍāga vā ārāma vā puṣkariṇī vā ca te pi mṛgarāja paśyitvā prītāḥ bhavanti alakāra bhūta nagara upavanasya
translated: People run out of the city to the parks, ponds, gardens, and lotus ponds. They become joyful upon seeing that deer king. He is like an ornament to the city and its parks.

original: yadi mahārājasya prasādo bhaveyā eṣo mṛgarājā jīvanto mucyeyā //
analyzed: yadi mahā rājasya prasādaḥ bhaveyāḥ eṣaḥ mṛgarājā jīvantaḥ mucyeyāḥ
translated: If it pleases the great king, let that deer king be released alive.”

original: rājñā amātyā āṇattā //🔽gacchatha ta mṛgarāja mahārāja mahānasāto ānetha //
analyzed: rājñā amātyā āṇattā  gacchatha ta mṛgarāja mahārāja mahānasātau ānetha
translated: The king ordered his ministers,🔽“Go and bring that deer king from the royal kitchen.”

original: so tehi amātyehi gatvā mahānasāto ānīto rājño sakāśa //
analyzed: saḥ tehi amātyehi gatvā mahānasātaḥ ānītaḥ rājñaḥ sakāśa
translated: The ministers went and brought the deer king from the kitchen to the king.

original: rājā ta mṛgarāja pṛcchati //
analyzed: rājā ta mṛgarāja pṛcchati
translated: The king asked the deer king,

original: ki tva svayamāgato nāsti bhūyo kocit mṛgo ya tuva svayamāgato ti //
analyzed: kim svayam āgataḥ na asti bhūyas kaścid mṛgaḥ ya svayam āgataḥ ti
translated: But it is not the case that no other deer has ever come of its own accord.

original: so mṛgarājā āha //
analyzed: saḥ mṛgarājā āha
translated: The king of deer replied,

original: na hi mahārāja nāsti apare mṛgāḥ //
analyzed: na hi mahā rāja na asti apare mṛgāḥ
translated: “No, your majesty, there are other deer.

original: ki tu adya dvitīyasya mṛga yūthasya osaro //
analyzed: ki tu adya dvitīyasya mṛga yūthasya osaro
translated: But today it is the turn of the second herd of deer.

original: tatra yasyā mṛgīye vāro āpadyati sā gurviṇī duve potakā kukṣismi //
analyzed: tatra yasyāḥ mṛgīye vāraḥ āpadyati sā gurviṇī
translated: And in that herd there is a doe whose turn it is to go to the king’s kitchen. She is pregnant and has two young ones in her womb.

original: sā mṛgī vucyati gaccha mahānasa tava adya vāro //
analyzed: sā mṛgī vucyati gaccha mahānasa tava adya
translated: She was told, ‘Go, it is your turn today.’

original: dvitīyamṛgayūthe viśākho yūthapati asti //
analyzed: dvitīya mṛga yūthe viśākhaḥ yūtha patiḥ asti
translated: In the second herd of deer there is a leader named Viśākha.

original: sā ta gatvā āha //🔽mama adya osaro rājño mahānasa gantu kintu aha gurviṇī duve me potakā kukṣismi icchāmi anya visarjayitu ya vela aha prasūtā bhaviṣya
analyzed: sā ta gatvā āha  mama adya osaraḥ rājñaḥ mahānasa gantu kintu aha gurviṇī me potakā icchāmi
translated: She went and said,

original: tato gamiṣyāmi //
analyzed: tatas gamiṣyāmi
translated: ‘Today it is my turn, and I must go to the king’s kitchen. But I am pregnant and have two young ones in my womb. I want to send someone else in my place, and when I have given birth I will go.’🔽But the other deer would not agree to go in her place.

original: tato yo anyo mṛgo āṇāpyati so na icchati gantu jalpati etasyā mṛgīye osaro eṣā gacchatūti tehi mṛgehi na mucyati //
analyzed: tatas yaḥ anyaḥ mṛgaḥ āṇāpyati saḥ naḥ icchati gantu jalpati etasyāḥ mṛgīye eṣā gacchatu uti tehi mṛgehi na mucyati
translated: And when another deer was ordered to go, he would not agree, saying, ‘It is the turn of that doe. Let her go.’ And he was not released by the other deer.

original: tava adya osaro tva gacchāhi sā tehi amucyantī mama mūle āgatā //
analyzed: tava adya osaro tva gacchāhi sā tehi amucyantī mama mūle āgatā
translated: ‘Today it is your turn. You go.’ But she was not released by them, and so she came to me.

original: aha tāye vijñapto mama adya tato yūthāto osaro me duve potakā kukṣismi na ca tehi mucyāmi tadicchāmi mṛgarājena ito yūthāto anyamāṇāpayitu
analyzed: aha tāye vijñaptaḥ mama adya tatas yūthātaḥ osaraḥ me na ca tehi mucyāmi tat icchāmi mṛgarājena itas yūthātaḥ
translated: I have informed her that today it is my turn from that herd, and that I have two young ones in my womb, and that they will not let me go. Therefore I wish that the king of deer should order another from this herd

original: yo rājño mahānasa gaccheyā /
analyzed: yaḥ rājñaḥ mahānasa gaccheyā
translated: to go to the king's kitchen.

original: yena antareṇa aha prasūtā bhaviṣya tato gamiṣya //
analyzed: yena antareṇa aha prasūtā bhaviṣya tatas gamiṣya
translated: I will go from wherever I give birth.

original: tasyā maye mṛgīye abhaya dinna mayāpi yo mṛgo āṇāpyati so na icchati /
analyzed: tasyāḥ maye mṛgīye abhaya dinna mayā api yaḥ mṛgaḥ āṇāpyati saḥ naḥ icchati
translated: I gave that doe immunity, but the deer that was ordered by me did not want to go.

original: na asmāka osaro dvitīyasya yuthasya osaro eva yoyo āṇāpyati soso na icchati anosarasmi ihāgantu //
analyzed: na asmākam osaraḥ dvitīyasya osaraḥ eva sosaḥ naḥ icchati anosarasmi iha āgantu
translated: It is not our turn, it is the turn of the second herd. Whoever is ordered does not want to go when it is not his turn.

original: so ha jānāmi mayā etasyā mṛgīye abhaya dinna gacchāmi svayanti so aha svayamāgato //
analyzed: saḥ ha jānāmi mayā etasyāḥ mṛgīye gacchāmi svayanti saḥ aha svayam āgataḥ
translated: I know that I have given that doe immunity. I will go myself. He came himself.

original: so rājā tasya mṛgasya śrutvā vismito sarvo ca janakāyo aho yāvaddhārbhiko mṛgarājā //
analyzed: saḥ rājā tasya mṛgasya śrutvā vismitaḥ sarvaḥ ca jana kāyaḥ aho yāvat hārbhikaḥ mṛga rājā
translated: When the king heard that deer, he was amazed, and the whole crowd of people said, Oh, how noble is the king of deer!

original: tasya kāśirājño bhavati //
analyzed: tasya kāśirājñaḥ bhavati
translated: Then the king of Kāśi thought:

original: nāya tiriccho yaḥ eṣo mṛgo parasya kāraṇena ātmāna parityajati dharma jānāti /
analyzed: yaḥ eṣaḥ mṛgo parasya kāraṇena ātmāna parityajati dharma jānāti
translated: This is not an ordinary deer, who for the sake of another gives up his own self and knows the Dharma.

original: vaya tiricchā ye vaya dharma na jānāma ye imeṣā evarūpāṇā satvaratnānāmaheṭhakānā heṭhāmutpadyema //
analyzed: ye vaya dharma na jānāma ye imeṣā evarūpāṇām satva ratnānām aheṭhakānām heṭhām utpadyema
translated: We are indeed unfortunate, we who do not know the Dharma, and who, having harmed such a precious being, have caused harm to arise.

original: so ta mṛgarājāmāha //
analyzed: saḥ ta mṛgarājām āha
translated: He said to the king of deer:

original: prīto smi tava sakāśāto sakṛpo ca mahātmā ca tva ya mṛgabhūtena te tasyā ātmabhṛtyāye mṛgīye abhaya dinna //
analyzed: prītaḥ smi tava sakāśāt ca mahātmā ca tva ya mṛga bhūtena te tasyāḥ ātma bhṛtyāye mṛgīye abhaya dinna
translated: I am pleased with you, you are compassionate, magnanimous, and you, being a deer, have given safety to that doe who supports your life.

original: aha pi tava āgamya tvadvacanātsarvamṛgānā ca abhaya demi //
analyzed: aha pi tava āgamya tvad vacanāt sarva mṛgānā ca abhaya demi
translated: I too, relying on you and at your word, give safety to all deer.

original: adyāgreṇa ye ca tatra uddeśe teṣā sarveṣā mṛgāṇā abhaya dadāmi gacchāhi vasatha abhītā anuttastā //
analyzed: adya agreṇa ye ca tatra uddeśe teṣām sarveṣām mṛgāṇām abhaya dadāmi gacchāhi vasatha abhītā
translated: From now on, in that region, I give safety to all deer. Go and live without fear or anxiety.

original: rājñā nagare ghaṇṭhāghoṣaṇā kārāpitā //
analyzed: rājñā nagare ghaṇṭhā ghoṣaṇā kārāpitā
translated: The king had a proclamation made in the city by beating the drum:

original: na kenacit mama vijite mṛgā viheṭhayitavyā tasya rājño teṣā mṛgānāmabhayadānapradānāt /
analyzed: na kenacid mama vijite mṛgā viheṭhayitavyā tasya rājñaḥ teṣām mṛgānām abhaya dāna pradānāt
translated: By no one in my realm should deer be harmed. Because of that king's gift of safety to the deer,

original: yāvaddeveṣu śabdamabhyudgata /
analyzed: yāvat deveṣu śabdam abhyudgata
translated: the news spread among the gods.

original: śakreṇa devānāmindreṇa rājño jijñāsanārtha anekāni mṛgaśatāni mṛgasahasrāṇi nirmitāni //
analyzed: śakreṇa devānām indreṇa rājñaḥ jijñāsana artha anekāni mṛga śatāni mṛga sahasrāṇi nirmitāni
translated: Śakra, lord of the gods, in order to test the king, created many hundreds and thousands of deer.

original: sarvo kāśijanapado mṛgehi ākīrṇo nāsti so kṣetro yatra na mṛgāḥ //
analyzed: sarvaḥ kāśi janapadaḥ mṛga ihi ākīrṇaḥ na asti saḥ kṣetraḥ yatra na mṛgāḥ
translated: The entire country of Kāśi was filled with deer, there was no field where there were no deer.

original: jānapadehi rājā vijñapto //
analyzed: jānapadehi rājā vijñaptaḥ
translated: The people of the country reported this to the king.

original: tena dāni nyagrodhena mṛgarājñā sā mṛgī vucyati //
analyzed: tena dāni nyagrodhena mṛga rājñā sā mṛgī
translated: Then the king of the deer, Nyagrodha, spoke to the doe,

original: bhadre gaccha viśākhasya yutha //
analyzed: bhadre gaccha viśākhasya yutha
translated: saying, “Go, my good woman, to the herd of Viśākha.”

original: sā āha //
analyzed: sā āha
translated: She replied,

original: mṛgarāja na gamiṣyāmi vara tava mūle mṛta na viśākhamūle jīvita //
analyzed: mṛgarāja na gamiṣyāmi vara tava mūle mṛta na viśākha mūle
translated: “King of the deer, I will not go. It is better for me to die at your feet than to live at the feet of Viśākha.”

original: sā dāni mṛgī gāthā bhāṣati //
analyzed: sā dāni mṛgī gāthāḥ bhāṣati
translated: Then the doe spoke this verse:

original: nyagrodhameva seveyā na viśākhamabhiprārthayet /
analyzed: nyagrodham eva seveyāḥ na viśākham abhiprārthayet
translated: “One should serve the Nyagrodha tree, not seek the Viśākha tree.

original: nyagrodhasmi mṛta śreyo na viśākhasmi jīvita //
analyzed: na viśākhasmi jīvita
translated: It is better to die in the Nyagrodha tree than to live in the Viśākha tree.”

original: jānapadā rāja vijñāpenti //
analyzed: jānapadāḥ rāja vijñāpenti
translated: The people of the country reported this to the king:

original: udajyate janapado rāṣṭra sphīta vinaśyati /
analyzed: udajyate janapadaḥ rāṣṭra sphīta vinaśyati
translated: “The country is being destroyed, the prosperous kingdom is perishing.

original: mṛgā dhānyāni khādanti ta niṣedha janādhipa //
analyzed: mṛgāḥ dhānyāni khādanti ta niṣedha janādhipa
translated: The deer are eating the crops. Stop this, O lord of the people!”

original: udajyatu janapadi sphīta rāṣṭra vinaśyatu /
analyzed: udajyatu janapadi sphīta rāṣṭra vinaśyatu
translated: “Let the country be destroyed, let the prosperous kingdom perish.

original: na tveva mṛgarājasya vara dattvā mṛṣa bhaṇe //
analyzed: na tu eva mṛgarājasya vara dattvā mṛṣa bhaṇe
translated: But I will not break my promise after giving a boon to the king of the deer.”

original: mṛgāṇā dāyo dinno mṛgadāyo ti ṛṣipattano //
analyzed: mṛgāṇā dāyaḥ dinnaḥ mṛga dāyaḥ ti ṛṣi pattanaḥ
translated: The gift of deer was given, and Ṛṣipatana became known as Mṛgadāya.

original: dvādaśehi varṣehi bodhisatvo tuṣitabhavanāto cyaviṣyatīti śuddhāvāsā devā brāhmaṇaveśa nirmiṇiya vedā ca mantrā ca dvātriśa mahāpuruṣalakṣaṇā
analyzed: dvādaśehi varṣehi bodhisatvaḥ tuṣita bhavanātaḥ cyaviṣyati iti vedā ca mantrā ca dvātriśa mahāpuruṣa lakṣaṇā
translated: “In twelve years the Bodhisattva will pass away from the Tusita abode,” and the Śuddhāvāsa devas, creating the form of a brāhman, recited the Vedas and the Mantras and the thirty-two marks of a Great Man.

original: brāhmaṇā vācenti yathā bodhisatvamihāgata vyākarensuḥ ///
analyzed: brāhmaṇāḥ yathā bodhisatvam iha āgata vyākarensuḥ
translated: The brāhmans proclaimed how the Bodhisattva, when he came to this world, was declared to be a Great Man.
